XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Alleged Deliberate Misleading of the House by the Premier
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, on 7 October 2010 the Leader of the Opposition rose on a matter of privilege alleging that words spoken by the honourable the Premier in a ministerial statement after question time had been removed. It was suggested that the Premier had caused these words to be removed.

Later that day I made a statement in this House clarifying that words that had been spoken by the Premier in the House were not included in the record as they were considered to be a false start to the sentence which was subsequently restated by the Premier. As such, they were a redundancy and, therefore, under the parliament’s editing policy were not included in the record. No correction to the proof was sought or made by the Premier. The decision with respect to the matter was made by Hansard staff.

The Leader of the Opposition has subsequently written to me twice in respect of the matter. Firstly, the Leader of the Opposition has formally requested that the Premier’s omitted words be included in the Hansard . The Leader of the Opposition has pointed to the Premier’s confirmation that she also used these words in a subsequent press conference as evidence that the Premier intended to say them in the House and that the words were not in error and were not a false start. Secondly, the Leader of the Opposition is claiming that the Premier deliberately misled the House.
In accordance with standing orders, I wrote to the Premier on both matters seeking her response. For the information of the House, I table all correspondence in relation to this matter.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Bundle of correspondence relating to matter of privilege raised by Leader of the Opposition.
XML.Hansard-Body: I will deal with the request to include the omitted words in the record first. As my statement of 7 October 2010 makes clear, the principles upon which corrections to the record are accepted are expressly contained in the Members’ Information Manual. These are long-standing principles within Westminster parliaments and are based on the overarching principle that the Record of Proceedings is a report of the proceedings of parliament, not a verbatim record. I have viewed the audiovisual of the Premier’s statement. I am of the strong opinion that the words removed were a false start or a correction and, therefore, a redundancy and were removed correctly in accordance with well-established editorial principles.

I appreciate that given in 2010 we have both audiovisual and edited printed reports of proceedings of the House inconsistencies will occasionally occur. This in turn may lead to a legitimate re-evaluation of editorial policies. However, I am not inclined to retrospectively overturn almost 150 years of policy that affects the official records of the House without the detailed and careful consideration and consent of the House itself. Therefore, I am not going to accede to the Leader of the Opposition’s request.

I will now turn to the Leader of the Opposition’s claim that the Premier deliberately misled the House. I must admit to some doubt as to whether the Leader of the Opposition was claiming that the Premier deliberately misled the House in her words that were removed by Hansard or in her later statement in the House that the words were said in a press conference and not in the House.

In either case, I believe I can easily deal with the allegation. Having viewed the audiovisual of the Premier’s original statement, I am of the opinion that the alleged offending words were a false start or a self-correction. I cannot see how, in these circumstances, the elements required to be proved in terms of deliberately misleading the House could be established. A genuine false start or self-correction of a statement cannot be used as the basis for a claim of deliberately misleading the House.

Furthermore, it has been established that the Premier did not know about or ask for the Hansard record to be edited prior to the green being issued to her for correction. Therefore, it is a reasonable conclusion that the Premier did not believe she had made the statement in the House, but believed the words may have come from the press conference. Therefore, I am not intending to refer the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Comments by Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I have ordered that a ruling regarding a complaint by the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines, Energy and Minister for Trade against the members for Moggill and Coomera and their cross-complaints against the minister, the member for Capalaba and others be circulated. I table documents relevant to the matter.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Bundle of correspondence relating to matters of privilege raised by the Hon. Stephen Robertson MP and Dr Flegg MP and Mr Crandon MP.
XML.Hansard-Body: I have decided not to refer any matter raised to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in the parliamentary record.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Honourable Members, the reputation of all members and the dignity and reputation of this House can be adversely affected when members make unfounded or mischievous allegations of unethical behaviour against other members. It does not assist when members retaliate against such charges by making their own counter-charges.
On 16 September 2010, in debate on the Land Valuation Bill, a long saga of claim and counter-claim began.

During debate on that Bill the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines, Energy and Minister for Trade alleged that the Member for Moggill and the Member for Coomera had breached Standing Order 260 by not declaring in the debate their interest in the Bill. The Minister followed this allegation in writing as required by Standing Orders.

Both the Member for Moggill and the Member for Coomera when provided an opportunity to do so denied emphatically the charges by the Minister, rightly pointing out both previous rulings on the narrow scope of Standing Order 260 and an information paper produced by the former Members’ Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee.
Both members also made counter-charges, alleging that other members of the House, including the Minister, owned interests that should be declared if they were required to declare the matters.

The Member for Moggill also alleged that the Minister had misled the House by declaring himself a man of modest means. The Member for Coomera also added an additional allegation as regards the Member for Capalaba for an alleged breach of Standing Order 262.

I shall try to not waste the House’s time by going into too much detail of the claims and counter claims and will table, for the benefit of the House, all correspondence received in respect of these matters. I note that I did not in all cases write to members mentioned adversely seeking their responses to complaints made, as I was satisfied on the face that no credible matter arose.

In short, I find that the debate on the Bill on 16 September descended into an acrimonious, undignified and unparliamentary exercise. There was no substance to the Minister’s original allegations of unethical conduct and there was no substance in the members’ counter claims against the Minister’s conduct or the conduct of other members, including the Member for Capalaba.

To assist members I have again ordered to be circulated in the House an information note by the Members’ Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee published in 2005 on standing orders 259 and 260.
I consider the Minister’s statement about his ‘modest means’ not to be something that can be objectively determined, but simply what is known as ‘puffery’.
I am not intending to refer any of these matters to the Integrity Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Alleged Deliberate Misleading of the House by a Minister
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I have ordered that a ruling regarding a complaint--
Honourable members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides of the House will come to order! I have ordered that a ruling regarding a complaint by the member for Mudgeeraba against the Attorney-General of deliberately misleading the House be circulated. I have decided not to refer the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee. I table the correspondence with respect to this matter.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Bundle of correspondence relating to matter of privilege raised by Ms Bates MP.
XML.Hansard-Body: I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in the parliamentary record.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: On 7 October 2010 the Member for Mudgeeraba wrote to me alleging that the Attorney-General had deliberately misled the House on two occasions in debate on 6 October 2010 deliberately misled the House.

The member’s essential complaint was that the Attorney-General in his summing up of the Justice and Other Legislation Amendment Bill misrepresented the contribution of the Member on the Bill. Indeed, the member alleges that the Attorney-General attributed statements to the Member that were not the member’s statements.
In accordance with Standing Order 269(5), on 13 October 2010 I wrote to the Attorney-General, enclosing a copy of the member’s allegations and requested a response.
On 21 October 2010 the Attorney-General provided a very detailed letter of response. For the benefit of the House, I table a copy of all the correspondence in this matter.
It is well established that there are three elements to be established when it is alleged that a member has committed the contempt of deliberately misleading the House:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • first, the statement must, in fact, have been misleading;
• secondly, it must be established that the member making the statement knew at the time the statement was made that it was incorrect; and
• thirdly, in making it, the member must have intended to mislead the House.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There is always a danger that a member, in referring to an earlier speech by another member, will misrepresent that member’s comments.

Various parliamentary procedures and rules were developed around this problem. In past times it was well accepted that proof copies of Hansard could not be quoted, because members who had made the speech had not yet had the opportunity to correct those proofs (See rulings by Speaker Nicholson 9 September 1971 at 457 and Acting Speaker Lickiss 28 March 1973 at 3362).

Similarly, there was also a rule, then enshrined in standing orders (former Standing Order 120), that speeches from the same session could not be referred to in debate (See Deputy Speaker Row 6 March 1984 at 1806), although it was held to apply to concluded debates, and that Hansard or speeches in the same debate could be referred to or quoted (Chairman Mann, 21 October 1948 at 864).

In both New Zealand and the Commonwealth House of Representatives, standing orders allow corrections of misrepresentations. Standing Order 69 of the House of Representatives provides a member can speak again in a question to explain some material part of his or her speech which has been misquoted or misunderstood. In making this explanation the Member may not interrupt another Member addressing the House, debate the matter, or introduce any new matter.
I see some merit in this type of procedure, but it currently forms no part of Queensland procedure.
It is clear that a deliberate misrepresentation can constitute a deliberate misleading of the House and a contempt only if all the elements described above can be established.

However, I do not believe that any of the elements have been sufficiently been made out. The Attorney-General’s letter has persuaded me that he was only attempting to paraphrase the member’s comments. The inverted commas in the Hansard of the Attorney-General’s speech were a punctuation device used by Hansard, not inserted by the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General maintains that he was not directly quoting the member, and he could not have been given her speech was less than two hours before his summing up and there was no time to obtain and check the Hansard of the member’s speech.
I have, therefore, decided not to refer the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Rules Relating to Questions and Answers
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: As is my practice, following last sitting week I reviewed the Record of Proceedings . This review highlighted an issue that I did not address adequately when the Acting Leader of House raised the matter. Standing order 115 provides for the rules for questions. One of the rules is that questions should not contain imputations. In at least three questions on the last sitting day, 7 October, members in their questions made imputations by use of the word ‘rorts’. I advise all honourable members to consider the rules relating to questions.

This leads me to the rules relating to answers. On 1 October 2010 the member for Maroochydore wrote to me regarding an answer to a question on notice from the honourable Attorney-General. I table the member’s correspondence.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Correspondence relating to matter of privilege raised by Ms Simpson MP.
XML.Hansard-Body: The member complains that the Attorney in his response attacked the member on a false premise, that the answer was unparliamentary and if the answer had been made in the House the member would have had a remedy. I have reviewed the answer to the question. The member may well feel aggrieved by the tone and content of the answer, but I am not convinced that if it had been an answer made in the House the member would have had an immediate remedy as there was no personal reflection. Therefore, I intend to take no further action. However, I do warn all honourable ministers that answers to questions, either on notice or without notice, are required to adhere to the normal rules of this House as regards personal reflections and parliamentary language.

XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.42 am): Queensland is on the precipice of a brand-new industry--an industry that means thousands of jobs for a generation of Queenslanders, an industry that means millions of dollars for our state, and an industry that will forever alter the character of some of our key regional areas. On Friday the federal government gave its conditional environmental approval for two multibillion-dollar liquid natural gas projects--the $7.7 billion Santos-Petronas Gladstone LNG project and QGC Pty Ltd’s $8 billion Curtis LNG project. Five years ago these industries were just a pipedream. Today they are a reality. Our government promised to invest in jobs and in new industries for Queensland, and we have done exactly that. There is an army of workers ready to put their shovels in the ground and get to work building these projects.

Importantly, these projects strike a balance between developing a key industry and protecting our precious environment. We said that we wanted this industry to go ahead, but not at any cost. Through the state approvals process we have already imposed more than 1,200 environmental and social conditions which cover everything from community support through to environment protection. Additionally, the federal government approval imposes a further 300 conditions, making these projects the most environmentally stringent in the history of Australia. Queenslanders can be assured that we will be working with both companies throughout the life of the project to ensure that these tough conditions are adhered to. These projects combined potentially mean 10,000 jobs for Queenslanders in what is a world-first industry. Queensland will be the first place in the world where coal seam gas will be converted to liquid natural gas. This will excite international interest in what is happening here. Pending final government approvals and investment decisions by the companies, work could possibly start on these two projects later this year.

This has been some time coming. This is the end result of a process that has taken approximately two years and involved around 27,000 pages of material being assessed by the Queensland Coordinator-General. But with a brand-new industry now within our grasp, it has been well and truly worth the effort.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.45 am): I am very pleased to advise the House that I spent a week recently governing Queensland from Townsville. My week in Townsville--
Opposition members interjected.

Ms BLIGH: If you listen, you will hear. My week in Townsville has reinforced to me that this great city has an extraordinary number of opportunities that are about to come together. These projects could turbocharge Townsville’s economy in a way never before seen in the city’s history. There is the relocation of Defence Battalion 3RAR to Townsville, which will bring about 750 soldiers and their families; the NBN rollout; the expansion of the Townsville port; a possible expansion of Sun Metals; the expansion of Abbot Point; Townsville’s potential as a centre for tropical health excellence; connection of the north-west minerals province to the national electricity grid; and the potential of baseload renewable energy into Townsville from green hydroenergy from PNG.

Our government has a big vision for Townsville, and I want the city to make the most of its opportunities. That is part of the reason why I went to Townsville to run the state for a week. As a result of my stay, we are now working to fast-track the state development area in Townsville to provide industrial land to market quickly. I can also advise that we are now working on the feasibility of building more government office space in the CBD to help revitalise the city centre. In addition, I am following up on a number of very good ideas that were raised with me by many businesses, community groups, sporting organisations and arts agencies that took the time to visit me in Townsville and bring their ideas forward.

Running the state from outside of Brisbane for a week was a new approach for a Premier. As a test run, I have to say it was a big success. The technology enables me in this position to liberate myself from Brisbane geographically. I was able to use videoconferencing to chair meetings in Brisbane and keep the decisions flowing. That included a virtual cabinet meeting--a first for Queensland. Staying put there in Townsville for a week also gave me more time to sit down with people, and I relished the opportunity to immerse myself in all things Townsville. I had 15 separate face-to-face meetings that involved more than 70 people covering everything from business, education, community, sport and the arts. I also spoke at some eight functions attended by hundreds of people and had an opportunity at them to chat informally afterwards with many of the guests about their ambitions for this great city. I intend to be back in Townsville on a regular basis, but I also intend to take this idea to other regional cities of Queensland to use technology that in the 21st century allows a Premier of Queensland to effectively run the state from any part of the state.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Breast Cancer Awareness Month; Creed, Mrs P
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.48 am): October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month and, because I am a firm supporter of this important initiative, I was heartened to see so many men and women yesterday wearing pink as part of Pink Ribbon Day. Yesterday I also joined thousands of other Australian women who signed up to the National Breast Cancer Foundation’s national online research register called Register 4. Participants in the register are required to provide basic information about themselves and their lifestyle and are then emailed about each new research project that they may be eligible to participate in. The National Breast Cancer Foundation is calling for one million women to join the register, and I urge all women to heed that call and sign up. I make the point that the register is also open to men and that you do not have to have had any personal experience of breast cancer to be very helpful in breast cancer research in that as much as anything you can be part of a control group. So I do encourage every member to consider it and to talk about this register in their own electorates.

We have got some great researchers in Australia doing terrific work but they need people to be part of those research efforts. Breast cancer affects one in 11 Queensland women every year and it claims almost 500 Queensland lives each year. While there is currently no cure, early detection is playing an increasingly important role.

The Chief Health Officer in Queensland estimates that the incidence of breast cancer could be reduced by 25 per cent to 30 per cent if 70 per cent of women aged 50 to 69 years were screened regularly. Currently, only 58 per cent of this target group are getting their free screenings through BreastScreen Queensland. I also know that the rate at which women in city and urban centres get screened is lower than those in rural, remote and regional areas. I encourage all Queensland women, wherever they live and whatever their age, to talk to their GP about prevention strategies and to take advantage of the free, world-class professional and modern services offered by BreastScreen Queensland. Our investment in this service means that fast and efficient screen services are saving time for busy women, and digital mammography technology allows breast images to be checked immediately for quality. These advances mean that a one-on-one appointment with a female health professional takes only about 15 to 20 minutes.

This week is not just about recognising the bravery of the many Queensland women and their families who have experienced, who are enduring or who are fighting breast cancer; it is also an opportunity for us to recognise the tireless work of the many people who are supporting women across Queensland in their difficult and individual journeys. One such person to whom I rise to pay tribute today is nurse Patsy Creed. Next month Nurse Creed will retire from the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital after 34 years of service. Since the early 1990s, Mrs Creed has been a pioneer and driving force in achieving the introduction of breast care nurses to Queensland’s public healthcare services. In fact, Nurse Creed is one of the first dedicated breast care nurses here in Queensland. They are now a feature of caring for women with breast cancer around Australia. Members would be aware of the work that the McGrath Foundation does in this area. I think it is important that we recognise one of those people who was a pioneer of this initiative, because it is making a real difference to these women who are experiencing breast cancer. So on behalf of the House and on behalf of all of those who have fought, who are currently fighting or who will fight breast cancer, I give our thanks for the unflagging support and energy that Mrs Creed and her fellow breast care nurses have devoted to this cause. Thirty-four years of service is a great achievement. It is a great contribution in a very important area. I also ask honourable members to join with me in congratulating not only Nurse Creed but also the many unsung heroes who play a role in the fight against breast cancer and all other forms of cancer.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.52 am): Last night, I was pleased to host an official reception to celebrate the centenary of the University of Queensland. In attendance were Chancellor Mr John Story, Vice-Chancellor Professor Paul Greenfield as well as many stakeholders, members of staff and members of the alumni, including a number of members from all sides of this House. This was an opportunity to honour the important contribution of the University of Queensland to our state.

The university began with an initial intake of 83 students, 23 of whom were women. It now has more than 40,000 students enrolled from more than 120 countries. At the official inauguration of the university in 1909, the then Premier William Kidston famously said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There is a difference between the youngest University in the Empire and the oldest: Oxford was established by a King; the university of Queensland is established by the people.
XML.Hansard-Body: This university has continued to give throughout its 100 years opportunities to young people regardless of where they live in Queensland and the financial circumstances of their families. This university has set the bar for higher education in Queensland and is a world leader in many fields, including medical research, hypersonic flight, the world of whales and Australian anthropology. As some members may be aware--it is a somewhat quirky fact--it is home to the world’s longest continuously running laboratory experiment, known as the pitch drop experiment. This experiment was started in 1927 by Professor Thomas Parnell to demonstrate to students that some substances that appear to be solid are, in fact, very high-viscosity fluids. Parnell poured a heated sample of pitch into a sealed funnel and allowed it to settle for three years. In 1930, the seal at the neck of the funnel was cut, allowing the pitch to start flowing. Since 1930 there have been eight drops of pitch. Spectacularly, nobody has actually seen it happen. It is now the subject of an entry into the Guinness Book of Records and is another reason for UQ to be on the international stage.

All Queenslanders can be proud of this great centre of learning, and not just because of its world-famous pitch drop experiment. It has been a place where our best minds have been trained and given direction in life. It has been a centre of ideas and science, of words, art, history and all of those wonderful things that make up the sum of our knowledge as humans. As a former graduate--an honour I share with other members of this House--I congratulate the university on reaching this milestone anniversary. I have every confidence that its next 100 years will be just as remarkable as its first century of achievement.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.55 am): I think just about every one of us in this House can remember a bully from our schooldays. Whether we were the victims of a bully or we witnessed the bullying, we know that the actions of a bully can scar a young mind for life. That is why our government is determined to stand up to bullies. We are determined that our schools will be places where our children can reach their full potential in a safe environment and where our teachers and other staff can enjoy a workplace free of this sort of activity.

I am pleased to announce today the appointment of high-profile psychologist Dr Michael Carr-Gregg as the state government’s official antibullying expert. Dr Carr-Gregg has been engaged to provide ongoing practical, effective advice on tackling this challenging social issue. The appointment is the next step in the fight against bullying and demonstrates that we are serious about making our schools safer, more tolerant places for students. Dr Carr-Gregg is a well-respected expert who will provide the government with advice on future policy directions and procedures relating to bullying. He will also be involved in projects such as conducting workshops with principals and other staff and creating resources for schools. Dr Carr-Gregg has recently carried out presentations at 30 Action Against Bullying seminars across Queensland. He will ensure that the government has within easy reach a qualified expert that parents respect and trust.
This appointment is made on the back of recommendations from the Queensland Schools Alliance Against Violence report, which I table today.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Report, dated October 2010, titled ‘Working Together: Queensland Schools Alliance Against Violence Report’.
XML.Hansard-Body: We established this task force in February this year to bring together the Catholic, independent and state schooling sectors to find new ways to stop bullying and violence in our schools, particularly in the context of the growth in the use of technology in cyperspace by young people. I would like to thank Professor Ian O’Connor, the Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University, for his leadership of this alliance.

With the release of the report and recommendations, we have a clear blueprint for how we move can forward and continue to make progress on this issue. The recommendations were developed through careful consideration and each of the school sectors will now look at the best ways to implement them. Our schools will be encouraged to develop and implement a cybersafety strategy. Cyberbullying is a particularly challenging issue, because this form of harassment can take place at any time away from the schoolyard, usually online and on mobile phones. Simply banning mobile phones or Facebook for students is not realistic. The world has moved on and our children, and indeed many of their parents, regard these things as essential.

We are considering a raft of measures such as online programs designed to help schools develop cultures of respect as well as to increase cybersafety skills. Schools could also be urged to establish cybersafety teams, which would work within the school to develop cybersafety security systems, policies and acceptable use agreements. Dr Carr-Gregg has indicated that he intends to provide constructive criticism when there is the need for more action. He has also said that Queensland is leading Australia in attempting to address these issues in our schools. Unfortunately, no society has ever succeeded in completely stamping out bullying. However, our government is absolutely determined to make sure that everything that can be done is being done and that is the least that our children and our schools deserve.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training)
(9.59 am): The safety and wellbeing of all Queensland students is a top priority for the Bligh government. Over the past 12 months we have taken strong action to make Queensland schools even safer. Last year all state schools reviewed their responsible behaviour plans for students to make sure they set high standards of behaviour and contained appropriate responses to bullying and cyberbullying. In December we announced our commitment to grant state school principals the authority to suspend and exclude students. We also engaged Dr Ken Rigby whose report and professional development vodcasts provided a sound foundation for further work to tackle bullying head on. Education ministers across the country accepted Queensland’s push for a national ‘Say no to bullying day’ to be held in March next year. In February we established the Schools Alliance Against Violence, implementing one of Dr Rigby’s recommendations. Under the chairmanship of the highly respected Professor Ian O’Connor, Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University, the alliance brought together the state, Catholic and independent school sectors to tackle the complex issue of bullying on a united front. Professor O’Connor’s leadership has been instrumental in shaping the valuable work and recommendations of this alliance.

I welcome the school’s alliance report released today, and its recommendations, along with the announcement of well-respected psychologist Dr Michael Carr-Gregg being appointed as the government’s anti-bullying expert. The three school sectors will now work together in implementing the recommendations. Having seen Dr Carr-Gregg’s work at the alliance’s recent Action Against Bullying seminars across Queensland, I am thrilled he has agreed to come on board to offer his expertise. The response to Dr Carr-Gregg’s presentations was overwhelmingly positive from principals, school staff and parents. He engaged with the audience with real life case studies, video resources, and offered useful advice. It is clear that his practical and personal approach was highly valued with participants using such words as ‘invaluable’, ‘thought provoking’, ‘informative’ and ‘entertaining’ to describe the program. I am pleased all members of the alliance, including representatives from parents and citizens associations, principals associations, the Queensland Teachers Union, Independent Schools Queensland, the Catholic Education Commission, the Queensland Independent Education Union and Education Queensland, have endorsed the report.

Bullying and violence is a whole-of-community issue and is not to be tolerated anywhere at any time. The three school sectors in Queensland are leading the way in the fight against this totally unacceptable behaviour when it occurs in schools. No-one has all the answers, yet by working together we are proving we are serious about stamping out antisocial behaviour and making our schools even safer and more tolerant places for Queensland students.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (10.02 am): Earlier this year an historic agreement was reached on health reform between the Commonwealth and the states. This agreement means a better deal for Queenslanders. It will deliver better hospitals and better health services. It comes after years of inaction and underfunding by the former Howard government. As part of this agreement the Bligh government secured an additional $755 million for delivering improvements in three priority areas: better emergency departments with $150 million to reduce waiting times for more than 150,000 Queenslanders over the next four years; faster elective surgery with $160 million to ensure more Queenslanders get surgery sooner; and more hospital beds with $325 million for 270 new sub-acute care hospital beds over the next four years.

But this agreement is not just about more funding; it will also change the way we deliver health services in the future. We are committed to more localised hospital management with more involvement from clinicians and the community. That is why we will work with the Commonwealth in establishing local hospital networks. These networks will be responsible for the day-to-day operation of public hospitals. It is our aim to establish these networks by 1 July 2011. This is an ambitious time frame and that is why we are getting on with the job of delivering this important reform.

Right now we want to hear Queenslanders’ views on the number, location and boundaries for these new networks. The networks will need to be large enough to operate efficiently and provide a reasonable range of hospital services, yet still be small enough to be effectively managed. Of course, there will still be some services that will continue to be centrally operated. Those services that deliver a real benefit, professionally or clinically to staff, or a better service for patients state-wide, will continue to be operated in this manner. No-one could suggest that instead of Education Queensland or the Queensland Police Service we should have the Longreach school system or the Cloncurry Police Service. A health service is arguably far more complex and deserves to be delivered as such.

Who could forget the federal coalition government’s contribution to health reform, the Tasmanian Mersey Hospital takeover, an isolated and poorly thought-out policy announced in a desperate attempt to win a marginal seat? The Queensland government will not rush reform in this manner. We are committed to getting this right. That is why my department has conducted face-to-face and videoconference consultations with almost 1,000 people in 10 health service districts during 36 sessions across 12 different sites. Over the next month sessions are also planned for Cairns, Mount Isa, the Gold Coast, Nambour and Mackay.

We have heard from staff across every category, as well as GPs, community organisations, health community councils, patient advocates, university clinical schools and peak bodies. Consultations have been scheduled in another seven districts as well as with major health stakeholders. Any Queenslander who wants their view heard can also visit www.health.qld.gov.au/health-reform. All of this feedback will inform the state government’s response to the Commonwealth due later this year. The new networks will have a local CEO and a local governing council and will deliver a real say to Queenslanders on how their local health service is run.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development)
(10.05 am): Around the world right now the debate is sharpening on the correct path for governments to tread as the global economy navigates its way out of the longer tail effects of the global financial crisis. Our government introduced a comprehensive fiscal and economic reform strategy, one that we have had the courage to stand by and one that is delivering. The recovery in Queensland is building and reports this week from commentators have supported the case.
Yesterday, CommSec said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the main positive is in the measure of economic growth--Queensland is second strongest of the states with activity just over 18 per cent higher than the decade average.
XML.Hansard-Body: The report yesterday did not say our economic growth was behind other states. The fact is it said we were second strongest. It did not create a league table or rank economies, despite some yesterday suggesting that our economy was ranked last. The fact is it is not. Those who suggest it is on the basis of this report are either intent on deliberately talking down the economy or uninterested in the facts getting in the way of a campaign, or perhaps just innumerate.

There are challenges--many challenges--and the recovery is not yet full blown. I have said this consistently and yesterday the CommSec report backed it up. I note also for the record of the House that CommSec has, in fact, changed its methodology after serious concerns were raised by me and other Treasurers. This morning Access Economics has released its business outlook for the September quarter. Access Economics has again improved the growth estimates for Queensland for 2010-11, increasing by half a percent through to 3.8 per cent--ahead of its national forecast of 3.7 per cent. Its forecast improves further in 2011-12, out to 4.4 per cent. Access says in its report--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queensland is expected to once again carve out a growing share of Australia’s economy and population over the longer term.
XML.Hansard-Body: We are on the right side of a global industrial revolution. Challenges around property in particular and those related to access to credit are also identified in the report. The report makes note of the potential for Queensland’s LNG industry to provide another layer of strength to our economy. Shepherding this industry to a reality was a key commitment of this government and one that we are delivering on. The fact is the policies we have put in place to create jobs and to expand the economy are working. The evidence is there for all to see, except for those blinded by their campaign of negativity. One can trawl through any report to cherry pick quotes, but the numbers, as ever, tell the real and indisputable story. Jobs have been created in Queensland each month for the last 14 months. The outlook for the state’s economy is a positive one. By maintaining our commitment to invest in the $17 billion building program, the Bligh government’s economic policies are about securing long-term prosperity for the Queensland economy. We are delivering jobs, not cuts; an economy recovery, not a body blow to growth--jobs, not cuts, just like we said we would.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology)
(10.08 am): Our government takes the issue of protecting people against exposure to asbestos very seriously. QBuild has, for many years, led by example when it comes to increasing awareness of asbestos issues and providing specialist training for its staff to keep them safe. In May last year QBuild began a practical asbestos training program which complies with two national codes of practice.

In April this year, QBuild conducted a PAT refresher program for all trade based and relevant office staff, irrespective of their occupation. The program was conducted in conjunction with Biga Ltd, a Queensland based registered training program. The refresher program allowed staff to sit the asbestos removal certification exam developed by Workplace Health and Safety Queensland to obtain a B-class asbestos removal certificate. As a result of this training, more than 1,150 QBuild staff now hold a B-class licence.

I am very pleased to inform the House that QBuild’s PAT Program has also been formally accredited as a competency by the Training and Employment Regional Council until 2015. This means that the program, accredited as ‘course in fixed asbestos handling and maintenance’, can be used across Australia by the industry to enhance safety when working with asbestos. Biga lodged the program on behalf of QBuild with the Department of Education and Training for accreditation and formal recognition of the training. Although formal agreements have yet to be made, QBuild will work with Biga on how the course can be promoted to registered training providers and the private sector.

This national recognition just goes to show the quality of the training developed by QBuild and the practical commitment of this government to minimising the risk of asbestos. QBuild has also developed a contractors asbestos pack featuring a DVD, safe working procedures and a booklet for correctly and safely managing asbestos. The pack will help ensure contractors doing work for the government know as much about working safely with asbestos as possible and the high standard we expect from them. There are no excuses for them not to follow it.
QBuild staff receive the most comprehensive asbestos training in Australia, and I am pleased that the industry around the country now has the opportunity to benefit from its training and resources.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.11 am): Queenslanders are well versed in preparing for--and recovering from--natural disasters like storms and floods. So far this year, for example, four tropical cyclones have impacted the Queensland coastline and as much as 90 per cent of local government areas across the state have been flood declared. The impact of natural disasters can be heartbreaking for those whose homes are inundated with floodwaters or, worse still, destroyed by cyclones.

The Bligh government recognises that the changing climate patterns will have an impact on the frequency and severity of natural disasters in the future. That is why in 2009 we joined forces with the federal Labor government to develop the Natural Disaster Resilience Program. This four-year, $44 million funding program aims to assist local councils and other disaster response organisations to better prepare for--and mitigate the effects of--natural disasters.

With 124 applications for funding received in the program’s second round, it is obvious that organisations such as local councils are more than willing to partner with the state and federal governments on this important work. In fact, on a visit to Cunnamulla last week, Paroo Shire Council Mayor Jo Sheppard expressed to me her support for the program and her hope that her council’s application for funding would be successful. Murweh Shire Council Mayor Mark O’Brien has also initiated applications through the program to enhance Charleville’s resilience to flooding. I am pleased to advise both Councillor Sheppard and Councillor O’Brien that projects in their areas have been approved. In the Paroo local government area the Wyandra community resource and local emergency coordination centre project has attracted $65,000 in funding. Murweh Shire Council will receive close to $1.4 million in funding for a diversion channel for Bradley’s Gully, a Charleville floodgate strategy and the purchase of the Guardian disaster management software.

These are just four of the 68 projects with a total value of $26 million to receive funding in the Natural Disaster Resilience Program’s second funding round. Other successful projects include flood mapping of the Hughenden urban area, a flood levy improvement project in Balonne Shire, a feasibility and pilot study of flood surveillance cameras in the Ipswich City Council area, and a tropical cyclone storm surge and wave impact study for the Mackay regional coastline.

By acting now to enhance community resilience we can reduce the effects of future natural disasters and the impact they have on our communities. I seek leave to table a list of successful applications.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Schedule of funding for projects.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (10.14 am): Every person in Queensland deserves to go home safely to their loved ones every day after work. Sadly, this does not occur for about 100 workers in Queensland each year. Furthermore, tens of thousands more workers are injured in the workplace each year, exacting a massive human toll for workers, their families and the community.

The Queensland government has made worker safety one of its highest priorities, and part of this means raising awareness among workers and the community about the need to address safety concerns at work. An important part of this approach is our involvement in Safe Work Australia Week, which started on Sunday and continues until Saturday, 30 October 2010.

Safe Work Week was launched on my behalf in Brisbane yesterday by the Parliamentary Secretary for Industrial Relations, the member for Yeerongpilly. He joined the government’s Safety Ambassador, Rugby League legend Mal Meninga, at the launch, where employers and workers heard about the latest efforts and initiatives to cut death and injury in the workplace. Mal is a keen supporter of Safe Work Week and has added his voice to those of experts letting us know how we can work safer. Mal will be talking about his own family tragedy brought on by a workplace incident.

Yesterday’s launch was just the start of a week of activities throughout the state where worker safety will be the focus. Here in Brisbane, I will be joining workers and Mal Meninga in King George Square on Thursday for a free breakfast that will highlight workplace health and safety. Tonight, I will attend the annual Queensland Work Safe Awards, which celebrate innovation in workplace health and safety. Other events are being held throughout the state this week, including regional seminars on how to avoid common workplace injuries, an Indigenous business leaders meeting and a major conference on Zero Harm at Work in Rockhampton.

Workplace safety is not just about employers and workers; it is an issue that impacts everyone. Going to work should mean coming home safe and sound to our loved ones, but the fact is that people die or are seriously injured while doing their jobs and it can happen to anyone at any time. Safety needs to become an integral part of the everyday culture of all workplaces and we must realise that safety is everyone’s responsibility.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (10.16 am): The Bligh government is delivering more for older Queenslanders and those with a disability. We are committed to supporting people who want to remain living in their own homes. We understand that most older people and younger people with a disability wish to remain living in the community but some need support to maintain their independence and social participation. That is why today I am pleased to announce, in conjunction with federal Minister for Mental Health and Ageing, Mark Butler, that almost $51 million in funding for Home and Community Care services will be allocated.

The centrepiece of this announcement is the allocation of almost $7 million for minor and major home modifications for people right across this state. Minor modifications include installing a hand-held shower, modifying steps or installing handrails. These may seem like small changes to many of us, but to those set to benefit these can be huge improvements to their quality of life. It also enables people to remain living in their own homes for longer. The funding for major modifications includes the installation of stair lifts, ramps or bathroom modifications. Almost 5,000 extra Queenslanders are now set to benefit from these modifications, many of whom are pensioners. This funding will assist residents right across Queensland, from Cairns to Caloundra, from Mount Isa to Mackay and from Logan to Longreach.

Along with the almost $7 million for home modifications, key components of the new funding allocation also include $10.9 million to increase support for people in their own homes in areas such as cleaning and bathing as well as support to access their community for respite; $5.7 million in major capital to expand or modify buildings and facilities for centre based day care; $2.1 million to provide domestic assistance, personal care, nursing and allied health; $5.5 million for nursing and allied health care, including administering medication, wound dressings, occupational therapy and podiatry; and $3.3 million for transport to assist people to do things like visit their local doctor, to do their shopping and to do their local banking.

This funding is part of the joint Commonwealth-state Home and Community Care Program. Almost 170,000 Queenslanders benefited from this funding last year. We are committed to ensuring that all Queenslanders remain independent, in their own homes and in their own communities for as long as possible. This significant allocation of funding today is evidence of that commitment. I urge all members to share this good news with members of their local community.

Hon. PG REEVES (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport) (10.19 am): As members know, over the weekend the Gold Coast 600 took place and it has been hailed a roaring success. ‘A Great Show’ roared the Gold Coast Bulletin . And why are they so pleased? Because 170,073 tickets were sold for the three-day event. They are also pleased about the 551,000 viewers nationwide and the fact that the coverage topped its timeslot on Sunday. Early estimates are that the ratings are well up on last year, with an increase of close to 10 per cent on 2008 figures.

The V8 Supercars event was broadcast to over 110 countries around the world, promoting on an international stage what the Gold Coast and Queensland have to offer. Queensland is where Australia shines. Those numbers mean jobs and a boost to tourism, and that is very important for the Gold Coast, which is famous for fun. This government is about jobs and not cuts. That is the difference between the Bligh government and the LNP.

I know that the local members are big supporters of the event, particularly the members for Southport, Albert, Burleigh and Broadwater as well as those opposite. The member for Broadwater was very proud of the performance of the Labrador State School choir, which sang the national anthem prior to the first race on Saturday. It was a stirring rendition.

V8 Supercars Australia, the promoters, need to be congratulated. The Gold Coast 600 is an important part of Queensland’s events calendar. Over the past 19 years it has generated an estimated $700 million for the Gold Coast and Queensland economies. This is just one of many events the Bligh government brings to the people of Queensland, and in particular the Gold Coast region. Next month 10,000 athletes will descend on the Gold Coast for the Pan Pacific Masters Games. Later in November, again the eyes of the nation will turn to the Gold Coast as the AFL takes its national draft on the road for the first time in 25 years. We are about attracting the big events because it means jobs, and we are about jobs and not cuts.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Mining Companies, Environmental Authorities; Australia Pacific LNG
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability) (10.21 am): The Bligh government is serious about protecting our environment. That is why we have tough penalties in place for companies that breach their environmental authorities. For their operations all mining companies require environmental authorities that set strict standards to protect the environment. Most companies do the right thing and have processes in place to manage any risks from their operations. However, the penalties are severe for those who fail to meet their obligations.

Last week the owner of a Cloncurry copper mine was fined $135,000 for causing serious environmental harm when contaminated stormwater was released into the local creek. The company, Great Australian Operations, has also been forced to remove the contaminated material and provide ongoing monitoring of the creek to ensure it is recovering. This case was the latest in a number of prosecutions that we have pursued against mining companies that have caused environmental harm. Last month Ernest Henry Mining was fined $100,000 for illegal discharges from its copper/gold mine near Cloncurry. Earlier this year MMG Century was also fined $130,000 for discharges from its zinc and lead mine into Page Creek north-west of Mount Isa. Those sentences send a clear message to industry that our government takes our environmental legislation very seriously and if companies cause environmental harm we will not hesitate to act.

In addition to this strong deterrence, our government is also working closely with mining companies to ensure they are prepared for the coming wet season and have systems in place to significantly reduce the potential for illegal discharges to occur. Officers have undertaken an inspection program that includes assessing mining companies’ compliance with the water conditions of their environmental authorities. This is to ensure mines have done the preparation needed ahead of the wet season.

I would also like to update the House on the matter regarding Australia Pacific LNG’s operations in the Surat Basin. Last week the company briefed the state government on the detection of traces of hydrocarbon chemicals during routine testing on eight exploration wells. The company advised there is no evidence of environmental harm or risk to landholder bores as the water is isolated from watercourses and livestock. The company has suspended its hydraulic fracturing operation as a precaution. While it is investigating the source of the chemicals, and at government’s request, independent testing has been done on relevant landholder bores to confirm that no environmental harm has occurred. The results of those samples are currently being processed by an independent laboratory as a matter of priority. Whenever there is an unexplained detection on a mine site, we expect companies to act. I look forward to updating the House when final results are received.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (10.24 am): I am pleased to announce that applications are now open for $2 million in funding for rural community building programs. One-off grants of up to $10,000 for projects that improve the economic, social, cultural and environmental capacity of communities in rural Queensland are now open until 7 December. The types of projects we are looking for include programs that attract investment and skilled workers, environmental management activities, plans for the development of local sporting facilities or to engage volunteers and events that celebrate a cultural or community milestone.

I encourage eligible organisations in Blueprint for the Bush communities to apply. Eligible organisations must be an incorporated not-for-profit organisation, a sponsored unincorporated not-for-profit organisation, a local government entity or a regional and remote area development organisation. This $2 million in funding is part of the Bligh government’s commitment to helping rural and regional communities become places where people want to live, work and raise families.

This is just one initiative aimed at regional economic development and rural job growth. Other regional development programs include the Queensland Regional Development Initiative, delivering $7.52 million in funding over four years for key projects and creating job opportunities; the Surat Basin future directions strategy, which is part of a $27.9 million initiative; the $100 million associated with the Sustainable Resource Communities Policy to fund social and economic infrastructure in key mining communities over a three-year period; and the establishment of 12 Regional Development Australia committees across Queensland.

We are firmly focused on delivering for the future economic growth of all of regional and rural Queensland. That is why I am minister for all of rural and regional Queensland and not just specific areas of Queensland. This is part of our plan to protect and create rural jobs and growth, and we are delivering. I encourage organisations to apply and become a part of this rural economic growth by going online to regions.qld.gov.au. Applications are open now.

Mrs MILLER (Bundamba--ALP) (10.26 am): I table the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Legislation Alert No. 13 of 2010 . In addition, I table submissions received from Mr Alastair MacAdam and the Queensland Law Society regarding, respectively, the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 and the Natural Resources and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010.

Tabled paper : Submission from Alastair MacAdam, senior lecturer in law, Queensland University of Technology and barrister of Supreme Court of Queensland regarding the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010.
Tabled paper : Submission from the Queensland Law Society regarding the Natural Resources and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.27 am): I give notice that I will move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House notes:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. the Minister for Community Services has stated that just to transport a young person under police escort to Brisbane from Wide Bay/Burnett costs approximately $8,000 and a minimum of $70,000 per year to keep them in detention;

2. Hard Yakka is a tough-love, military style training program conducted over 28 days that has a proven track record, changed young people’s attitudes for the better, kept them out of jail, saved lives and costs only $5,000 per person;

3. Hard Yakka is a joint venture between ex-SAS instructor Bob Davis and Wandiny RAPASS Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporation and is strongly supported by police, the local magistrate, community workers and parents of children at risk;
4. Hard Yakka needs government support and funding to continue its good work in our community by--
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms STRUTHERS: I rise to a point of order. The member has made some claims about amounts of money that I had allegedly said it costs to transport a youth from Bundaberg to Brisbane. That is incorrect. I do not know the amount it costs, but I will find out. I ask for that to be withdrawn.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! There is no point of order. The member is giving notice of a motion and the honourable minister will get a chance, I think, to debate that if it comes on.
Ms STRUTHERS: It contains an incorrect assertion.

Mr SPEAKER: The minister makes a point that I should not have dismissed so lightly. I say to the honourable member for Burnett that you should be in a position to authenticate the words in your notice of motion. I will say to the House again that with this whole series of notices of motion, which I do not get to see beforehand, it is a very hard process to adjudicate.
Mr Schwarten: An abuse of parliament. That’s what it is.
Mr SPEAKER: That is up to the House to determine. I call the honourable member for Burnett.
Mr MESSENGER: Will I continue with my notice?
Mr SPEAKER: Yes. I have asked for notices of motion and the honourable member has the call.
Mr MESSENGER: The motion continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 4. Hard Yakka needs government support and funding to continue its good work in our community by providing a credible last-chance alternative to detention for children at risk.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the Premier to ensure funding for at least one more Hard Yakka course, accompanied by a study documenting its effectiveness with a view to establishing a tough-love military style program for children at risk state-wide.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: I ask the honourable gentleman to provide me with the authentication of the facts. Otherwise I will rule the notice of motion out of order.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.30 am): I rise on a matter of privilege suddenly arising. In replying to the comment made by the Minister for Community Services, I can say here in this parliament with my hand on heart that both Bob Davis and I were witness when you told us personally that it cost approximately $8,000--
Ms Struthers: Mr Speaker--

Mr SPEAKER:
Resume your seat. The member has risen on a matter of privilege. I will hear the matter of privilege.
Mr MESSENGER: Mr Speaker, you have asked that I provide proof that the Minister for Community Services stated that it cost $8,000 to transport a child.

Mr SPEAKER:
All I am after is that you will need to authenticate that and that will be fine.
Mr MESSENGER: I will get that authentication from Bob Davis, who was witness to that conversation.
Mr SPEAKER: That is fine.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! Before I call question time, visitors to the House today are the Kelvin Grove State College in the electorate of Brisbane Central, the Blackwater State School in the electorate of Gregory, the Glenreagh Public School from New South Wales and the Elanora State School in the electorate of Currumbin. I would also like to acknowledge in the public gallery a former member of this House, Mr Stuart Copeland.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.31 am): My first question without notice is to the Minister for Child Safety. The minister’s Labor colleague the member for Cook has been tweeting. One of the member for Cook’s recent tweets says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Walking a day in the shoes of a Child Safety Officer in Weipa. Not a happy day so far. Some stories are horrific. Staff morale is very low.
XML.Hansard-Body: Why are the minister’s own Labor colleagues saying staff morale in his department is so low under this long-term Labor government?

Mr REEVES: I thank the honourable member for the question. As I have stated in this House previously on a number of occasions, and I have had representations from a range of MPs, I have had the pleasure of visiting every single child safety office in Queensland--every single one of them. I have met with the majority of staff both individually and as a group at every one of those offices.

These child safety officers have some of the most difficult jobs imaginable in the Public Service. These child safety officers have to deal with some of the most complex and difficult people that anyone could imagine. These child safety officers have to knock on a door not knowing what to expect on the other side of the door. These child safety officers have to deal with children and young people who have been abused and neglected. These child safety officers are some of the most professional people that I have ever come across in my life.

I want to thank the member for Cook for choosing to walk a day in the shoes of a child safety officer. The member for Cook spoke to me during that experience and he has spoken to me since to inform me of what he learnt from walking a day in their shoes. That is the whole intention of the ‘Walk a day in my shoes’ program. It is so that we can get that firsthand experience. I myself walked a day in the shoes of a teacher aide. I learnt heaps from that experience.
We will continue to work with child safety officers to give them the support they need. Since 2004 we have tripled the budget and doubled the staff in Child Safety Services.
Mr Wallace: They’ll cut it back like they’re doing in England.

Mr REEVES: That is right. Look at what is happening with their tory mates in the UK. They want to cut child safety officers; we want to give them jobs. The recent budget provided for an increase of 30; in the UK, there will be $7 billion in cuts to family and community services.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides of the House will come to order. Resume your seat. I will wait for the House to come to order. The honourable minister has the call.

Mr REEVES: For the information of the House, there will be $7 billion in cuts in the UK to family and community services--$7 billion. On this side of the House, we look after staff. We are interested in jobs, not cuts.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is to the Premier. When the Labor government announced that it would privatise Queensland Rail, the state’s debt was estimated at $44 billion. Can the Premier confirm that the state’s debt under the long-term Labor government will be more--more--at the end of the privatisation process than it was when Labor first announced the sales?

Ms BLIGH:
I thank the honourable member for the question. This question comes from a Leader of the Opposition who is completely bereft of an economic policy.
Mr Seeney: Answer the question rather than attack the questioner.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides of the House will come to order.
Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. It is little wonder that the Leader of the Opposition does not have an economic policy because his understanding of economics is minuscule.
Mr Seeney: You can’t answer the question, so you make a personal attack.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: I am very happy to take this question from the Leader of the Opposition because what it demonstrates, as I said, is that he has a minuscule understanding of the state budget and the state economy. Will we have debt associated with the borrowing to build infrastructure that we had in place at the beginning of the 2009-10? Of course we will. We outlined a borrowing program. We committed to the infrastructure. We signed the contract. We got the cranes on site. We employed thousands of people, and we are building the infrastructure. That means--
Mr Horan: Debt is going up faster than you can sell assets.
Ms BLIGH: What will we have at the end of our asset sales program? We will have less debt than we would have had without it.
A government member: And more assets.

Ms BLIGH: And more assets. What is the plan of those opposite to reduce debt? They do not have one. They do not have a debt reduction strategy. What we know is that on this side of the House we are determined to build Queensland. We have signed the contracts. We are building the infrastructure. Economists around Australia and around the world have endorsed our strategy.

We will use the assets sales revenue not only to pay down debt now; it will also avoid future debt because those borrowings will be through the private sector. You could not find someone more bereft of economic policy than the member for Surfers Paradise--not a schmick of an idea about how to build a $3 billion or $4 billion project. Under his proposal, he would stop it after he won. He would turn the cranes off. He would send everybody home. We will build Queensland. We will invest in jobs because we stand for jobs, not cuts. We know what those on the other side are up to.
Mrs KEECH: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier advise of some of the economic benefits to Queensland of the government’s continued investment in the motorsports on the Gold Coast?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for her question. I thank the member for Albert and the other local members on the Gold Coast for their terrific support of the Armor All Gold Coast 600. It was held last weekend. It is rightly being hailed as a massive success and has provided a much-needed boost to the local economy of the Gold Coast.

We know that tourism is doing it tough and it is doing it toughest in our biggest and best tourist markets like the Gold Coast. I want to congratulate a great Gold Coast based company, the V8 Supercars, for the work that they have done to make this a success. They have done a terrific job this weekend in their first outing. I think they deserve credit for that. I also want to congratulate and thank the Minister for Sport, Phil Reeves, for the work that he has done to make sure that this was a great event.

The event has this year injected tens of millions of dollars into the Queensland economy. Some 170,000 tickets were sold. The TV ratings are in. There were 551,000 viewers Australia-wide. The coverage topped its timeslot on Sunday. It beat the Four Nations Rugby League test match.

This is an example of the massive benefits that can accrue to a local regional economy when a government is prepared to invest in it--invest in the infrastructure needed for it; invest in the incentives to make it happen. We could not get a more stark contrast between what our government is doing for regional centres like the Gold Coast with our infrastructure program and our investments than what would happen if those opposite were in charge. We know they went to the last election with a proposal to cut the budget by three per cent every single year and to cut 12,000 jobs out of the economy every single year. We do not have to think about it any more as just an imagining because we only have to look across the ocean and see it in practice.
What are the tories doing in the UK? They are slashing and burning, cutting jobs--half a million jobs.
Mr Springborg: Old-fashioned British Labour.

Ms BLIGH: I note the member for Southern Downs endorsing his tory mates in the UK--getting right behind the $7 billion in cuts to families. He is backing the $2 billion in cuts to disability services. He is backing the reduction in funding to police. That is what those opposite love. They cannot get enough of it. When they see a cut in a budget setting they get wildly excited.

The last election was fought on the jobs, not cuts. We are providing jobs. They are backing cuts. Their mates across the ocean are showing how it is done. When the next election comes Queenslanders will have that example to measure them by.
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my right.
Honourable members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Both sides of the House will now come to order. I call the honourable member for Clayfield.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Treasurer. I refer to reports of the government’s decision to bring forward the sale of the Abbot Point coal terminal for the simple reason that the Queensland government just cannot get enough money from the sale of the Port of Brisbane. Does this not confirm once and for all that this is just another fire sale of assets because Labor cannot rein in its debt?
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Just wait, Treasurer. I will wait for the interjections to stop. I call the honourable Treasurer.

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer for his question about the importance of this government’s economic plan and the strength of this government’s economic plan that we have put in place. Yes, it is no secret to the Queensland people that we have decided to divest the Abbot Point coal terminal because we have decided not to continue to put public funds into a coal terminal that will require hundreds of millions of dollars in order to expand into the future to meet the needs of the growing resources sector in Queensland. We have decided not to do that. We have decided, as we said, to put it to the market by the end of this year. We have decided to say that we would have that transaction completed in the first half of next year. That we will.

None of this is a revelation. All of that is in the public arena. What this government will do is continue to pursue the plan that we said we would. Why? Because that plan is delivering. It stands in stark contrast to the plan that is being put forward by the shadow Treasurer and his tory mates on the other side.

Take a look on the other side of the world right now and we see what the tory plan would be. If those opposite want to continue to fund coal ports then they are going to take a hat to what the UK tories are doing. What does that mean? Billions of dollars of cuts to child benefits. Billions of dollars of cuts to working families. Billions of dollars of cuts to rate subsidies for people who need to pay for it. Billions of dollars of cuts out of education.

If we look across the water, what are they doing in the UK? Some $53 billion has been cut out of education. There is 21 per cent being taken out of transport, 27 per cent out of local government and 51 per cent out of housing.

What is the evidence in support of the plan that we have taken, the choice that we have made to invest in social services--to invest in the things that Queenslanders need? Do not take my word for it. How about we take what Professor Joseph Stiglitz, who, after all, has only won the Nobel Peace Prize for economics, said. What has he said about the tory plan in the UK? He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Cutbacks in investment, in education, technology and infrastructure will be even more costly in the future for they will spell lower growth, lower revenues, indeed higher unemployment itself, especially if persistent will result in the deterioration of skills, in effect in the destruction of human capital.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is the miserable prescriptions that the tories in Queensland have for the Queensland government. This is a government that stands for investing, for jobs, not cuts; for not the cruelty of the austerity measures that those opposite advocate. While they stand here and continue to promote their antiprivatisation agenda, all they consign Queensland to is a great big debt snort of another $15 billion in support of resource companies instead of support for families and working people and putting people in jobs just like this government said it would.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left!
Mr Lucas interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The honourable Deputy Premier! I call the member for Whitsunday.
Ms JARRATT: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier outline how our world-class exporters contribute to the Queensland economy and how the government supports their innovation?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for her question. Our government is very clear about the importance of exporting to the Queensland economy. We are a small domestic market. We will only continue to see growth, prosperity and wellbeing if we keep our eyes firmly focused on the rest of the world. We need to see our market as the global market. Increasingly, we are seeing more and more Queensland companies do just that--turn their eyes to the global market. When they do, the Queensland government is right there to back them.

We believe simply that export equals innovation, equals jobs. Our export agenda is critical to our jobs agenda. Trade and Investment Queensland in its assisted businesses this year secured nearly $614 million in export contracts. That was up 17 per cent on the previous year. So in 2009-10--one of the toughest years economically that the globe has experienced for some time--it was up 17 per cent. Trade and Investment Queensland helped $923 million worth of foreign investment into Queensland in addition to the export.

Last week was Export Week. Mr Speaker, I was pleased to join with many of our exporters for both our regional export awards in Townsville and Cairns and then here with you and many others for the Premier’s export awards and to recognise those great exporters of Queensland--the new and emerging companies as well as those that have had great achievements over a period of time. It was great to see Queensland’s new export award going to Becker Helicopters on the Sunshine Coast. It won the Dermot McManus Award for their export of pilot training DVDs and manuals around the world.

Of course we know that under Labor we will get investment in business, in innovation, in skills and in programs to grow business. Last year we saw the LNP go to the election promising to cut the Queensland Investment Incentive Scheme--the scheme that brings businesses to Queensland. It had an awfully familiar ring about it. What is it doing? What is David Cameron doing?
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Stop the clock. I cannot hear. Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I had asked you to cease interjecting.

Ms BLIGH: It has got an awfully familiar ring about it, because what are the British tories doing? Cutting business, innovation and skills programs by a whopping 28.5 per cent. So it is not just the public sector jobs that will go but it will be all of those companies that rely on those sorts of programs to get going. The slash and burn that is happening in the UK prompted that well-known economist Joseph Stiglitz to make the point that this sort of austerity in hard times turns downturns into recessions and recessions into depressions. Under Labor you will get investment in jobs and investment in infrastructure. The LNP equals cuts!
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides of the House will come to order. Honourable member for Hinchinbrook, you have had more than enough today. If I hear you again, I will warn you under the standing orders.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Minister for Natural Resources. Will the minister confirm that in the latest chapter of Labor waste approximately $200,000 worth of fridge magnets publicising the SEQ Water Strategy are now sitting gathering dust in a warehouse?

Mr ROBERTSON: From time to time all agencies, including the Queensland Water Commission, engage in public relations and education campaigns to advise the community on important matters. It is obviously a matter for those agencies to determine what the best approach is. I am informed that in fact magnets were produced by the Queensland Water Commission but for a variety of reasons it has decided not to proceed with the distribution of them at this--
Mr Seeney: You instructed them.
Mr Springborg: Political embarrassment.
Mr Seeney: You instructed them, didn’t you?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Callide! The minister has the call.
Mr ROBERTSON: It has chosen--
Mr Seeney: Notice the minister didn’t deny it!
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Callide!
