Mr ROBERTSON: It has decided not to proceed with the distribution of those magnets. I will take the interjection from the member for Callide, because one of the things that I have always been keen to do during the time that I have been a minister in this government now for over some 10 years is to ensure that taxpayers of Queensland get value for money. If I see what I consider to be savings for taxpayers in terms of how agencies go about their business, then I will make my views known in that respect to ensure, as I said, that taxpayers do get value for money. However, in the time that is available to me in reflecting on the fact that last week was Export Week, a week where we do in fact shine a spotlight on those Queensland companies that are--
Mr Seeney: You can export some fridge magnets! And if you can find an export market, well done!
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr Seeney: You might win an export award!
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Callide, I have warned you three times--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Callide, I have warned you three times. I now warn you under 253(1). Next time you are gone.

Mr ROBERTSON: During last week I was somewhat bemused by one of the headlines in the Courier-Mail on the issue of disclosed expenses for overseas trade missions. In taking on board the very useful suggestion by the opposition alerting the Courier-Mail to this, I thought I would just have a look at opposition reports and I just happen to have this one by a Mr Tim Nicholls MP from 25 April to 9 May 2010. Does it disclose the costs of that trip in accordance with what the opposition demands of government? No, it does not, and I table that report.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Report by Mr Nicholls MP on overseas travel to attend BIO international convention and related pre BIO activities.
XML.Hansard-Body: As usual, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition gets caught out in terms of not doing his homework and accuses us of doing the very same thing that his colleague--

Ms JOHNSTONE: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Can the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health advise the House what has been the impact on health services when governments have decided to cut budgets and cut jobs instead of investing in infrastructure, services and job creation?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. In fact, it sits very presciently with the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition earlier. We of course have a $7.33 billion health infrastructure program, and as you build the particular aspects of it you draw down the money for it. You actually do not borrow the money to build the hospitals and sit it in the bank until such time as you build them. You draw it down, and of course that debt will go on until that point in time, but an asset is being added to it as part of that. The Sunshine Coast University Hospital will secure 2,500 construction jobs and 3,500 health jobs when it opens and thousands more when nearby commercial facilities open. We of course know that those opposite will not commit to building it. We took the tough decisions because we believe in jobs, not cuts. Indeed, what did CommSec say yesterday through Craig James on ABC Radio? He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Some of the other states jealously guard their AAA rating, but Queensland is saying ‘we want infrastructure first and anything else second’ and I think that longer-term perspective by the Queensland Government is going to hold the ... economy in very good stead ...
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I table that.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Email, dated 25 October 2010, from Kimberley Gardiner containing transcript of 612 ABC news item on State of States report.
XML.Hansard-Body: In the state budget after just 15 months we are already three-quarters of the way towards meeting a commitment of 3,500 extra clinical staff. Since 2005 we have employed more than 14,000 extra doctors, nurses and allied health professionals. This year we will have 556 interns and next year 644. In 2005 it was 250. What are they doing on the other side of the House? They are endorsing regimes throughout the world that actually result in fewer health workers being employed. California in September alone cut 37,300 workers, including 13,600 in health and education alone. In this year’s budget Governor Schwarzenegger cut $1.3 billion in funding for Medi-Cal, California’s free health program for the poor, and the California Medical Association labelled that move ill advised and fiscally reckless, saying that life without access to health care can be terrifying.

In Ireland there have been Public Service pay cuts of between five per cent and 15 per cent in one year. In the UK, $20 billion will be cut from the NHS budget by 2014--double the entire Queensland Health budget this year. There will be a 19 per cent cut to front-line services and it will cut 140 doctor training positions. We have 556 in Queensland alone. It is going to cut 140 out of the UK. Of course, we saw Abbott and Howard cut $1 billion from the Health budget. It is a very clear prescription: you can be committed to an infrastructure building program that will stand Queensland in good stead for the future that is acknowledged by others to do that, or you can take the short-term view. I would rather build hospitals than have coal trains that other people are going to use and build anyway. That is the secret.
Mr SEENEY: My question is to the Minister for Public Works. I refer the minister to the article he wrote for the Courier-Mail where he attacked loyal Labor Party member Peter Simpson.
Government members interjected.
Mr SEENEY: Mr Speaker, for the benefit of the minister, I will start again.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my right!

Mr SEENEY: I refer the Minister for Public Works to the article that he wrote for the Courier-Mail where he attacked loyal Labor Party member Peter Simpson--a member who has never once dined at the five-star Aria restaurant and is now facing expulsion for standing up for his working-class colleagues. I ask the minister: does the minister believe that it is part of his ministerial duties to pen vicious personal attacks against working-class people who stand up to the government’s privatisation agenda?
Mr SCHWARTEN: Thank you, Mr Speaker. I have been waiting for this one. Come in, mug.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides of the House. I am desperately anxious to hear the reply from the minister.

Mr SCHWARTEN: And I am desperately anxious to give it. Of all the hypocrisy I have ever heard to come from that man! It is just unbelievable. Let me talk about this portfolio and what it does. It is building Queensland. It is building it using the hands and minds of workers who are members of the Electrical Trades Union, who are members of the CFMEU and who are members of the BLF. There are 106,000 of them out there.

What I pointed out to Mr Simpson--and I am happy to point it out in here--is that he is doing nothing to help those members. He sold them out on the job in Queensland. At every single job that I have been on I have had ETU members, BLF members and CFMEU members there and I have repeated the message that we are borrowing money to keep them in jobs. There is no three-year guarantee for them like there is for railway workers. I am not surprised to hear the member defend the rort that is Queensland Rail. The reality is this--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Mr Speaker, can I continue?
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Mr SCHWARTEN: The Nicklin government enticed the coal industry here with three public subsidies. First of all--the greatest of them all, the greatest rort and the greatest thing done to working people in this state--was to use public housing funds to subsidise houses for wealthy coalminers. That was the first one. I privatised that and I am delighted I did. I privatised every one of those houses in coal communities in Queensland, because it was not good enough--
Mr Horan interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Toowoomba South.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I want to get this messages across. That is No. 1. That is what Joh did. He took money off the poor and put it into the coal companies by way of housing. The second point is the low royalties that everybody in the Labor Party complained about for years--everybody before Simpson was even born. Without their saying that the coal companies were rorting the royalties in this state--and that is what Nicklin did and that is what Bjelke-Petersen did; they continued to subsidise those companies by not giving Queenslanders their fair share--
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: There is too much interjection from those on my left. I could understand it if the minister was personally attacking you. At the moment he is giving an explanation in relation to the question that was asked. The minister has the call.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Mr Speaker, he was taking from the poorest people in those circumstances by ensuring that we funded education last, that we funded disability services nonexistently, by giving those cheap royalties to multinational companies. What was the third one? The third one was that he allowed the coal companies to do what no other government has done and that is borrow--
Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (11.03 am): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the minister be granted an extension of time so he can be further heard.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SCHWARTEN: Good.
Mr SPEAKER: Leader of the House, do you want to place a time on that?
Ms SPENCE: No.
Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
Mr Springborg: Give him another shovel. He’s worn out the other one.
Mr Seeney: Keep digging, Robbie.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I know they do not want to hear how for generations the people of Queensland have been robbed because of their government and its decisions to underfund the basic services in this state. It has taken us 20 years in government to try to turn that around, because they did everything they could to kowtow to multinational companies in this state at the expense of the poor in this state. All the teachers in Queensland, the lowest paid in Australia; police officers, the lowest paid in Australia; nurses, doctors, the public health system--run through the floor, all because they would rather subsidise the multinational coal companies in this state.

Let us have a look at the deal on the table at the moment. The prospectus of the QR float says that there is a facility for $3 billion already there to borrow. That is $3 billion that is on the public account otherwise--
Ms Bligh: That is for the next two years.

Mr SCHWARTEN: In just two years, yet we see every single day people who sit opposite say that we should be borrowing more for infrastructure--roads, bridges and all the rest of it. I agree with all of that, but I do not agree with borrowing on the public account to--
Mr Horan: The poor old railways workshops. They’re all gone.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I have said this to them, too, and most of them get the message, I tell you. Decent people in the Labor Party certainly do, because decent people in the Labor Party know you for the scum you are. They know you for the rorters that you are.
Mr Elmes interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr SCHWARTEN: They are scum, Mr Speaker.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The language is unparliamentary. You will withdraw it and when you withdraw it, I want--
Mr SCHWARTEN: I will withdraw it.
Mr SPEAKER: Member for Noosa, you are interjecting far too much. I warn you under standing order 253(1).

Mr SCHWARTEN: The bottom line is this: we have decided as a government that we will invest in the future of education, because what is it that keeps this state going? It is people who get jobs. We privatised the forestry, which they opposed--$603 million that was returning three million bucks. What was the announcement in Rockhampton last week? It was that the new firm was investing in that business, planting thousands more trees. Guess what? They are going to build a new sawmill. Are they putting it on the public account? No, they are not. But there will be more workers there who will be working under award conditions as members of the Australian Workers Union who will have all of their conditions that you people want to take away. The final point--
Mr Springborg: What about Simmo?

Mr SCHWARTEN: Yes, I am happy to get to Mr Simpson, because people like Mr Simpson were not around during the SEQEB dispute, when 1,200 ETU workers and every member of our family put 10 per cent of their pay--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Mr Speaker, I would like to make this point.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr SCHWARTEN: I was around--Simpson was not--in 1980--
Mr Robertson: 1985.

Mr SCHWARTEN: He was not around in 1980, either, in the street-marching stuff. In 1985 he was nowhere to be seen in the SEQEB dispute. I was down here in a number of these rallies and I saw what happened as the police were put on the backs of workers at the instruction of Bjelke-Petersen. I stood in this parliament and voted to restore the conditions of the employees who had been robbed by your side of parliament. In 1975 my father worked for the works department when overnight it was privatised. All of the new school buildings were privatised. They were given out to private enterprise. Guess what happened? He left that job with eight hours pay in his pocket--no relocation expenses, no superannuation. What have the railway workers got? A 14 per cent wage increase that 92 per cent of them supported. The people I know in the railways have got that in their pockets. They have a 14 per cent wage increase, guaranteed superannuation, a guaranteed job and are going into an industry that pays well beyond what every other industry in Rockhampton pays.

I go on to building sites and I talk to families. I see blokes who do not know where their next job is coming from. They are members of the ETU, and Peter Simpson has never been near them. You have never once heard him say anything about the plight of ETU workers who are struggling to know where their next job is going to come from. He is too busy worrying about 300 or so workers who are guaranteed a job in Queensland Rail. That is what I object to. That is why I wrote the letter to the editor, because there is nothing Labor whatsoever about sponging on the taxpayers’ account by multinationals. I do not support that. No decent person would. And if anybody on that side had any conscience whatsoever, they would reveal to Queenslanders what exactly they intend to do. Are they going to go down the path of what the other economies are doing and slash jobs? Are they going to do that? Are they going to cut the capital works, like the tories did in 1929? Is that what they are going to do, and have 23 and 24 per cent unemployment in this state?
Mr Dickson interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: You do not like to hear the story. You do not like to hear the truth, but that is the reality of it. You stand condemned--
Mr SPEAKER: The honourable the minister will direct his comments through the chair.

Mr SCHWARTEN: The honourable member stands condemned not only for his ignorance but for the fact that he is selling out the people on the Sunshine Coast who we are trying to borrow money for to build a hospital.

Mr SEENEY: I rise to a point of order. I call your attention to the comment that the minister made that QR was a rort. I move that the minister’s statement be incorporated in the prospectus for the QR float.
Mr SPEAKER: It is out of order to have a motion moved in the middle of question time that would interfere with the sessional orders. So there is no point of order.
Mr WATT: My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of any recent support for the government’s economic plan?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Everton for his question and for his commitment, along with the other 50 members of this government, to the government’s economic plan which stands for delivering jobs and not the cuts that the other side stands for. Over the last couple of days we have seen a lot of commentary about the state of the Queensland economy and I want to put it on the record for the benefit of the House. We saw that Craig James from CommSec said yesterday that Queensland is saying that we want infrastructure first and anything else second. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... and I think that longer-term perspective by the Queensland Government is going to hold the Queensland economy in very good stead.
XML.Hansard-Body: I could not agree more with Mr James. Even the Courier-Mail yesterday reported that Mr James from CommSec said that Queensland had been a victim of circumstance, not mismanagement. I look forward to the LNP continuing trying to misquote Mr James and his comments on the Queensland economy. Last week the shadow Treasurer admitted he had a little problem with numeracy, but after his comments trying to put words in the mouth of Mr James yesterday it is clear that he is also illiterate because that same report said that our economic growth was the second strongest in the nation--up 18 per cent on the decade average. While ever the shadow Treasurer and those around him continue to advance the fraud that they do not support privatisation, we know that they do support something else. In the absence of them coming clean and finally admitting--as they have so many times before on the record--that they support privatisation, we know what the alternative is because it is being played out around the world at the moment.

What is the alternative? Well, in the UK right now the shadow Chancellor, the shadow Treasurer, just put in place a plan for cutting 500,000 jobs out of the British public sector. That is what those opposite will be aspiring to at the next election. They went to the last election with a plan to cut 12,000 jobs. They will be looking across the ocean with stars in their eyes. Because we know right around the world that a tory is a tory. A tory here is a Tory in the UK. What do they stand for here? Like they stand for in the UK, they stand for cuts. What do we stand for? We stand for jobs. One hundred thousand jobs are being supported in the Queensland economy because of the courage of this government to take the high road and to put in place the program. How many people have lost a job because of privatisation? Zero. How many people have got a job in Queensland because of the courage of all 51 members of this government? One hundred thousand people because of the building program.

I am proud to stand with 50 other people who have the courage of their convictions, unlike those vacuous and callous people opposite who would condemn this state and the working people in it to the austerity measures that the UK tories are putting in place. I encourage all Queenslanders to look across the shore to see the horror of what these tories really stand for.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Sale of Public Assets; Racing Queensland
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr STEVENS: My question is to the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading. I refer to secret Labor government plans to dispose of the famed Albion Park racecourse by this cash-strapped long-term Labor government. Will the minister confirm that this is yet another fire sale simply because Labor cannot rein in its debt? Does he still give 100 per cent support to the chairman of Racing Queensland?
Mr Lucas interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The Deputy Premier will cease interjecting.

Mr LAWLOR: There has been quite a bit of speculation recently about the future of Queensland racing. Let me assure the House that racing in Queensland is in safe hands. The government, as those opposite well know, has committed $80 million to Racing Queensland to develop infrastructure. Racing Queensland has gone through the various pieces of infrastructure around the state and put a submission to the government which is being considered. The first thing you have to remember is that Albion Park is owned by Racing Queensland, as are other places such as the Gold Coast Turf Club.
Government members interjected.
Mr LAWLOR: Why are you saying that the government should interfere with what Racing Queensland--
Mr SPEAKER: Direct your comments through the chair and that will help the order of the House.
Mr Stevens: He’s the Sergeant Schultz of racing. Looks like him, too.
Mr LAWLOR: You should be in a home for the bewildered, you really should.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Mr LAWLOR:
last week I was overseas in London and China promoting tourism. When I came back the various comments made by the opposition and the Mayor of Brisbane about the future of Albion Park were brought to my attention. So I had a little look at what the town plan provides for Albion Park. Let me read a bit from the Brisbane City Council Albion Neighbourhood Plan--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Raceway Precinct will provide for medium density development and increased business activity.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The member for Clayfield would know all about this. It goes on--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The intent is to encourage redevelopment of the Albion Park raceway facility. The preferred option is for the relocation of the facility to allow redevelopment more appropriate to an inner city location.
XML.Hansard-Body: Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Resume your seat. I will wait for the House to come to order.

Mr LAWLOR: The interesting thing, of course, is that if one looks at the UK, they are going to cut sport and culture by 24 per cent. I suppose that is part of the platform of those opposite, too, now. We have committed to in excess of $80 million over the next four years. We are assessing the most recent submission put by Racing Queensland to the government.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr KILBURN: My question without notice is to the Attorney-General. Could the Attorney-General provide the House with details of any significant milestones in relation to the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions?

Mr DICK: I thank the honourable member for his question and for his unwavering support for an independent Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions in Queensland, which he has spoken at length about in this House. Last week was a significant milestone for the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions as we celebrated its 25th anniversary. I was very pleased to attend the function that was held to commemorate that event with not only the Director of Public Prosecutions, Tony Moynihan SC, but also all three former directors: Des Sturgess QC, Royce Miller QC and Judge Leanne Clare SC. It allowed me to celebrate the work of 384 staff members in that office who work throughout Queensland. Fifty per cent work out in regional Queensland and more than half of the staff are women.

We need courageous, fearless and, most importantly, independent prosecutors in this state. It is only Labor that stands up for an independent Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions. Last year, in 2009-10, that office conducted 950 committals, 850 trials, more than 4,300 sentences, 250 bail hearings and 466 appeals. In the past five years this Labor government has increased funding to that office by a third. We will continue to support an independent office, and it is only Labor that supports the independence of the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions.

The number 25 is an important number. It is an important number for the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions and an important number for conservatives because that is the size of the cut that is being delivered to the justice system in the United Kingdom--a 25 per cent cut to the UK Home Office. What does that mean? Up to 18,000 police officers will be cut, up to 3,000 prison places will be cut and, most damnably of all, £350 million will be cut from legal aid. It is not a cut; it is a massacre to public finances never seen before in living memory.

No wonder the Leader of the Opposition will not talk about his economic plan. If members opposite do not support assets sales, if they do not support increasing revenue by raising taxes, there is only one way to get the budget into surplus, which is what the Leader of the Opposition said he wants to do, and that is to cut, to cut and to cut again. You cannot keep the community safe if you cut public defenders, public prosecutors, police and prison services.

I challenge the Leader of the Opposition today to go out of this House and to speak to the media and say that he will not cut. I challenge him to do that today. These cuts in the UK have been described as ‘brutal, ideological and cripplingly unfair austerity’. That is the only option they have. That is their dirty little plan. That is the secret plan of the opposition. I call on the Leader of the Opposition today to rule it out once and for all.

Mr EMERSON: I refer the Premier to the weekend by-election in the Walter Taylor ward where Labor came a distant third, with just 16 per cent. Will the Premier now give a guarantee that she will not, in any way, try to rig or cheat Labor’s way to the next state election by changing the electoral laws for voting?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. I am pleased to have an opportunity to talk about the weekend by-election result in the Brisbane City Council ward of Walter Taylor because I think it has some very interesting outcomes for all political parties. It was an interesting outcome for Labor, although I do note that the Walter Taylor ward is what would be known on any measure as an absolutely blue ribbon Liberal Party seat; it has never been held by the Labor Party.

I was a bit concerned that there was such a low voter turnout at just over 60 per cent. That is probably partly because it was a by-election, but that is something that we should all be a bit worried about. We do want to see a high voter turnout at any election at any level of government.

The much more interesting outcome of the Brisbane City Council by-election on Saturday was the swing against the Liberal National Party in that ward. The preliminary results show a primary swing against the LNP of over six per cent and a likely two party preferred swing against the LNP of close to nine per cent. It was a pretty interesting outcome in a ward that has never been held by Labor. If I was the member for Indooroopilly, I would be having a long, hard look at a number of the booths and I would not have Campbell Newman out campaigning for me on polling day.
An opposition member: They won’t have you!
Ms BLIGH: We will not be campaigning in Walter Taylor; we will not be campaigning in a ward.

The decisions about the electoral system in Queensland will be a matter for this parliament. I have answered this question in the past. I have not taken any further action on it. I answered it in full in the last sitting of parliament.
Ms MALE: My question without notice is to the Minister for Education and Training. Could the minister please outline what support the Bligh government is providing for teacher aides in Queensland?

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. Teacher aides are a vital part of the total complement of teaching staff in our state schools. They make such an enormous difference to the opportunities of kids in state schools; they give them a flying start into learning and life.

Only last weekend I had the pleasure of opening the Lighting the Way conference of teacher aides from across Queensland. About 350 teacher aides attended, undergoing professional development, networking and talking about how they can help kids in school. They, too, want to give kids a flying start in our schools. They are really the quiet achievers, as I discovered when I experienced my ‘Walk a day in my shoes’ day last Tuesday at Samford State School. What these teacher aides do is just beyond the imagination. They support in such a range of ways. I commend them and congratulate them all the way through.

There are 14,000 teacher aides in Queensland. We stand behind the important work that they do. Their work flies beneath the radar in some ways and is not recognised like it ought to be. We need to keep recognising it and raising their profile.

We support teacher aides and teaching staff. The Liberals and the National Party do not. They stand for cuts. If there is one thing that is in the DNA of the Liberals and Nationals and the tories, complicated as it might be, it is cuts. Whatever it is, cut it. Cut jobs, cut whatever. In England, 490,000 public servants will have their jobs cut and £7 billion will be cut from the welfare budget. What did the Liberal National Party say at the last state election--our home grown version of tories? It said that 36,000 public servants would be cut from the Queensland Public Service over three years. That translates to 420 teacher aides every year over three years or 990 teachers every year over three years. However, we support increasing those teacher and teacher aide numbers and we have dramatically done so in the past. But wait, there is a policy change. A press conference was held by the Leader of the Opposition in which he said only last weekend that he wants smaller class sizes. How can he have smaller class sizes by cutting teacher aides and cutting teachers? The two do not add up, but I have an answer as to why he may have said that. He consulted his Treasury spokesman, whom we know really understands mathematics, and he has given the advice that it does add up.
We stand for strong education and the retention of teacher aides. The opposition stands for cuts, cuts and cuts.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: My question without notice is to the Premier. With the announcement of federal government approval of two LNG projects for Gladstone, will the Premier give an undertaking to residents in my electorate that this government will fund necessary infrastructure including expanded hospital and health services, affordable housing, roads, social services and education and not abrogate its responsibility for funding this growth?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. As she well knows, these two projects offer an extraordinary opportunity, not only in the south-west of our state but, importantly, in Gladstone and I believe to the entire Central Queensland area. Along with that growth will come demand for increased infrastructure. I am very pleased that the Coordinator-General’s conditions on these companies include for the first time in many years a requirement on the companies themselves to invest and construct a number of houses in both Gladstone and in the south-west. I think that is important because it will go quite a long way to relieving housing cost pressures. I do not want to see ordinary families who have lived in Gladstone for a long time finding it hard to buy or to rent because of that pressure. That is a very important step by the Coordinator-General.

The member is right; it will also lead to demand with increased population for increased services in areas like education, health and police. I am very happy to put on record an assurance that this government will continue to fund, firstly, schools along the formula that applies everywhere else in Queensland. When we have new enrolments, new classrooms and the teachers and other staff needed will follow. I understand from the Deputy Premier that Queensland Health is currently doing a services plan for the Gladstone Hospital and health service area and that he has met personally with the member for Gladstone. The purpose of that plan is to make sure that we are one step ahead of the growth and demand that we expect to come out of these projects. Similarly, in areas such as policing and roads, ministers are working on the implications for not only Gladstone and Central Queensland, but also for the south-west of the state.

As I have said in a number of forums, particularly in South-West Queensland there are communities that, literally for decades, have been experiencing population decline. Whenever I have visited those communities I have talked to local residents, mayors and others about the problems of decline, such as how to keep teachers at the schools and how to keep hospital services going. There is some spare capacity in those towns to absorb some of this, but there will need to be growth.

However, over the last few decades Gladstone has been a growing community and we will have to continue to make sure that we match that growth. I look forward to working with the council in Gladstone, the local member and other relevant stakeholders to make sure that we are a step ahead of that growth. It will be a challenge, but it is a great challenge to have. This is prosperity the likes of which has not been seen in Queensland for a long time in terms of a brand-new industry and we welcome it.
Mr CHOI: My question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works. Can the minister inform the House about the employment of apprentices by QBuild.
Mr SPEAKER: Minister, you have one minute.
Mr SCHWARTEN: It is that time of year when we advertise for--
An opposition member interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I know you are crooked on apprentices and QBuild, but other people might be interested in listening to this. This is the time of year when we release annually 100 apprenticeships through QBuild, the same QBuild that those opposite would privatise. Since we have been in government, 1,339 people have gained trades. That has happened because this government has been in power and QBuild has not been privatised, which is what the previous government intended to do. I want to know whether it will be reassessed. I have here a document. I found out that the honourable member who sits opposite cannot even be original. He has borrowed a phrase from Chancellor George Osborne, who said there would be ‘fundamental reassessment’. It sounds like he would have said it. That is the way they are: there is not an original thought in their minds; they borrow terminology from the Brits and the tories.

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.30 am): Today it has emerged that this long-term Labor government is good at only one thing: creating debt. The astonishing thing is that Labor is creating debt faster than it can sell assets. It does not matter how fast the ‘for sale’ signs go up, Labor’s debt total goes up faster. Labor is no longer running a government; it is running a great big debt generator. On 22 November QR National will be listed on the Stock Exchange, delivering a maximum of $5 billion to this desperate Labor government that is drowning in debt. The LNP has opposed that sale from day one.

On 2 June 2009 the budget that contemplated the sale of QR National was brought into this House. From the day the legislation was brought into this House and rushed through by a Labor government that deceived the people of Queensland by saying that it had no plans to sell assets but as soon as it got re-elected started planning a fire sale, the fire sale of Queensland assets has been consistently opposed by the LNP. The LNP continues to oppose the rushed sale of assets, including the sale of QR National, which has been imposed on Queenslanders.

Let us not forget why Labor has mistakenly gone down the path of privatising assets such as QR National. Let us not forget that Labor sent Queensland bust in a boom. Queensland was the only state to have its credit rating downgraded during the global financial crisis. Queensland did not lose its AAA credit rating because of a downturn in the resources sector. If it did, Western Australia would have lost its as well. Queensland lost its AAA credit rating simply because of the economic irresponsibility of this toxic, long-term Labor government. Now every man, woman and child in Queensland will be carrying government debt of almost $20,000 each, and this Labor government is trying to tell them that it has no choice but to sell an asset that Queenslanders already own.

Asset sales are not the solution to the debt crisis of Labor’s making. For years the Queensland budget has been in structural deficit. The solution to a structural deficit is not a fire sale of assets but involves living within your means by controlling the growth in government expenditure. The waste and unsustainable spending by this state Labor government would make Gough Whitlam blush.

Today, there are two very disturbing facts that I want to remind the House of. The first is that in the 18 months between when Labor first announced the sale of QR National and the date it gets its hot, wasteful little hands on the proceeds more debt has been accumulated than the government expects to receive from the sale. Labor members should listen carefully to this: there will be more debt after the sale of QR National than there was when it was first announced. More than $10 billion of additional debt has been accumulated since the announcement of the privatisation of QR National. That is twice the current anticipated proceeds of the sale of QR National. The second disturbing fact is that in the time between when Labor first announced the sale of assets and when it completes its entire privatisation agenda, including the sales of the Port of Brisbane, Abbot Point and Queensland Motorways, more debt will have been accumulated than the expected sale proceeds of the entire privatisation agenda of around $15 billion.

I will repeat those disturbing facts for the benefit of the House, because they are indeed startling. There will be more debt after the sale of QR National than there was when it was first announced and, worse, there will be more debt after the sale of all the assets than there was when they were first announced. Even when we compare the sale proceeds of QR National to the interest on Labor’s debt, it is but a drop in the ocean. The expected sale proceeds of $4 billion to $5 billion from QR National would not even pay the interest bill for the next 18 months.

The LNP believes that growing our economy and stopping the waste are the best ways to start paying off the generational debt that Labor has left all Queenslanders and future Queenslanders. This state has had nearly two decades of Labor’s irresponsible spending. My government will balance the books, my government will repay the debt and my government will get the AAA credit rating back, because that is the economically responsible thing to do.

A stagnant or declining population will undoubtedly lead to higher unemployment. Recently the Bureau of Statistics revealed that last year Queensland had the lowest interstate migration level since 1984. That is incredibly bad news. It is incredibly bad news for Queensland business. Ever-rising state charges for water, electricity and rego are making it increasingly difficult for businesses and ordinary families. No longer do southerners flock to Queensland as a state of opportunity. Instead, they see a poorly managed state burdened by debt, a state burdened by deficit and a state burdened by a toxic, long-term Labor government. We will ensure that we get our state from the bottom of the ladder in terms of economic performance, service delivery, education standards and cultural facilities back to where we should be: right at the top.

This toxic, long-term Labor government is out of puff and is limping its way to the next election. The comparison between Western Australia and Queensland could not be more clear. Both are resource-rich states. WA is absolutely booming under a conservative probusiness government while Queensland is struggling under a tired, old Labor government that impedes business at every turn.

If we are elected, we will re-energise Queensland. We will do what good governments do best: facilitate and encourage business. Our No. 1 task will be to let business get on with business, to grow and create jobs and to create the wealth that generates the taxes to provide the services Queenslanders need. An LNP government will rebuild Queensland’s economy through a partnership with business.

There will be a lot to fix after such a long-term Labor government. However, that has happened elsewhere in the country, with Jeff Kennett in Victoria and Premier Colin Barnett in WA. I am confident that an LNP government will turn around this state’s fortunes and create an environment in which we can all prosper and, importantly, once again we can be proud that Queensland regains its rightful place as the best place to work, live and do business. Under an LNP government, Queensland has a much brighter future.

Ms GRACE (Brisbane Central--ALP) (11.39 am): The Bligh government is urging employees, employers and the community to work together to cut the incidence of death and injury in the workplace. The plea has been made as part of Safe Work Australia Week, which runs this week from 24 to 30 October. Safe Work Australia Week is of vital importance in spreading the message throughout the entire community that workplace safety is for everyone. We all have a role to play in cutting injury and death from the workplace. Ensuring that Queensland workers come home safe and healthy is a goal worth striving for. It does not matter what industry we work in. As Queenslanders, we want to return home safe each day to our families and loved ones.

Promoting workplace health and safety has been a lifelong mission for me and it is vital to cutting the Queensland workplace injury and fatality toll. There was a slogan in the union movement, and we have lived by it for many years, in relation to occupational health and safety--that is, that workers sell their labour, not their health. The human dimension is that each year in Queensland there are about 100 work related fatalities and nearly 30,000 cases where workers are either permanently impaired or seriously injured. On the economic side, the cost of these workplace incidents to the Queensland economy has been estimated at more than $5.2 billion each year. The Queensland government wants to turn these shocking statistics around to ensure that people make it home safe and sound to their loved ones at the end of each working day.

The government is working with employers and workers to build a positive zero harm safety culture in all Queensland workplaces to reduce the number and severity of workplace incidents. Ensuring our businesses are as safe and productive as possible will also secure Queensland jobs and keep the economy strong.

Safe Work Australia Week is for all Queenslanders--whether you are a small, medium or large business; an office worker or labourer; an apprentice or manager; from the country or the city; or work in an office or outdoors. This is the perfect opportunity for employers and workers to look carefully at their workplace health and safety practices and systems and how they can be improved. Workplace Health and Safety Queensland has many events planned during Safe Work Australia Week to raise awareness of the importance of a safe and healthy workplace, as I said, for all Queenslanders.

It was great to have Simon Finn, parliamentary secretary to the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, launch the Safe Work Australia Week at a forum held at the Victoria Park Golf Complex in my electorate of Brisbane Central. The forum keynote address was delivered by rugby league legend and Queensland State of Origin coach, Mr Mal Meninga. Mal has taken on the role as a safety ambassador for Safe Work Australia Week this month and will be helping to spread the safety message during the week.

The forum provided a comprehensive look at the new harmonised occupational health and safety laws to be introduced from 1 January 2010. Speakers from Safe Work Australia and Workplace Health and Safety were there to outline details of key aspects of the new legislation. John Crittall from Master Builders Queensland and Amanda Richards from the Queensland Council of Unions were also there to discuss the impact of the new laws from an employers’ and workers’ perspective. Also in attendance was the Workplace Health and Safety Board chair, Vince O’Rourke, and other board members. The new laws will mean that occupational health and safety rules will be applied consistently across Australia, making it easier for workplaces to understand and comply with requirements and this will improve both safety and productivity in industry.

On Thursday the 28th this week Mal Meninga, along with the Hon. Cameron Dick, the minister, will be at the King George Square Zero Harm at Work breakfast, which kicks off at 7 am, and I plan to be there. Celebrating this year’s theme ‘Zero Harm at Work, the event will include Nova 106.9 providing entertainment, games and giveaways. Safety ambassador Mal Meninga will address the crowd and discuss the importance of workplace health and safety and his personal perspectives as a coach, team player, business owner and family man. Industry groups supporting the Zero Harm at Work theme have agreed to be involved in the event providing giveaways or support with promotional materials, banners and a variety of interesting stands. Come along everyone and have the chance to win an autographed football from Mal.

Helping businesses to set up health and wellbeing programs is a priority for the Queensland government. There are a host of activities happening in hundreds of workplaces across the state from Toowoomba to Townsville to Rockhampton. In Rockhampton, we have the second annual Central Queensland Zero Harm Seminar.

Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (11.44 am): On 4 September this year I was very grateful that the Premier travelled to Toowoomba to open the $8 million National Carriage Factory at the Cobb and Co Museum in Toowoomba. This project received an investment of $4 million from the Queensland government. I was very keen to see this project come to fruition, as were notables in Toowoomba like Mary Wagner and the Premier’s former media adviser Steve Keating.

Why is this a very significant project? The Cobb and Co Museum will serve as Queensland’s first nationally accredited training facility for trades that are in danger of being lost--trades like blacksmithing, leadlighting and leather work. The Cobb and Co expansion is a key infrastructure development for the region, creating jobs. The Cobb and Co expansion created around 280 jobs in the first year of operation. It has also stimulated the local economy.

The development was also supported by the Board of the Queensland Museum, the Department of Education and Training, Q150 community legacy infrastructure and the local community. With respect to the local community, it contributed $2 million, which was a fantastic amount to be raised in a city like Toowoomba. The campaign to launch it was set up about four years ago under the leadership of Mary Wagner, and some really outstanding donations were from Mr and Mrs Clive Armitage and Mr Clive Berghofer.

The museum features a purpose-built, open plan factory for workshops with accredited heritage training programs in specialities such as heritage building, blacksmithing, silversmithing and equine trades catering for secondary school traineeships through to adult learners. This project builds on the great work carried out by Cobb and Co over many years, led very efficiently by its CEO, Deborah Tranter.

I also mention an event that occurred on 8 October this year when the Minister for Sport, Mr Reeves, attended Toowoomba. He announced a government grant of $2.24 million towards a total of $3.6 million for the construction of a tennis centre and clubhouse at the University of Queensland. The minister launched the project at the USQ amongst officials from the USQ, the city council, the Toowoomba Tennis Association and indeed Tennis Queensland.

The project will create nine International Tennis Federation standard courts and will construct a clubhouse. The three existing courts on site will be upgraded. So in total there will be 12 ITF standard courts. The project will be completed in early 2011. The facility will provide more opportunities for everyone to play tennis and for tennis events to be held. Other funding came from USQ, $600,000; the Toowoomba Regional Council, $300,000; Tennis Queensland, $362,582; Tennis Australia, $80,000; and the Toowoomba Tennis Association, $20,000.

The program creates much needed jobs and supports local suppliers of products and services. The Queensland government recognises the important role sport, such as tennis, plays and how it contributes to the local community. We are committed to providing sport and recreation facilities that help Queenslanders to get active and work with industry leaders to build capacity within the sport and recreation industry. This project contributes to the Toward Q2: Tomorrow’s Queensland initiative of helping Queenslanders become Australia’s healthiest people by reducing obesity levels by one-third by 2020.

The minister, whilst in Toowoomba, also announced a rescue package for the Toowoomba Sports Ground Trust. The trust has been conducting a review of its operations in light of its financial difficulties. The state government has delivered a $150,000 rescue package to ensure that the Toowoomba Sports Ground survives into the future. It is an iconic sporting facility for the Toowoomba community, and we certainly do not want to see it fail. I met with the minister on a number of occasions, and I was very pleased that he acceded to our request. The trust chairman, John McDonald, said, ‘The Queensland government has stepped in to save the sportsground at a time when we needed it most.’

Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (11.49 am): I today join with the Premier in welcoming the approval by the federal minister for environment, Tony Burke, of the two coal seam gas projects which will produce LNG for export from Gladstone. I reaffirm the support of the LNP for the proposals that are being pursued by the BG Group, Santos, Petronas and Total joint venture. The conditions applied by the federal minister together with the conditions already applied by the Queensland Coordinator-General will make this the most heavily regulated and closely monitored industry in Queensland’s history. That should ensure that the land and water assets of the area are appropriately protected.

The current state Labor government in Queensland has not dealt well with the development of the industry up until now. It has constantly lagged behind and has had to be pushed by the LNP opposition and a range of stakeholder groups.

There is no doubt that the state will benefit hugely from this new industry. It is up to the state government to ensure that all the resources are in place to properly cope with the development and protect the environment in the region. Some of the regional communities that have been declining for decades can anticipate an explosion of growth and economic development the likes of which they could only have dreamed about in the past. Already small businesses of all types from Gladstone to Toowoomba have been gearing up to be in a position to benefit from the development of the gas industry. Likewise, the state government needs to be gathering up its service delivery to ensure that people in south-west Queensland and Gladstone can cope with the coming development.

When I made my first speech in this parliament 12 years ago I said that the biggest export from regional Queensland was our kids. At that time there was only one choice for young people in the communities that I represented. That was to leave to get a job somewhere else. Over those years the coalmining industry has developed markedly. Now it will be joined by a whole new coal seam gas industry that will provide high-value jobs and career paths in central and south-western Queensland communities for generations of such young people.

The gas industry will bring new skills and a new work culture to an area of our state where the choices have been very limited. As a local member I welcome that. I will be focusing on ensuring that my constituents can access the opportunities that will come with the export gas industry. I will also be maintaining my strong focus on the issues that have already affected landholders throughout the region who are dealing with such things as exploration activities, gas production infrastructure or pipeline construction on their land.

The government has been slow to act on many of the regulatory issues involved. The CSG industry is different from traditional mining activities in that it involves a long-term co-existence between landholders and gas companies. My aim as a local member and shadow minister, and hopefully as a minister, is to achieve a situation where that long-term co-existence produces an outcome where every landholder who is involved in the CSG industry ends up better off than they would have otherwise been.

The land access laws and the compensation provisions currently require that landholders be made no worse off. But the future aim of all industry participants should be to ensure that landholders are better off. Likewise with the environmental issues, especially the water issue.

There has been a lot of concern expressed about the water issue, and understandably so. But I believe that the CSG developments, with proper management, can improve the water situation in the area by using the produced water to supplement existing irrigation schemes and to recharge aquifers that have been declining under current extraction levels for many years.

The state and federal conditions will set up the most extensive and rigorous water-monitoring system in Queensland’s history, and rightly so. But that water-monitoring system should ensure that any unplanned-for impacts are detected very quickly, and both sets of conditions deal extensively with the remediation requirements in any such situation. They should also deal with remediation and re-establishment of vegetation.

This development will overlay a whole new energy province on a closely settled existing agricultural area, some of which is unquestionably high-quality land. It will be a huge challenge to successfully achieve that in a way that ensures that the economic benefits of the export gas industry flow to the state and to the local communities and, at the same time, that the long-term sustainability of the land and water assets are protected and that individual property owners’ rights are not trampled.

The LNP as a whole and the local members who represent the area will continue to ensure that the complexities of that challenge are recognised and met in a proper way. We will continue to push the government on a whole range of issues on which the government has been slow to act. We will continue to ensure that the land and water assets are protected. We will continue to support the industry to produce the economic outcomes for the whole of Queensland that it has the potential to do.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP) (11.54 am): Young Queenslanders all over the state are enjoying learning in world-class facilities because of the Bligh government’s delivery of the federal government’s Building the Education Revolution program. The BER program is delivering 21st century facilities such as school halls and libraries that make parents and students happy to go to school. In my electorate more than $9.8 million is being spent on 12 projects across four schools.

Two independent reports by PricewaterhouseCoopers, in 2009 and 2010, have already found that Queensland projects achieved value for money. As well as value for money, Queensland’s BER rollout also achieved best practice design standards which were coordinated by the Department of Education and Training in a way that allowed schools to focus on their core business of teaching and learning. Most recently, a third report from the federal government’s BER task force confirmed that BER delivery in Queensland is a success. The federal government task force met with senior department officers, had access to all the files and documents regarding our BER program and at no stage raised any criticism. Further, all of the applicable recommendations in all three reports have been implemented or are in the process of being adopted.

A fourth report into the rollout of BER will be released tomorrow by the Queensland Auditor-General. I am confident that this report will confirm what the previous three already have. The Bligh government is committed to transparency and we look forward to the release of this latest report. I am confident that it will yet again show that Queensland got value for money and built facilities that students and teachers from the Gold Coast to the Far North enjoy using every day.

Queensland has had a different approach to Building the Education Revolution from the very beginning. It was our objective from the very start of this process to stretch every dollar as far as we could for every school. We recognised that we could not take a cookie-cutter approach with BER as every school was different and had individual needs. That is why we consulted widely with school communities and the P&Cs--to ensure we got the most bang for our buck. Their views have been carefully considered in each project and, combined with a flexible approach while still complying with BER program guidelines, schools have secured better quality outcomes.

Queensland state schools handled more than four times the number of projects as the Catholic sector, many of them in rural and remote areas. Considering the high number of state school projects, it is pleasing to note that there have been only 21 complaints out of the more than 4,500 infrastructure projects--that is less than half of one per cent--and the federal task force singled out the Queensland state school sector for praise.

As well as building better schools for our children to learn in, the Queensland construction industry has also benefited from Building the Education Revolution. As this House would well know, our construction industry is still trying to recover from the severe effects of the global financial crisis. The BER program is delivering real work for Queensland businesses, real jobs for locals and new facilities for our schools. I know that the Gold Coast construction industry has been particularly hard hit. It is our BER projects and others funded through the Bligh government’s $17.1 billion infrastructure program that is keeping them going.

The two PricewaterhouseCoopers reports and the federal task force report all tell us that BER in Queensland has been going well, has been managed and is a success. Even the opposition via the member for Moggill has acknowledged how important this BER program is. In fact, the member recently wrote to our education minister to inform him of how delighted he was by the BER program in his own electorate and even asked for more funding. Despite his private delight at the program, he is still publicly condemning it.

Three reports and a fourth on the way all tell us the same thing: BER in Queensland is a success and it is building first-class facilities to enhance and develop the young minds of our future generations. I know that our Minister for Education is anticipating another positive report when it is released tomorrow. I look forward to hearing more success stories from teachers, parents and students who, like me, are delighted with the results and the long-term outcomes of their Building the Education Revolution projects.

Mr HOBBS (Warrego--LNP) (11.59 am): For the last 16 years Queenslanders who live in Murray-Darling Basin catchments have negotiated, researched and argued on the value of every drop of water in that system. This protracted debate has taken a severe toll on many landholders and irrigators in terms of their private lives and in terms of their businesses. Due to the fact that Queensland was one of the last states in this system to develop its irrigation industry and southern states had already overallocated theirs, there was consistent pressure on Queensland to underdevelop and allow more water to flow into southern states. Queensland irrigators in the Lower Balonne even offered and gave up a 10 per cent reduction in allocations. Yes, there was a voluntary reduction of 10 per cent by Queensland irrigators to try to help the river system. The state Queensland Labor government deliberately manipulated the science and was discredited in a Land Court case. Landholders funded their own scientific studies. They had to because they could not trust what the government was saying. During this time, as members can imagine, debate was very heated.

As a circuit breaker the landholders’ science was peer reviewed by an independent group of scientists headed by the late Professor Peter Cullen from the Wentworth Group. That peer review found that the landholders’ science and understanding of the river was correct--that is, that the Lower Balonne was in fact in good shape and not dissimilar to the Warrego and the Paroo, where there was little or no irrigation. Finally after 16 years the resource operation plan was signed off on by the state government and peace finally came to the Murray-Darling Basin catchments in this state. Other river resource operation plans were also signed off on. The river system of the Murray-Darling Basin and in particular the Condamine-Balonne has had intensive scrutiny and has had detailed science, but we have a sustainable extraction rate for long-term sustainability.

The Commonwealth government has now instructed the Murray-Darling Basin Authority to redo all of the work that has already been done in Queensland in the Murray-Darling Basin catchment and to develop sustainable diversion limits. The Murray-Darling Basin Authority has determined a 3,000 to 4,000 gigalitre a year reduction in the current diversion limits which represents a reduction of between 22 per cent and 29 per cent on average across the whole basin. In Queensland our sustainable peer review, which is 15 years of scrutiny, shows that the river system is higher than the average. With regard to the Condamine-Balonne, they want to claw back 29 per cent. In terms of the Warrego, which has roughly 80 per cent end-of-valley flow, they want a 40 per cent cut. In terms of the Moonee, which has 70 per cent end-of-valley flow, they want a 34 per cent cut. In terms of the Nebine, which has in the vicinity of 90 per cent end-of-valley flow, they want a 40 per cent cut.

The Warrego runs into swamps and hardly gets to the Darling anyway. Therefore, this cutback will close down the existing small irrigating industry and will not put any more water into the Darling. This is a devastating plan for Queenslanders all the way down each river system--from the piggeries on the Downs and the hatcheries on the Downs to the feedlots, the farms and the towns from the Darling Downs right through to the border. This is only causing uncertainty once again for our industries, our towns and our jobs. The reason they have not had water down the Murray-Darling Basin is that it has not rained. There has been a drought. Everybody has been suffering, and even rivers not in the Murray-Darling Basin have also suffered the same fate. It has not damned well rained!

If the federal government is serious about finding some water, it should look at carrying out good environmental work on Menindee Lakes and save the 250 to 300 gigalitres from the evaporation that occurs each year. The Menindee Lakes has been changed from its natural state and man-made banks have been built to hold water back. A sustainable off-stream storage should be built to supply Broken Hill and the banks removed, with some careful planning and further works to be done to enhance the environmental qualities of the lakes and allow more water to flow down that system. A tax has also been put on the people of the Lower Balonne, which is worth $2.5 million a year. They are the only irrigators in the whole of Australia who have that special tax. That has been imposed on them and it should be removed. If the tax is to remain, at least put it into a fighting fund to fight this dreadful takeover by the Commonwealth government because it is only going to destroy our irrigators, our towns and our jobs in this state.

Ms NELSON-CARR (Mundingburra--ALP) (12.04 pm): I rise today to speak about a project which is little known in general but extremely well known as a positive achievement in some Townsville schools because of the collaboration between James Cook University and Education Queensland. It is a project which targets mobile students, particularly Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students, in high areas of disadvantage, and that means in many slabs of my electorate. At the end of 2010 funding for the Let’s Stay Put project at Heatley, Vincent and Currajong state schools will come to an end. These schools receive funding from Community Renewal money which was allocated based on the results from the Commonwealth project in 11 other Townsville schools. This funding has made a difference, and I thank the Minister for Communities for her foresight and commitment. The funding under the Smarter Schools National Partnership program for literacy and numeracy is the Closing the Gap commitment which I believe must be continued.

Let me talk about the Let’s Stay Put program. In 2006 Let’s Stay Put commenced in the Upper Ross in Townsville. The project aims to address the needs of students who are highly mobile--moving between multiple schools--like Simone, not her real name. Simone, a year 3 student, arrives at a local school to enrol. Simone is accompanied by her mother and brother. This will be the third school in the last three months. She attended her last school for three days and Simone’s mother explains that housing is difficult to find and she hopes her new rental home will last for a while. The Let’s Stay Put project is a great collaboration between Education Queensland and James Cook University’s School of Education in Townsville.

The project has two objectives. Firstly, it helps students and their families make a positive adjustment when they have to change schools through the deployment of a resource, a mobility support teacher, an MST. The MST is a fully qualified teacher who completes the enrolment process for every student who arrives at the school, ensuring a smooth transition through accurate assessment of learning and support needs, particularly in numeracy and literacy. The MST also plays a critical role linking families to support services, particularly housing and family services. The second aim is to promote the importance of stable schooling, especially in the early years of schooling. MSTs work to support mobile students and their families in their transition in the new school; support the principals and deputy principals in the enrolment process; work collaboratively with classroom teachers to ensure a successful transition; work with external agencies to ensure enrolling students and their families are supported; and collect and collate relevant data.

As I have said, these projects will cease operation at the end of this year. The funding has run out and those responsible for the program have been very creative in looking at ways to keep it going but so far to no avail. I do ask the Minister for Education to please give this some serious consideration and lobby the federal government at the ministerial council meetings for a continuation of what has turned out to be a collection of real data which should have serious implications for national data analysis. NAPLAN of course has its place, but with this significant cohort of mobile students it addresses the symptoms only and not the cause. The data is also skewed towards the census data collection--that is, like the day 8 numbers and so on. The real figures for this group are very different. The Let’s Stay Put project is evidence based action. Researchers from JCU have systematically collected data about every student who is enrolled or has left schools. This evidence shows the incredible extent of movement--movement that is not captured by the department’s current census collection methods. In these schools serving low socioeconomic communities, students can move back and forth between schools several times a year depending on family and housing circumstances. Sometimes they might stay a month at one school and other times a few days.

Benchmarked against movement in schools in Britain and the US, the schools in Townsville have exceptional levels of mobility. The index used by JCU researchers, the Joiners Plus Leavers Index, shows that while internationally mobility of school students of over 35 per cent is considered exceptionally high, in Townsville for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students mobility can be as high as 95 per cent. This is an extraordinary level of movement that obviously has huge impacts on schools and classrooms. Half of the Queensland Indigenous population actually lives in north and Far North Queensland and schools like Heatley, Vincent and Currajong are now focus schools for improving Indigenous education outcomes. Innovative programs like Let’s Stay Put, which provides just 0.5 of an additional teacher at each school, are able to be catalysts for improvements in learning and closing the gap.

Mrs MENKENS (Burdekin--LNP) (12.09 pm): A number of times I have raised in this House concerns about the minister’s administration of the department and the specific example of her Office for Women. Instead of being used as an effective advocate and a tool for change, the Office for Women is bogged down in bureaucracy literally. Ninety per cent of its budget is spent on staff and supplies. The minister can say anything she likes to try to defend this method of self-generating and self-supporting the administration. In fact, before the Estimates Committee F hearing this year she did make a number of statements that have little resemblance to reality.

The Women’s Infolink service is part of the information strategy of the Office for Women--part of the 10 per cent of expenditure that is not devoted to running itself. The Mason report into the office said that the Women’s Infolink line was ‘probably the best known component of this strategy’. In fact, the Mason report described the information function of the Office for Women as being a core function. It also listed a number of calls in the month preceding the report on issues such as couples and family counselling, domestic violence services, emergency housing issues and health and general counselling. Between 2005 and 2010, 23 per cent of calls have related to family law, 22 per cent to women’s health and 20 per cent to violence, primarily domestic violence.

On 1 July this year the Office for Women’s freecall 1800 infolink service was deleted from the White Pages online. It will be left out of the next White Pages directory as well. There is no longer a direct freecall number. The 13QGOV number--the local-call-cost general government number--is the only available contact. The call is answered by a consultant, male or female, who transfers calls through to the appropriate offices or provides referrals of government services. This is a result of a conscious decision to close the Women’s Infolink line, saving the department about $30,000 a year through the discontinuation of the Smart Service Queensland contract for the Women’s Infolink service. The use of the Women’s Infolink line has dropped dramatically in recent years. There were 5,000 calls to the line last year.

Now for the disparity. In the estimates hearing, held on 21 July, I asked the minister a simple question: could she guarantee that the Women’s Infolink line was going to remain open as a separate entity? The minister gave a response of about 150 words, in which she stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We have Smart Service Queensland as the agency that delivers services on behalf of other agencies. So we all contribute funding to that.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: In fact, the contract between the Office for Women and Smart Service Queensland was discontinued three weeks before this answer. The minister said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Seventy-seven thousand requests for information referral or advice were responded to by the Women’s Infolink telephone service.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The actual number is just seven per cent of that number--just 5,000 calls. The minister said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... people will access a number. It will say ‘Women’s Infolink’. In they go.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The White Pages number was discontinued three weeks earlier, with all calls going through the general Queensland government service. The minister said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Essentially, it is remaining open. It is open for business and it does a lot of business.
XML.Hansard-Body: Under RTI I have subsequently obtained an email of 3 June about the closure of the Women’s Infolink service which indicates an upcoming briefing of the minister and states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The main reason we are looking at closing the Women’s Infolink helpline is due to calls dropping by 75% since the service was transferred to SSQ--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: that is, Smart Service Queensland. It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: From the discussion I had with Mark earlier in the week I’m advised that from July all calls will go through the 13QGOV number and that we won’t be able to retain the Infolink 1800 177 577 number. If this is the case then we don’t have any option but to advertise with the 13QGOV number while we go through the process to seek approval to close Infolink.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This email is dated seven weeks before the estimates committee hearing. After the estimates committee hearing the following briefing note was sent to the minister with the comment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There are no issues in the Service Level Agreement with SSQ impeding the termination of the OFW--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: that is, Office for Women--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: service delivery contract.
XML.Hansard-Body: That briefing note outlined the 75 per cent decrease in the number of calls to the Women’s Infolink line and described the ‘low public profile of the service with stakeholders and the general community’. It stated further that the Office for Women was advised of the decommissioning of the number and detailed the omission from the White Pages . It even stated that it was not known where I obtained my information for the estimates hearing. It was a thorough briefing note.

So if the minister’s original answer was based on ignorance of the fact, there has been ample opportunity for her to correct the record. To date she has failed to do so. As a result, I will be writing to the Speaker to refer this matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee.

On a practical note, it is also of concern that the Smart Service Queensland service charter restricts the provision of referrals to government agencies only. When the subject matter of the calls to the Women’s Infolink are considered--domestic violence, family law and women’s health--the direction of these inquiries through the general government number has repercussions both for users of the service, who are seeking support and assistance, and for the non-government organisations that provide that support and assistance.

Mr O’BRIEN (Cook--ALP) (12.14 pm): How pathetic is Tony Abbott? After coming out after the election and saying that his first order of business would be to introduce legislation to stop Queensland’s Wild Rivers Act, he has subsequently stalled, backflipped and oozed away. But perhaps I am being disingenuous. Perhaps he is starting to listen not just to the broad range of people who live on Cape York Peninsula, many of whom support the legislation--people like Gina Castelain, David Claudie, Eddie Holroyd and Donnie De Busch--who are all traditional owners on Cape York and who all own businesses on Cape York Peninsula.

Perhaps Tony Abbott has listened to his Liberal National colleagues who have on several occasions supported the passage of the wild rivers legislation through this House. I remember well when we first introduced this legislation to the House. It was debated and, whilst some National Party members, as they were in those days, mumbled some concerns, they did not take the opportunity to oppose the legislation. The Liberals were more supportive. In fact, the member for Moggill commented during the second reading debate of the original bill--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... let me say that the Liberal Party understands that in a state with rapid development and a great deal of environmental impact from development the goal of preserving our relatively untouched river systems is a worthy goal, and we support the intent of a bill to that effect.
XML.Hansard-Body: The legislation was amended and improved following its enactment as the government continued to consult with stakeholders. This process culminated in the introduction of the Cape York Peninsula Heritage Bill in 2007. This legislation amended the Wild Rivers Act and received the virtual unanimous support of this parliament, including the member for Callide, who said at the time--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: But this legislation goes some way towards finding a balance through agreements reached by the government with representatives of the Cape York Land Council, Balkanu, the Wilderness Society, the Australian Conservation Foundation and AgForce. All of the parties to whom I have spoken are cautiously optimistic, saying that the agreement strikes the right balance.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The member for Callide went on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This bill makes a lot of concessions to the Indigenous people of the area. We welcome those changes. I acknowledge that the government has been able to come in here and acknowledge the fact that it got it wrong and that it is prepared to change it. That in itself should be acknowledged. The wild rivers legislation is being improved.
XML.Hansard-Body: Those are the words of the member for Callide. The member for Hinchinbrook said that the act ‘protects native title rights ... and asserts mandatory water allocations in each of the catchments once endangered by the wild rivers declaration. I support this act.’ The member for Burdekin said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: More and more people are interested in visiting all of these unspoilt areas of the world where development has been kept to a minimum and of course the unique natural features have been preserved. The tourism industry could be said to be sustainable and it can also help enrich the economy without adversely affecting the land if it is correctly managed. Tourism would provide an opportunity for members of the local Indigenous communities because they have a wonderful natural affinity with the land and also have vast knowledge of the land. Tourism is a way that they can showcase their culture to visitors to the cape.
XML.Hansard-Body: Given the support that those opposite have given to this legislation, I am at a loss to understand the statement of the Queensland Leader of the Opposition calling for wild rivers laws to be scrapped.

I am also confused about Noel Pearson’s approach to this issue.
