Noel has been an important partner with the state government in reforming a number of longstanding issues on Cape York, such as tenure resolution, alcohol management plans and now welfare reform. It is a huge agenda and I have backed him, even though those issues such as alcohol reforms have cost me large numbers of votes in Indigenous communities. The difficulty I have is that I was standing just near him on 7 June 2007 when we introduced the Cape York Heritage Bill into this parliament. That law reformed the original wild rivers legislation, including ensuring that native title rights remained unaffected and improving the process for development to be assessed in those areas. On that day Noel said that the legislation meant that land rights are going to be put behind us and that we can get on with the social agenda of development and welfare reform and social recovery. Soon after in the Australian Noel wrote that the law represents the best opportunity to strike a balance between conservation and development for the future of this region.

I do not want to fight with Noel or the Cape York Land Council. The issues in Indigenous communities are too large and have been going on for too long for any of us to afford that luxury. Dying in a ditch over wild rivers diverts the government’s focus from welfare reform, alcohol reform and business opportunities opening up on Cape York as infrastructure improves and awareness of its uniqueness grows. We on this side of the House understand that environmental protection is synonymous with economic growth. We understand that things like World Heritage listing in places like Cairns and Port Douglas and the Douglas region in general have brought an enormous number of jobs and an enormous amount of wealth to that region. That is why we will continue to support the wild rivers legislation.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Gladstone Region Social Infrastructure Strategic Plan; LNG Industry
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind)
(12.19 pm): I rise to speak on the announcement of the LNG industry in my electorate. I welcome the Premier’s response to my question without notice this morning. I also acknowledge the positive meetings I have had so far with the health minister in relation to health services. Whilst several of his staff members have come up to the Gladstone area, I look forward to the report that should be out in the next week or so in relation to future planning.

On 16 September, in question on notice No. 1886 in relation to the draft summary of preliminary findings for the Gladstone Region Social Infrastructure Strategic Plan, I asked the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning about the finalisation of the plan, why the delay had occurred and whether the minister had made any changes to the findings. The minister answered that question. He talked about the cooperation between the Queensland government and the Gladstone Regional Council to carry out the study, that the social infrastructure strategic plan will be used to guide the direction of future industry investment in social facilities and went on to answer a number of questions. However, the minister did not respond in relation to changes to the document from its forwarding from the region down to his office.

I would like to acknowledge, however, that at the bottom of that answer the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning commented on Mayor George Creed’s resignation and the fact that George had made a superb contribution to the region. I echo that. George is not enjoying good health at all.

The social infrastructure strategic plan has been touted as the blueprint for infrastructure for the region. I particularly valued the Premier’s comments this morning where she acknowledged that investment in infrastructure is not just the responsibility of the gas companies, it is the responsibility of government as well. The project overview of the SISP is to inform and guide future planning activities and investment decisions for strategic social infrastructure in the region. In the document that was forwarded to the minister titled, ‘The opportunities framework: Gladstone Region Social Infrastructure Strategic Plan’, if I go to the first item under the recommended opportunities framework it talks about health. It includes statements like ‘address the lack of public transport to access medical services in Rockhampton’, ‘consider a hospital shuttle bus’, ‘liaise with Queensland Rail’, ‘consider the potential for short-term provision of a small number of emergency acute inpatient mental health beds’ and ‘incorporation of an inpatient mental health unit in long-term strategic planning for Gladstone’--that is required immediately and long term--‘consider the level of emergency care available to meet the future needs of industry and potentially the availability of intensive care at Gladstone Hospital’. It goes on with approximately 15 or 16 recommendations on health and wellbeing, community health precincts, community health centres, general practitioners and allied health services. When we read through the document that was released, we find that it contains phrases such as ‘health and wellbeing’, ‘address the lack of public transport’, ‘provide support for staff development and funding of a children’s and families centre’, ‘fund innovative models’ and ‘consider the holistic health and wellbeing of the community’. It is significantly sanitised.

I table a copy of the two documents that were forwarded to the minister’s office from the group who did the study--that is, the Gladstone Region Social Infrastructure Strategic Plan, the Social Infrastructure Strategic Plan for the Gladstone Region, Summary Report, and then the Social Infrastructure Strategic Plan that was released by the minister to the community. There are significant differences. There is a huge reduction in the identified infrastructure needs from the document that was forwarded to the minister’s office after the study and the document that came out of the minister’s office. It could be said that the reduction is identifying those things that can be contributed to by the Gladstone Foundation. If that is the case, I believe the report released by the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning does a disservice to all those who contributed to the original plan. There can be indicators in a report to show those items suitable to the Gladstone Foundation and those that government should fund. We need that infrastructure desperately.

XML.Hansard-Body:
Ms DARLING (Sandgate--ALP)
(12.24 pm): The Urban Land Development Authority was established as part of the Bligh Labor government’s commitment to affordable housing. But the authority has also been charged with developing liveable and environmentally sustainable neighbourhoods and I am pleased to report that it is excelling. On 18 September, Minister for Infrastructure and Planning Stirling Hinchliffe and I officially opened the Fitzgibbon Chase display village. We enjoyed a tour of the houses on display by Aushomes, AV Jennings and Ausbuild, all of which have a six-star energy rating. We also had a sneak peak at the new ‘Fonzie’ flats which have sold for under $200,000 and some of which should be occupied by the end of the year. The open day that was held on the same day was also a great opportunity for local residents to check out what has been happening on the site next door.

Fitzgibbon Chase has parks and barbecues which are now operational for the use of all local residents. I took the opportunity to play the musical handrails on the bridge above one of the new parks. I would like to thank the artists, Barbara Penrose and Nameer Davis, for making the most of an Arts Queensland grant to bring music to the residents of Fitzgibbon Chase. This is a truly unique and delightful addition.The minister and I crossed two new footbridges to walk from the display village and information centre to the existing streets and houses of Fitzgibbon. Again, these new footbridges, provided with state funding, mean that Fitzgibbon residents in the older part of the suburb now have a direct walking or cycling path to Carseldine station. I would like to acknowledge and thank the many people who raised this issue with me and I am please that we have delivered. I am determined to ensure that this development provides lifestyle improvements for the entire neighbourhood, like connecting pathways, green space and recreational areas, not just for the new residents moving into the development. Many Fitzgibbon houses have been subject to flooding in the past, but flood mitigation works on the new site will benefit both new and existing homes while providing sustainable water use.

It was very exciting last month to welcome the first new residents into their homes. I noticed many young people choosing to set up share houses, as well as families and singles. The mix of dwelling types at Fitzgibbon will encourage a mix of people to the area and I know that the development will provide opportunities and services, such as commercial and community spaces, for both employment and relaxation. Premier Anna Bligh has also made a decision that will bring further opportunities to the area and consolidate its future as an important northside hub.

I welcome the announcement that the former QUT Carseldine campus will become a government office precinct. It is anticipated that around 1,000 Public Service workers will be based at Carseldine by the end of 2012 with the decentralisation initiative being a catalyst for the new Carseldine Urban Village. I am keen to see open spaces on the Carseldine side of the development, with sport and recreation areas for northside residents. I am also thrilled that this decision brings certainty to the child-care centre that was originally established to provide care to children of staff and students at the campus but is being used by many local families in my electorate as it is a beautiful centre with top-class staff. I am pleased that my lobbying to save the centre has paid off and I thank the parents in my electorate who raised this with me.

The C&K Carseldine Community Childcare Centre, as it is now known, has been through some uncertain times since QUT ceased using the campus and subsequently the student guild moved away from providing child-care services. I thank C&K for coming to the rescue, but I know it has been a very unsettling time for staff and families. I know that workers in the government office precinct will appreciate the services at their doorstep such as child care, shops, trains and buses. The precinct, which is within the Fitzgibbon UDA, will also provide an opportunity for the many public servants living in my electorate to seek work closer to home.

I look forward to discussing the practicalities of decentralising many Public Service offices with the unions and my local workers. I thank those constituents who have already started the conversation with me about sensible decentralisation that supports worker lifestyle and reduces the cost and environmental impact of commuting. The entire Fitzgibbon development is expected to inject $500 million into the Queensland economy with the delivery of 1,400 jobs over the life of the project, plus provide ongoing government, commercial and retail opportunities for thousands of workers once the development is complete. I congratulate Paul Eagles, Minister Stirling Hinchliffe and ULDA staff for their professional approach to planning such a liveable community on the north side of Brisbane.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): The time for matters of public interest has now expired.

S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (12.32 pm): I present a bill for an act to amend the Energy Ombudsman Act 2006, the Environmental Protection Act 1994, the Fisheries Act 1994, the Land Valuation Act 2010, the Mineral Resources Act 1989, the Petroleum Act 1923, the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004, the Queensland Competition Authority Act 1997, the Queensland Institute of Medical Research Act 1945, the South-East Queensland Water (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) Act 2009, the Sustainable Planning Act 2009, the Vegetation Management Act 1999, the Water Act 2000, the Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act 2008 and the Wild Rivers Act 2005 for particular purposes, and to make consequential or minor amendments of other acts as stated in schedule 2 for purposes related to those particular purposes. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Water and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010.
Tabled paper: Water and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, explanatory notes.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (12.32 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Water and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 amends the South-East Queensland Water (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) Act 2009 and the Energy Ombudsman Act 2006 to further implement the second stage of the South-East Queensland water reform program and provide key additional customer protection provisions for residential and small business water customers. Following the commencement of the council owned distributor-retailers on 1 July 2010, the government is now implementing a strengthened package of transparency and regulatory protections for customers. Under these amendments customers will
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: be informed about their distributor-retailer’s governance and accountability arrangements in respect of its participant councils; be notified of proposed and final water and wastewater prices and charges; be better informed about the contents of their water and wastewater bill, including identifying when it has been based upon an estimated meter read; and have access to an independent dispute resolution process provided by the Energy and Water Ombudsman Queensland in accordance with a Customer Water and Wastewater Code.
XML.Hansard-Body: A regulation-making power will also be introduced to allow the contents of a water and wastewater bill to be further defined. This is necessary in light of the somewhat dishonest and tricky campaigns that have been launched by some councils in South-East Queensland over the last number of months. Through confusing water bills, some councils have deliberately set out to blame the state for water charges levied by council owned water and sewerage businesses. Some councils have been deliberately hiding the simple facts that, on average, three-quarters of the average South-East Queensland water and sewerage bill is levied by council owned water businesses. Only a quarter of the average bill is a result of state government bulk water charges. This regulation- making power is designed to enable the development of a clear template to ensure residents receive straightforward and honest information.

The Energy and Water Ombudsman is an expanded role for the current Energy Ombudsman. It will be industry funded and supported by an advisory council comprising industry and customer representatives. The introduction of the ombudsman is necessary in light of confusing messages from some councils and the current high number of complaints about service.

The Customer Water and Wastewater Code will be released for public consultation shortly. Public feedback will be incorporated into the final code, which will commence on 1 January 2011 in line with the Energy and Water Ombudsman. While the Energy and Water Ombudsman will have jurisdiction in South-East Queensland only at this stage, its powers could be expanded later across the state. This expansion might be necessary to protect consumers should some local governments continue to engage in misleading and confusing campaigns about water and sewerage services and prices.

The bill also includes amendments to the Queensland Competition Authority Act 1997. These amendments will enable the Queensland Competition Authority to make binding and enforceable price determinations for the water and wastewater services provided by South-East Queensland’s three distributor-retailers water authorities: Allconnex Water, Queensland Urban Utilities and Unitywater. Based on a transparent and independent scrutiny of the costs of providing water and wastewater services, enforceable price determinations will allow the Queensland Competition Authority to regulate the prices these water authorities may charge consumers. This will provide increased consumer protection and will ensure that the prices consumers are charged are fair and efficient. Price determinations for these water authorities will be in place from 1 July 2013.

The bill will also make amendments to the Queensland Competition Authority Act to update and enhance the existing process for the making of price determinations. Importantly, the bill will explicitly require the authority to consider implementing price paths in order to moderate the impact on consumers of increases in price over time.

The bill also provides for amendments to the South-East Queensland Water (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) Act 2009 to continue previously held exemptions from the payment of fixed access charges for water and wastewater services under the Local Government Act 2009 and associated regulations.

Today I introduce into parliament an important bill to further deliver on the government’s blueprint for Queensland’s liquefied natural gas industry. The emergence of this new industry is significant for all Queenslanders. The government is committed to achieving a balance between the development of the coal seam gas industry for the benefit of all Queenslanders and the rights of landholders and environmental sustainability.

Under the Water Act 2000 this bill puts in place a strong groundwater management regime to manage impacts on bore water supply and natural springs while the petroleum companies exercise their water rights under their tenure. This new regulatory regime replaces the current framework under the petroleum legislation. This bill provides that all petroleum companies, including CSG companies, have an obligation to make good impacts on bore water supplies and mitigate impacts on natural springs caused by their extraction of groundwater. Consistent with the government’s earlier announcement, trigger thresholds are specifically set in the bill to ensure impacts on water supplies linked to groundwater extraction are investigated and made good. The triggers are two metres in alluvial aquifers, such as the Condamine Alluvium, and five metres in consolidated aquifers, such as the Great Artesian Basin. Impacts or likely impacts on water supply bores caused by the extraction of underground water by petroleum tenure holders, resulting in reduced water quantity and any consequential impact on water quality, will be made good by the petroleum tenure holders.

A key first step for petroleum tenure holders will be the undertaking of assessments to collect baseline information on water supply bores and then, following bore assessments being conducted, make good agreements will be entered into with bore owners. An adaptive management regime underpins this new regulatory framework to allow progressive improvement in the understanding of impacts and also to support timely implementation of the make good arrangements for water supply bores. Petroleum companies will, every three years or earlier if required, produce underground water impact reports subject to public consultation. These reports will include a comprehensive water monitoring program, a projection of future likely water level impacts using progressively updated groundwater flow models and a spring impact management strategy.
Importantly, this groundwater management regime will manage the cumulative impacts of groundwater extraction. A cumulative management area will be established where impacts of tenure holders overlap.

The bill expands the functions of the Queensland Water Commission to have responsibility for regional groundwater monitoring and flow modelling and the production of the underground water impact report for the cumulative management area. Through its underground water impact report, the QWC will also assign areas of responsibility to individual petroleum companies in relation to make-good obligations and monitoring activity. These expanded functions of the QWC will be funded by a levy on the petroleum industry. The bill provides for a dispute resolution process about make-good arrangements requiring mandatory mediation, which can be facilitated by the Department of Environment and Resource Management assisting with technical information, before bringing the matter before the Land Court.

A key issue raised by landholders and conservation groups during consultation was the issue of impacts on the groundwater resource as a whole. Of particular concern was the need for the groundwater resource to be assessed and managed within the proposed Water Act framework. While it is recognised that impacts on the groundwater resource as a whole are currently managed under the Environmental Protection Act framework, the government will give further consideration to expanding the Water Act framework in the future to include an aquifer impact management strategy within the underground water impact reporting requirements.

Landholders have also raised the issue about what happens to make-good commitments if a gas company is insolvent. The Queensland government takes this issue seriously and has formed a project team that draws on key personnel across a number of government departments to work through these potential issues. The project will check to ensure that our current regulatory framework, with financial assurance under the Environmental Protection Act 1994, combined with the new provisions to the Water Act introduced in this bill, adequately addresses those concerns. Depending on the outcome of the project, the government will ensure any outstanding issues are addressed.

This bill amends the Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act 2008 to provide purpose-built rigorous requirements for the supply of CSG water if it has a material impact on town drinking water supply sources. In such cases, CSG water will be regulated as recycled water. This is necessary to ensure the protection of public health and provide public assurance that public health is being protected. This may be by supply of CSG water into a watercourse or aquifer, or by directly supplying to a town as a source for drinking water supply. A recycled water management plan will be required, except where it can be demonstrated there is no material impact on the town’s drinking water supply or where certain requirements are met specific to aquifers.

CSG recycled water providers will be required to prove treatment process, and supporting management arrangements will consistently deliver water of the quality required. They will also be required to review their recycled water management plans, conduct internal audits, engage third-party auditors to audit compliance with their plan, make water quality information publicly available and provide annual reports.

This bill also amends the Wild Rivers Act 2005 to extend the purpose of the act to preserve the existing natural values of the Lake Eyre Basin rivers. Those rivers have been subject to reasonable levels of development. However, they retain unique geographical and environmental values that are worth preserving. This amendment delivers on an election commitment to extend wild rivers protection to the Lake Eyre Basin. The bill amends the Vegetation Management Act 1999 to ensure category X and category C property maps of assessable vegetation or an area mapped as non-remnant on the regional ecosystem map or remnant map, in place prior to the area being included in a wild river declaration, will continue as an existing lawful right.

This bill demonstrates that the government has again undertaken extensive consultation on wild rivers. We have made changes to reflect feedback from the communities of Lake Eyre Basin and Cape York, for example allowing for changes to property maps of assessable vegetation in high preservation areas and managing impacts of development on the channel country of the Lake Eyre Basin.

In September the government introduced important amendments to the valuation system in Queensland. The Land Valuation Act 2010 introduced a range of reforms to the valuation system to bring Queensland into line with other jurisdictions and introduce a more simplified and easily understood statutory valuation process. An amendment to the act is now required to ensure the government policy intent in introducing valuation reform is met. When the act received assent, the ability to undertake a statutory value of the surface area of mining, geothermal, greenhouse gas and petroleum leases was removed and this has caused the unintended consequence of increasing the value of these leases. This was not the government intent, so we are amending the act to ensure the status quo remains for the valuation of these leases.

The bill also amends the Queensland Institute of Medical Research Act 1945 to make important changes to the governance arrangements for the Queensland Institute of Medical Research to help it operate more effectively and efficiently. The amendments are being progressed in this bill rather than in a Health portfolio bill to ensure that the new governance arrangements can be implemented as close as possible to when the recently appointed director of the QIMR takes office early next year. The amendments abolish the QIMR trust, which has fundraising and investment functions, and confers those functions on the QIMR Council, the QIMR’s governing body. Having a single statutory body under the act will enhance the strategic management of the QIMR and provide for greater administrative and resourcing efficiencies. In addition, changes are made to the council’s membership structure which provide for greater flexibility in its appointment to enhance the council’s ability to effectively perform its extended functions. The QIMR strongly supports these amendments. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Seeney, adjourned.
Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (12.45 pm), by leave, without notice: I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That government business orders of the day Nos 1 to 11 be postponed.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (12.45 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1) That this House requests the Governor in Council to revoke by regulation under section 26 of the Forestry Act 1959 the setting apart and declaration as State Forest of the area as set out in the proposal tabled by me in the House today, viz

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Centred.Hansard-Bold: Description of area to be revoked

CELL.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Area described as lots 3, 5 and 6 on plan SP240432 and containing an area of 7.5765 hectares as illustrated on the attached sketch.

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 2) That Mr Speaker and the Clerk of the Parliament forward a copy of this resolution to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade for submission to the Governor in Council.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Department of Environment and Resource Management, through the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service, manages 417 state forests and 638 protected areas, covering nearly 12 million hectares across Queensland. With such a large and dispersed estate, there is the occasional need to revoke small areas from the state forest estate for legitimate purposes, for example to allow the upgrade or expansion of essential public infrastructure, including roads and railways. I will only support the revocation of land from our state forest estate for an alternative use if it can be clearly demonstrated that the proposed usage is in the broader public interest and there is no other practical alternative. The Department of Environment and Resource Management has given careful consideration to this proposal and appropriate consultation has occurred with affected stakeholders. Native title issues have also been considered in relation to this proposal and it has been determined that this action may proceed.

I will now outline the background of this proposal and the offsetting arrangements that have been agreed to compensate for the loss of estate. This proposal will revoke approximately 7.5 hectares of land from Sonoma State Forest, which is located about 12 kilometres north of Collinsville, and will allow for the construction of an additional rail line. This is a component of Queensland Rail’s northern missing link project, which will provide up to 50 million tonnes of additional capacity for coal transportation per annum. This will be achieved by connecting the existing rail network serving the Bowen Basin coalfields in Central Queensland to the rail line from Newlands and the Port of Abbot Point.

The area known as Briaba Bank, within Sonoma State Forest, has been identified as one of the sites where rail infrastructure improvements are necessary. Several alternative routes were considered. However, with this proposal most of the additional track may be constructed within the existing rail and road corridors, with only a small area of state forest required to supplement the proposed rail corridor. Corridors for the existing rail and the Bowen Developmental Road pass through the north-west corner of the state forest and also along its western boundary. By realigning part of the rail infrastructure on the existing road reserve, the total area of land required to be revoked from the state forest has been kept to a minimum. It is anticipated that construction of the northern missing link and the stage 3 expansion of the Abbot Point Coal Terminal will significantly increase the capacity and flexibility of Central Queensland’s coal export infrastructure.

In keeping with successive governments’ policy that there be a net gain for conservation from revocations, compensation on a two-hectares-for-one basis for the proposed loss from the state forest estate has been negotiated with the Department of Transport and Main Roads. While the Department of Transport and Main Roads does not have any land available to be added to the Sonoma State Forest, in 2009 agreement was reached that a sizeable area of land with good conservation values adjoining Mount Stowe State Forest, near Gladstone, would be made available as a land bank for compensation for a related revocation and any future revocations, including this proposal. The loss of conservation values from the area proposed for revocation is not considered to be significant, as it is comprised of sparsely wooded forest, classified as ‘not of concern under the Vegetation Management Regulation. I commend the motion to the House.

Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (12.49 pm): The opposition will be supporting the revocation involved in the motion moved by the minister. It is a sensible move to allow the progression of a vital piece of rail infrastructure. The northern missing link rail infrastructure has been overdue for some time. The motion before the House today will facilitate its long-awaited construction.

The minister has outlined the details of the revocation at some length, and I will not repeat those. However, I think the process that the minister went through could be seen as unnecessarily long and convoluted, especially in regard to the government’s offsets policy. Queensland has a large area of state forest and not all of that area has high conservation values. I note the minister’s comments about this particular area not having high conservation values being open woodland, and that is characteristic of a significant percentage of the area that was set aside as state forest land many, many years ago. I do not believe that it is necessary to consider every last piece of that state forest estate as being something that is inviolate and requires the types of offset that the government obviously adopts as a policy.

I believe it is appropriate for state land to be used for this sort of infrastructure when and if it is available and appropriate. The use of state land for building essentially state infrastructure should be seen as a right and proper purpose for that state land. While I take a view that those offset provisions to the extent to which the minister has outlined them may well be over the top, I have no problems at all with supporting the motion before the House to implement the revocation of this relatively small area of state land to allow what is a piece of infrastructure that the state badly needs to proceed. We will therefore support the motion before the House.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (12.52 pm), in reply: I commence my summation by thanking the shadow minister for his support and therefore the support of the opposition. Without wanting to provoke a longer debate, I do note his reservations that he has just enunciated. That is an issue that clearly delineates this side of the House from the other. The fact that we do believe, no matter how small, that offsets are appropriate to add to a net increase in conservation in this state is something that we are proud of. It may be convoluted in some cases, but it is scientifically robust and does add to a net increase in the conservation estate of this state of Queensland. The fact that the member has, as is his right, outlined his concerns should be noted as a matter that does delineate, as I said, the views and beliefs of this Labor government against those enunciated by the LNP. Having noted that, and not wanting to be overly provocative at this stage, I once again do thank the member and the opposition for their support for this motion.
Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
Resumed from 5 October (see p. 3516), on motion of Mr Roberts--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr JOHNSON (Gregory--LNP) (12.53 pm): The Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 is a very important piece of legislation. This bill amends the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 to support the state-wide rollout of ticketing for public nuisance, public urination and associated offences, as the minister points out in the explanatory notes. The Police Legislation Amendment Bill was introduced into the parliament recently on 5 October. The bill has three main objectives, as I just said, to amend the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 to enable the state-wide rollout of ticketing for public nuisance and associated offences.

As I was putting my tie on this morning, I was thinking about the police commemorative service that I went to recently. There was this little card in the order of service about a Constable Gregory Olive, who lost his life on 19 February 1962. He was fatally shot when he went to make inquiries regarding a neighbourhood dispute at a house in Kelvin Grove. When we think about this young officer, we think about the work that the police do in this state on a daily basis. That work is unprecedented. They put their lives on the line every day trying to create a safe environment for the likes of us, our families, our friends and the wider community of Queensland who want a safer and better state.

It is a sad situation when we need to bring this type of legislation into parliament. I think it is good legislation. The police will now be able to give these louts in public places--who want to be public nuisances, who want to deface and violate the objectives of what good common sense in society is all about--a ticket on the spot. This will keep them out of the courts, where the system is already overtaxed. Possibly we will see a turnaround in the behaviour of some of this loutish behaviour. Maybe we will see in time a situation where police are not subjected to violence, where they are respected in the community by the one per cent or thereabouts who do not have the same respect and regard as the other 99 per cent have.
In its review in 2008 of the public nuisance offences, the Crime and Misconduct Commission wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The new public nuisance offence now contained in section 6 of the Summary Offences Act makes it an offence to commit a public nuisance, with a maximum penalty of 10 penalty units ($750) or 6 months’ imprisonment ...
A person commits a public nuisance offence if their behaviour is both:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • disorderly, offensive, threatening or violent
• interfering with, or likely to interfere with, a person’s peaceful passage through, or enjoyment of, a public place ...
XML.Hansard-Body: Public places cover a pretty big area. I think the general public of Queensland are sick and tired of this behaviour as a common occurrence right throughout Queensland. We do not just see it here in Brisbane. We do not just see it on the Gold Coast. We see it right across the state, unfortunately. I even see it from time to time in my own electorate, which most of the time is a pretty peaceful area. But it is marvellous what alcohol will do to some people. It changes their character. On top of that, some of these people are on drugs, and drugs and alcohol is a very volatile mix. Again, as I say, our police are the ones who have to be the analysts of the situation, the evaluators of the situation and, ultimately, the people who have to make that decision sometimes on the spur of the moment to protect the wider community and also to protect themselves in the execution of their duty. The CMC report states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Section 6 states that offensive behaviour will include the use of offensive, obscene, indecent or abusive language and threatening behaviour includes the use of threatening language ...

A ‘public place’ is broadly defined to mean a place that is open to or used by the public, whether or not on payment of a fee. It clearly includes places such as shopping centres (see Schedule 2 of the Summary Offences Act).
XML.Hansard-Body: In examining the issues surrounding public order and disorderly type offences, the CMC noted previous research when it wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Australian empirical research clearly indicates that public order incidents contribute to fear of crime. Peter Grabosky’s (1995, p. 3) review of Australian research shows that ‘incivilities’, including ‘the frequent presence of drunks, vagrants, or unruly gatherings of young males’, induce a fear of crime in some people as these seem to suggest that the location in question is ‘out of control’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I were young blokes in communities once. I think we had a better respect and a better understanding of what our civil responsibilities were. It is unfortunate that this does not seem to be the case today. I think it has been fuelled by more young people out there. We have some fantastic young people in this state. One of my schools from Blackwater came through this morning. The kids were absolutely fantastic--their manners, their behaviour, the whole bit. This reflects that the good kids, the good young people of society, are being branded by the minority out there who want to be idiots, who want to cause concern, who want to violate what the good community wants and, ultimately, we now have this legislation before us. But I think the legislation is going to be an important factor in making certain that we do bring some credibility, some decency and some respect back into the public places that we all want to enjoy on a daily basis.
Sitting suspended from 1.00 pm to 2.30 pm.

Mr JOHNSON: As I mentioned before the lunch break, the introduction of a ticketing system for these types of offences was recommended in a CMC report on Queensland public nuisance offences which was released in May 2008. The CMC found that 60 per cent of summary offences dealt with in the Magistrates Court were offences of public nuisance and that 97 per cent of defendants either pleaded guilty or were found guilty after they failed to appear in court.

There was a 12-month trail of on-the-spot ticketing for public nuisance offences in addition to existing powers to arrest or issue an offender with a notice to appear in court. Griffith University has been engaged to undertake an evaluation of the trial. The Griffith University report concludes that tickets are a cost-effective means of dealing with public nuisance offences. I urge the minister in his summing-up to make reference to the types of offences and the relevant fines and penalties. If it is going to act as a deterrent, I think the penalties have to be pretty stiff, especially when it comes to the abuse of police in the execution of their duties.

Time and time again the opposition has been vocal in trying to put into this House a private member’s bill, as the Western Australian government has successfully done, relating to violence against police in the execution of their duties. I do not believe this is about playing politics. It is not about playing politics; it is about making our communities safer and better. When people go out--whether it be in the mall in Brisbane in the middle of the night or Toowoomba in the late evening or Cairns or any other regional centre--they want to be able to enjoy themselves and not be victimised by louts who want to make idiots of themselves and denigrate the values of these venues that we are talking about.

During the trial, 46 per cent of all persons ticketed had no previous criminal history and only one per cent of people who received tickets contested them before the courts. The report also found that the trial led to improved workload efficiencies for both the courts and the Police Service.

Previous research, as noted by Dr Tamara Walsh of the University of Queensland, has found that laws aimed at regulating public spaces have a disproportionate impact on the lives of those who are homeless or at risk of homelessness, as many social security recipients are. Homeless people by definition lack secure housing and thus they tend to occupy public spaces more frequently than the remainder of the population. Homeless people, particularly those who lack shelter altogether, are forced to live out their lives in public. They necessarily conduct certain behaviour, such as urinating, defecating, drinking alcohol and socialising, in public which the majority of the population prefer to conduct in the privacy of their homes or in the public amenities available. As a result, these people who are homeless are more visible to police, more likely to attract attention and more likely to behave offensively and, in turn, are more vulnerable to being considered a public nuisance.

It is this disproportionate focus which was a concern raised by civil liberties groups. Dr Walsh wrote that many vulnerable people are overrepresented amongst those prosecuted for acting offensively, even though their offensive behave may be reflective of their disadvantaged status. Instead of a law and order response, a therapeutic approach that addresses the underlying causes of defendants’ offending behaviour must be implemented. This very point has been clear and present in the Townsville area for some time and despite calls for mandatory rehabilitation for those homeless in the area suffering chronic drunkenness.

Research out of New South Wales found that 74 per cent of public order incidents--that is, assaults, offensive behaviour and offensive language incidents--were alcohol related in that the perpetrators had consumed alcohol within a few hours before the offence. In addition, 60 per cent of all alcohol related street offences in this study occurred on or in the vicinity of licensed premises and 91 per cent occurred around the closing times of bars, from 10 pm to 2 am.

I think it important that whilst we move to take many public nuisance offences out of the courts we need to ensure that those most at risk of committing such offences can be diverted where possible through proper rehabilitation and support programs. This is important when it comes to making certain that our streets are safe, that our communities are safe and that people can go about their business safely.

We cannot tolerate and must not tolerate this behaviour. At the same time, our police must be given every opportunity and every support in making certain that these young people or older people or anybody who wants to thumb their nose at the law become the subject of the police executing their right to make our streets safe and a community that people can be proud to be a part of.

Another provision of this legislation is to amend the Prostitution Act 1999 and the Prostitution Regulation 2000 to allow for automatic suspension and cancellation of a brothel licence or an approved managers certificate for nonpayment of annual fees. A licensee who has not paid that fee can have their licence suspended for 28 days. If the fee is still not paid their licence will be cancelled. This surprises me somewhat. I would like the minister to answer in his summing-up how many licensees fall into this category currently. This is an industry that certainly needs close scrutiny--not only scrutiny from police but also scrutiny from health authorities--to make certain that the women who work within this industry are given every opportunity to have the best health checks and the best protection available to them. As we know, there are many diseases out there. People who violate these licence regulations are certainly going to draw attention to themselves. This industry does attract many undesirable elements, especially that male element that want to visit these institutions to take advantage of what I believe are unfortunate women.

At the end of the day, it is most important that people within the Prostitution Licensing Authority area feel secure and that those people who breach those rules are brought to justice, and I believe that the book has to be thrown at them. There are always many issues confronting any licensed premises, and there are similarities between the licensing of brothels and the Liquor Act in terms of the suspension of licences. The explanatory notes state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: lifting of a suspension where, in exceptional circumstances, a licensee or approved manager enters into a payment plan with the PLA--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Prostitution Licensing Authority--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: for the payment of the outstanding annual fees;
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I ask the minister to elaborate on that. Does that mean that they are going to get time to pay outstanding fees? I would have thought that anyone who runs a business of this nature would have to pay that fee upfront or pay it when it is due. I ask for clarification of that situation. The explanatory notes go on to state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: automatic cancellation of the licence or approved manager’s certificate if the annual fees are not paid during the suspensions period or in accordance with any payment plan.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: One thing that concerns me and concerns the opposition is that payment plan, because it seems that there might be an out for these people to have a timed payment arrangement.
XML.Hansard-Body: Over many years--since time immemorial--prostitution has drawn the attention of the police to that element of society who want to break the law, and those same people are found to be culprits in many other areas of criminal activity. This is not an easy issue. It is all very well to stand in here and criticise, but the police are the people who do the surveillance. They are constantly out there monitoring this aspect of society, and I do not envy their job at all. The fact is that people who are licensed to operate these venues and the people who work within these venues certainly must be working within the confines of the law set down within this parliament.

Clause 6 of this legislation enables the electronic evaluation of offenders’ records of criminal offences for police surveillance and screening reasons. Currently, section 10.2A allows the commissioner to disclose criminal records within the CrimTrac and other police systems. This will allow a more specialised observation of offenders on a national basis under this sophisticated technology. Whether these people are breaching the law in the street or whether they are breaching the law under the prostitution licensing act or whatever, the powers that we give our police to surveil these situations are absolutely paramount in making our state’s streets safer. However, at the same time we have to give our police every resource we can to ensure that we are observing this criminal element that violates the law and snubs their nose at authorities.

In recent days we have heard about the unfortunate situation of police activity on the Gold Coast and the attention that some police have drawn to themselves at Airlie Beach, but I will say this in defence of Queensland police: the greater majority of them--99.9 per cent of our police--are out there doing an exemplary job. They are people who are committed to the cause and dedicated to their professional duties, and we must respect the work that they do.

Today I put it on the record that some of my constituents have made reference to me about some of our one-man stations around the state that have been the focus of closure. Regardless of where police are operating or what their responsibilities are, it is very important that we give the police the resources they need, whether they live in remote areas or coastal areas. Police presence is a deterrent in its own way without the police having to do anything. The public being able to observe the police is a deterrent to that element of society who wants to breach the law. This legislation will give police the power to execute their authority to ensure that those people are penalised or are subjected to a fine on the spot, and that is certainly going to make our community a safer place and keep these people out of the courts. That is going to enhance the opportunity of a better community for all and sundry. With that, I support this legislation.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (2.45 pm): The Police Service has a long history of the successful transition of crime prevention to crime resolution that reflects the times. Our Queensland Police Service, QPS, has more than its daily work cut out for it managing an increasing deluge of paperwork and process when the community is calling on it to be far more visible. This bill is a sensible attempt to reduce the increasing paper chase for our police officers for offences that should not impede their ability to do that for which they are properly trained. Additionally, this bill enables the CrimTrac system to function as per its design and the PLA, the Prostitution Licensing Authority, to be able to proceed with its activities in the event of no shows by industry offenders.

The critical piece of this legislation deals with public nuisance offences, which include being a public nuisance, urination in public and associated offences. These associated offences still seem to remain unclear on reading both the bill and the explanatory notes. This issue is a significant one. Public disorder has become a hallmark of Labor in government for nearly all of the 20 years of its governance. It is so because Labor underestimates offenders and overestimates its own ability to manage those offenders and the reasons that are associated with the offending behaviour. The evidence for this statement is merely to be found in the report card--that is, the number of offences of a nuisance nature annually responded to, the growth of those offences and the relative cost of those offences, inclusive of reception costs. There are 1,000 plus offences annually of this type, the growth is at least three per cent to four per cent and the cost is one to two hours of police down time. For each new offence that hourly cost is $200 directly and roughly $340 if one allows for having to replace that officer in the community when the other officer is doing the critical clerical work.

The QPS ran a trial in 2009 using infringement notices for public nuisance, urination and other minimal offences. It followed a CMC report recommending this step. Griffith University has been engaged to undertake the evaluation of the trial and has done so with a result determining that the issuing of these tickets is a cost-effective means of dealing with public nuisance offences. The minister has stated that 46 per cent of those issued with tickets have no prior criminal history. For those living on the Gold Coast this law particularly has focused on ‘managing party people’--I quote the minister from his second reading speech--‘with a potential to prevent them from entering the criminal justice system’. I want to discuss everything from the offences, the definitions, tickets and what really is best to manage party people. But I am going to start with the last first because one needs to state the blindingly obvious. To manage party people one needs to remove the party people from the environment where their behaviour is so unacceptable, because, often under the influence of alcohol and drugs, those offenders will often continue to offend until they are removed. On the Gold Coast there are too many examples where offenders are not removed and they continue to cause havoc until they are removed. Issuing this group with tickets is naive. The police need to remove the offender, whether or not they issue them with tickets, and that will actually stop the offending behaviour. Certainly, this is the Gold Coast environment and I do not want to speak for all of the other parts of the state, but it is very similar across Australia.

It may be even that zero tolerance is not enough and the government, by refusing to use its powers under the Liquor Act, is compounding everything from public nuisance offences to more serious offences. Yesterday, the fair trading minister refused to accept interstate and overseas evidence that demonstrates that restricting the number of licensing outlets in a particular area reduces offending behaviour. His statements fly in the face of powerful evidence. Yet we have a flawed strategy of issuing tickets as a general response where far more specific action is called for. The minister jumped on the bandwagon and said that caps on the number of outlets that sell alcohol would be against national competition rules. In view of the serious nature of the offences, the difficulty in managing these types of behaviours, and evidence from Sydney and London that restricting the numbers of licences in designated areas does reduce crime and offending behaviours, has the minister ever considered the submission to the federal government and also to the Attorney-General with regard to reviewing that component of competition law that may well save lives? Ideology should not blind one to what is needed in the community. We have a problem with the issue of zero tolerance, because some people falsely equate it with a police state mentality. The issue of zero tolerance in certain situations will prevent serious injury and maybe even save lives. We need to change our attitudes to what will work in certain situations and appropriately deliver laws that suit those environments.

The issue of tickets is really very interesting. If one is to use traffic offences as any guide, many of these tickets--possibly nearly 80 per cent--are lost, destroyed or ignored. SPER, that Leviathan-like monster that lurks in the background, will have a major role in the consequences of issuing tickets. No doubt SPER will go on to cancel further licences and we will have the issue of further unlicensed drivers who committed offences, and others, driving around our streets. Presumably, these tickets will largely be for amounts of between $100 and $300, which is strangely about what some seem capable of spending on a very big night or a weekend.

I am concerned that the implementation of the tickets has not included a consideration of including what is known as a positive ticketing program. That program, which was introduced originally in Vancouver in 2001, has since spread to more than 50 countries. I am greatly concerned that the program is being politely ignored by this state Labor government and that the QPS has, in fact, denigrated it. That disappoints me and many other people, particularly on the Gold Coast, where the CEO of the Gold Coast City Council, Dale Dickson, after a study tour has elegantly described the philosophy behind the program, how it operates and what are the outcomes. I put it to members that there are many ways to skin a cat--and for cat lovers I do apologise for that turn of phrase; it is rhetorical. By using tickets we can cover both ends of the behavioural equation--that is both good and bad--to obtain a positive result.

I will get to the bad, but I cannot understand why a party that believes that its government is a committed reformist government would not merely suggest these positive ticketing programs when evidence from 53 countries that have used this approach shows that 93 per cent of offenders do not reoffend within the scheme. For those who are curious, I point out that the positive ticketing program initially targets disconnected and at-risk youth in the community. Its intention is to ensure that positive tickets would legitimately reinforce positive behaviour exhibited by youths by offering them something of value. Community partners in Vancouver are McDonald’s, which issues food coupons; the 7-Eleven group, which issues slurpee coupons, movie and entertainment passes; local councils, which give pool and ice rink passes; and theme parks. Local businesses donate. These tickets have on them the vital phone numbers for the Kids Help Line, drug information and health services. At the opposite end of the ticket equation, which is the punishment aspect, the issue of this punishment ticket can be seen in the same terms as tickets being issued when caught speeding by speed cameras. It raises concerns about easy revenue raising when members of the public have effectively very limited capacity to defend any claim that the police have made against them in these circumstances.

The bill provides for the capacity of the members of the public to have their right to be heard in a Magistrates Court. With 60 per cent of people appearing in the Magistrates Court on the summary offence of being a public nuisance and 97 per cent of those people either pleading guilty or being found guilty, in sporting terms their chances are dismal at best and hopeless at worst. On most occasions the alleged offender’s word against that of the law is not upheld. It is a no contest. No doubt there are too many of these offences being dealt with in the Magistrates Court and even the swearing-in of judicial registrars and the delivering of no new money--read we need to have these offences removed from the courts. Is that the correct legal process? I say that it is not and that these actions appear to be reinforcing negative steps in that direction.

Before government members start telling me that people who commit these offences of public nuisance and public urination should be fined and not dealt with by courts, let us look at some real examples. In my electorate of Gaven, we have bus drivers being given bus timetables by TransLink that date back to 1995 and earlier. Because of the tightness of the schedule, these poor drivers--male and female--have no time in the schedule in which to get to the toilet. A month ago, just outside my electorate boundary on the east-west bus route, which starts in my electorate, a bus driver had to go to the toilet. The council had locked the public toilet near one stop. It locks the toilets after seven o’clock at night because of vandalism. She was behind the bushes and was unfortunately interrupted by a group of people who did not realise the nature of the situation. They were offended by the public urination by this woman and the exposing of herself in public. After some considerable discussion by a variety of people involved, the police were not called. The staff union representative--
Ms Grace interjected.

Dr DOUGLAS: Unions have been involved. We have had extensive meetings over this. The situation is appalling. The lady involved is obviously blameless but, under this law, she is going to be guilty of public urination and should be fined and issued with a ticket. This is the issue that is raised by the Law Society and other members of the bar. When is public urination an offence? When is it inappropriate? I accept minors are exempt, but what of incontinent older men and women--in some cases not very old at all? I am sure most do not support a lot of those people urinating in all manner of places where it should not occur, but sometimes it is not their fault. There is nowhere else to go.

This bill is somewhat glib in its politics in that it is just knee-jerk and sounds like a good idea, where, in practical terms, it may be just a bit ridiculous. For those who then go on to say, ‘If the person is aggrieved, they can just refuse to pay the fine and go to court to explain their circumstances,’ I ask: who says that a magistrate will believe, in an environment light years away from a very small bush in the backblocks of Surfers Paradise--where my unfortunate lady bus driver had to go--that they are telling the truth? Do members really think that these honest, hardworking individuals should have to be inconvenienced both in time and financially and be subjected to the humiliation of stating their case in court? I strongly disagree that they should have to do so, and so will most members of the public. Clearly, to any sensible person, one would have to embrace the sensible change to the Summary Offences Act 2005--
A government member interjected.

Dr DOUGLAS: The member should just listen to this. Alastair MacAdam suggests that the Summary Offences Act 2005 be redrafted to provide that the offence of urinating in a public place is not committed unless the urination occurs in an indiscreet and offensive manner or, in other words, the introduction of a ‘without reasonable excuse’ element to the offence. He then states that, as the provision is currently worded, a person who urinates in the following circumstances would commit an offence for which there would be no defence. He goes on to give the example of a man with a prostate problem and someone who was denied entry to licensed premises to access the toilets because of a lockout, the public toilets being locked, and lists all the circumstances in between. Alastair MacAdam remains very concerned about the offence of wilful exposure. So do I and so do Surfside bus drivers, because they cannot use the toilets easily on the Gold Coast, especially at night. Honourable members, for too many to be fined $200 for urination in a public place is grossly unfair and takes no account of the difficulties that many have in both accessing toilets and controlling their own physiology.

I strongly believe it is discriminatory and I intend to write to both the minister and the Anti-Discrimination Commissioner on the issue of the discriminatory values of this offence. To then allow ‘SPER monster’ to try to take these people’s drivers licences if they refuse to pay the fine and then try to defend the fine in court after debating what is going on I think manifestly compounds the discrimination. I believe it renders the amendment unjust and impractical. We must never condone the passage of legislation that is unfairly weighted against those who are least able to defend themselves, that being everyone from the elderly to the poor, the homeless and, in some cases, pregnant women.
Mr Roberts: So you would be opposed to mandatory sentencing on this argument, then, wouldn’t you?
Dr DOUGLAS: No, I said I support it in circumstances, Minister. We can go into that, but this is about tickets.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order! Members should direct their comments through the chair.

Dr DOUGLAS: Examining the key part of this bill by working backwards shows that the amendment is inappropriate. It is poorly targeted. It is not proportionate. It is not transparent. It is therefore poor legislation and is unworthy of support.

By initially ignoring the balance of the use of tickets, a lopsided result eventuates. It is therefore inconsistent law. You might ask what happened here. I can only guess someone thought, ‘Gee, this is really a good idea. It is all just so simple.’ But life is somewhat different. Critically, there was no key stakeholder consultation beyond government agencies. The broader stakeholders the Police Union, which the government seems routinely to want to vilify, and the Law Society were excluded. It is no wonder they have a dismissive view of this bill. I think the comments of Michael Cope from the Queensland Council of Civil Liberties really say it all. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This will become the thing police slap on someone whenever they aren’t happy.
No-one will fight them and ultimately people who are homeless or young will bear the brunt of this.
XML.Hansard-Body: He referred to the powers being a concern when it comes to offensive language and that it would see public nuisance offence rates soar. I have to say that it increasingly looks like a cash grab under the pretence of a management step for public order. Since the government agencies are not an independent umpire on the fairness of these new changes if the key stakeholders were excluded, and they subsequently commented negatively on the legislation anyway, I suspect it is dead legislation and deservedly is headed for the scrap heap.

The two other key aspects of this bill relate to changes enabling the electronic assessment of criminal history records for employment screening purposes. This completes the link to CrimTrac’s National Police Checking Service support system. Sensibly, it protects the confidentiality of the information of an individual by restricting access by third parties. It may be that this is too restrictive and one might not have considered that a valid third party should be considered for access on the basis of security clearance in the national interest.

The change to the Prostitution Act 1999, and by default the Prostitution Licensing Authority, will primarily enable the PLA to deal with non-compliant operators who choose to not pay annual fees--there has been a variety of reasons raised; some seemed to have misunderstood that they were up annually rather than for three years--not turn up for hearings and refuse to comply. These changes have been dealt with today by the shadow minister. I do not intend to go much further than this. The compulsory powers regarding the behaviour of witnesses are interesting. The minister concludes with the statement--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: No offence is committed where the answering of the question or production of the documents or information would self-incriminate.
XML.Hansard-Body: In the twilight world of prostitution nearly everything that operators do might be deemed to be incriminating, so one might conclude from this that all witnesses might well claim the Australian equivalent of the US fifth amendment--that is, section 10 of the Queensland Evidence Act 1977. So could the changes be nearly as effective as the public urination offence? If this bill might be considered as a whole, I believe the answer is yes.

In conclusion, this is a relatively simple piece of legislation that has been drafted in such a manner that a critical part of it is both unjust and impractical. I have referred to it as a potential piece of dead legislation even before it begins. Parts 2 and 3 of the legislation are probably going to survive for reasons of practicality. Certainly parts of step 3 might not. This seems to juxtapose two opposing views of a being, presented here as a bill. Interestingly, the Shakespearean play Hamlet is often seen as the true father of existentialism that is the forerunner of humanist theory that forms a core philosophical basis of Labor policy. In Hamlet, the Prince of Denmark is very similar to the Premier--not one to broker disagreement when challenged and pining for love from anyone who would listen in a one-sided statement of position. The immortal line ‘To be, or not to be: that is the question’ could easily have been replaced here by the same base motives that Hamlet wanted to understand--that is, ‘To pee, or not to pee: that is the question’. Well, honourable members, unless we change the Summary Offences Act 2005 as well, all the advice to the punters must be, ‘Hang on, even if you are busting.’

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP)
(3.03 pm): I rise today to contribute to the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. As outlined in the explanatory notes, the objectives of the bill are to amend the current legislation of the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000, the Police Service Administration Act 1990 and the Prostitution Act 1999 and Prostitution Regulation 2000. The changes to the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 are designed to support the state-wide rollout of ticketing for public nuisance, public urination and associated offences brought about by recommendations of a report by the Crime and Misconduct Commission released in May 2008 titled Queensland’s public nuisance offences . The CMC found that 60 per cent of summary offences dealt with in the Magistrates Court were offences of public nuisance and that, of these, 97 per cent of defendants either pleaded guilty or were found guilty after they failed to appear in court. Following the recommendations from the CMC report, cabinet approved a 12-month trial of on-the-spot ticketing for public nuisance offences in addition to the existing powers to arrest or issue an offender with a notice to appear in court.

Evaluation of this trial has been undertaken by Griffith University, and their report concluded that tickets are a cost-effective means of dealing with public nuisance. During the trial period Griffith University also established that, of all the persons given tickets for nuisance offences, 46 per cent had no previous criminal history and that only one per cent actually contested their tickets before the courts. Public nuisance offences are quite common on the Gold Coast, particularly when there is an influx of visitors from outside the area. Schoolies and the V8 Supercars are two events where this issue appears to be more prevalent. However, the nightclub strip in Surfers Paradise is also a common location where police are forced to deal with public nuisance offences.

In fact, one does not have to go very far on any given night to see unruly behaviour in some of our local shopping and entertainment areas. That is why we have police beats at places like Robina Town Centre in my electorate. Whilst these reforms are welcomed and will potentially free up our hardworking police officers from dealing with these offences in a summarily efficacious manner, our police still need more resources to deal with this and other types of crimes on the Gold Coast. Public disorder has become a hallmark of Labor governments over the past 10 years and the Queensland courts previously have been overloaded with public nuisance type offences. Police have to contend with almost 1,000 of these offences every day of the year.

Residents of the Mudgeeraba electorate are well used to not having enough police resources to deal with these offences, and more often than not they do not even bother to report crimes as the so-called 24-hour police stations that we have in Mudgeeraba, Robina and Nerang close up shop from 4.30 pm to 8.30 am daily. Whilst we do have cars deployed in this area, residents hang up when they are patched through to Broadbeach and fail to record complaints, which in turn is used by the government often to hide behind the crime statistics for particular areas such as Mudgeeraba. As the government and the minister know full well, for every crime reported there are probably four hang-ups in frustration that are not recorded. It is these figures that the government uses to determine resourcing of our local areas with police and it is this government that has stretched the thin blue line increasingly more thin.

Our residents have been demanding an increase in local police and a 24-hour police station that is counter-manned. Last year in this House a petition with over 2,500 signatures for more police and increased counter services in Mudgeeraba and Nerang was tabled in parliament by the shadow minister for police, Vaughan Johnson MP, on behalf of me as the principal petitioner. That petition was not about taking another uniformed officer off the beat so that they can actually issue tickets such as these; it is more about more police for our area and about the public perception that no-one is home at these stations after 4 pm because no-one answers the phone. Residents would be far more likely to report criminal activity if they knew they were contacting their own station. Law and order is a huge issue in the Mudgeeraba electorate, which is evidenced by the number of signatures that were collected.

On the eve of the 2006 state election, this Labor government also promised us a new police station in Reedy Creek, which was quickly claimed by the former member in the dying days of the election campaign. Not only is this police station not in the electorate of Mudgeeraba, but this station will be policing half of he Gold Coast including Burleigh Heads, Varsity Lakes, Robina and Reedy Creek on the eastern and western sides of the M1. The state ratio of police per resident is 1 to 434 and on the Gold Coast it is about 1 per 628. In the electorate of Mudgeeraba, with 28,000 residents and currently 24 police shared between Nerang and Mudgeeraba station, the ratio is more like 1 per 1,166. The minister did confirm our suspicions in the Gold Coast Sun back in May 2009 that the 24-officer station will be staffed by 14 officers, who will be relocated from Palm Beach, Broadbeach and Mudgeeraba stations of which one will come from Mudgeeraba.

Unlike the Labor Party, the LNP has a ‘tough on crime attitude’. Labor is soft on crime. It has been soft on hooning and soft on graffiti. It has failed to stand up for the residents and police in providing a safer community for Mudgeeraba. Whilst the Liberal National Party will not be opposing this legislation, at least our overworked police officers will be able to issue on-the-spot fines instead of spending hours back at the station doing paperwork and preparing for court appearances when they, like the public, would prefer to be out on the beat protecting citizens and property as they were trained to do.
Interruption.

Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order! I would like to welcome to the gallery this afternoon the Hon. Mozammel Huq, Chairman of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Ministry of Land and delegation members from Bangladesh.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!
Resumed.

Mr KILBURN (Chatsworth--ALP) (3.10 pm): On 23 May 2008 a report by the Crime and Misconduct Commission titled Policing public order: A review of the public nuisance offence was tabled in parliament. The CMC report identified ticketing as a viable option for dealing with public nuisance behaviour.

In a direct response to the recommendations contained in the CMC report, the Bligh government initiated a 12-month trial, undertaken by the Queensland Police Service during 2009. The trial enabled the issuing of infringement notices for public nuisance, public urination and associated offences where persons obstructed or disobeyed a direction of a police officer in relation to the public nuisance or public urination offence. The trial was conducted in the Townsville and the South Brisbane police districts. This year the Griffith University evaluated the trial and its report concluded that infringement notices are, in fact, a cost effective means of dealing with public nuisance offences. It enables police to spend more time attending to operational duties and responding to the needs of the community rather than attending to paperwork and the preparation of court documents.

I was fortunate to see this firsthand when, as a member of the Law, Justice and Safety Committee, I travelled to a number of places around Queensland and observed the work of police during the night. Townsville was one of the places we went and we spoke to the local police about the difference in being able to issue an on-the-spot infringement notice compared to the lengthy time that would be taken away from operational duties if they had to return to the police station to deal with minor infringements. We saw this in action firsthand.

The evaluation found that 46 per cent of all persons ticketed during the trial had no previous criminal history. Public nuisance ticketing has the potential to divert persons away from entering the criminal justice system unnecessarily and reduces the necessity for those persons to be arrested and taken into police custody for relatively minor offences.

On 15 June 2010 the Premier announced that police statewide would be given the power to issue on-the-spot fines for public nuisance, public urination and associated offences. The ability for police statewide to issue these notices is in addition to the current actions available to police. It is important to note that this measure will not replace current practices; this is just giving police another option. I think the police are quite capable of working out which is the most useful or appropriate action. Other actions they have available to them include cautions, diversions, move-on directions, the issue of notices to appear and arrest.

The member for Gaven suggested that people need to be removed from an area to ensure safety. I am sure that in certain circumstances that is true. In fact, I witnessed that myself. However, after travelling around the state with the committee, I have quite a bit of faith that members of the QPS are well able to identify what is the most appropriate action to take. If QPS members feel that the most appropriate action is for the person to be removed, I am sure that is what they will do and they will not use the ticketing option. It is simply an option that they have. They will make the decision as to which option to use. It is always best that operational people make those operational decisions.

Currently, section 394 of the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 restricts the issuing of a ticket and the subsequent release of a person by a police officer receiving custody of a person arrested for public nuisance or associated offences to the prescribed areas of Townsville and South Brisbane.
