In support of the state-wide rollout of ticketing for public nuisance offences, this bill will amend section 394 of the PPRA to remove the provision which limits the issuing of tickets by watch-house police officers on behalf of the arresting officers to the prescribed area.

I also note the speech made by the member for Gaven about the bus driver who was forced to go behind a bush. I also have faith that the QPS is well able to identify the difference between a bus driver who happens to be caught out and who is hiding behind a bush and someone trying to write their name on a shopfront at 2 o’clock in the morning in the main street of Townsville. I am confident that they will use their discretion in that circumstance.

I will now talk about the prostitution amendments and the non-payment of annual fees. Prior to August 2007, brothel licences and approved manager certificates were valid for only one year. Following legislative amendments, licences and certificates are now valid for a period of three years. Although a licence or certificate is valid for three years, the annual licence fee and the annual licence return fee or an annual certificate fee and annual return fee are payable. Some licensees and approved managers have taken the position that, because they have a three-year licence or certificate, they should not be required to pay their annual fee. In the absence of disciplinary action by the Prostitution Licensing Authority to suspend the licence or certificate, a person may hold a valid licence or certificate without the payment of the relevant annual fees. In 2009-10 the PLA took disciplinary action in respect to three licensees and six approved managers for failing to lodge their annual returns and their associated annual fees. The taking of disciplinary action by the PLA is ill suited to the non-payment of annual fees by licensees.

This bill amends the Prostitution Act and the Prostitution Regulation to provide for the automatic suspension and cancellation of a licensee’s licence or approved manager’s certificate following the non-payment of annual fees. Where the annual fees are not paid by the anniversary date and the licensee or approved manager has not entered into a payment plan with the PLA, the amendments will enable an automatic 28-day suspension of brothel licence or approved manager’s certificate, the lifting of a suspension where all outstanding annual fees are paid during the suspension period, the lifting of a suspension where in exceptional circumstances a licensee or manager enters into a payment plan for the payment of the annual fee, and automatic cancellation of the licensee’s licence or the approved manager’s certificate if the annual fees are not paid within the suspension period or in accordance with the payment plan. This model is similar to that found in section 36L of the Liquor Regulation 2002 where non-payment of the licence fee results in the licensee having the licence suspended for 28 days and cancelled if the licence fee is not paid within the suspension period. In providing the PLA with a discretionary power to allow a licensee or manager to enter into a payment plan with the PLA in exceptional circumstances such as a natural disaster or where the brothel is damaged by fire, the bill provides the PLA with sufficient flexibility to address situations where it could be considered unjust to suspend the licence or certificate in the circumstances. The entering into a payment plan by the licensee or manager will be at the sole discretion of the PLA.
These amendments are considered effective, appropriate and the most efficient way to deal with the non-payment of annual fees. I commend the minister for the bill.

Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (3.18 pm): I rise to the speak to the Police Legislation Amendment Bill. I rise to speak in respect of these proposed amendments in the hope that they will go some way in assisting the poor, beleaguered police officers of Queensland to do their job with greater ease and efficiency. I also want to speak briefly regarding the prostitution industry in Queensland. There is a clear message here for the current state Labor government. During the last decade or so public disorder across Queensland on Labor’s watch has reached epidemic proportions. Police have to contend with almost 1,000 public nuisance offences every day of the year and Queensland courts are overloaded with public nuisance offences.

The Crime and Misconduct Commission has found that 60 per cent of summary offences dealt with in the Queensland Magistrates Court are offences of public nuisance. Of those, 97 per cent of defendants either pleaded guilty or were found guilty after they had failed to appear in court. Surely there has to be a better alternative than having all these non-felonious matters clog up the Magistrates Court. Following the 12-month trial on the issuing of on-the-spot fine infringement notices for public nuisance offences, the Griffith University evaluation trial concluded that on-the-spot fine infringement notices are a cost-effective means of dealing with public nuisance offences. Forty-six per cent of all persons who received an on-the-spot infringement notice had no previous criminal history and only one per cent of the fines contested before the court. The Griffith University evaluation has also found that the trial led to improved workload efficiencies for both the courts and the Police Service. On the face of it, the introduction of on-the-spot infringement notices for public nuisance offences seems a logical solution to having Queensland police tied up and our courts overflowing with the prosecution of those types of matters.
The bill also proposes to amend the Prostitution Act 1999 and the Prostitution Regulation 2000. The explanatory notes state that the amendments--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • allow for the automatic suspension and cancellation of a brothel licence or an approved manager’s certificate for non payment of annual fees;
• provide the Prostitution Licensing Authority (PLA) with a prescribed scheme for undertaking disciplinary inquiries; and
• provide for probity checking of persons seeking to be or who are appointed as a member or executive director of the PLA, or employment as a staff member of the PLA.
XML.Hansard-Body: While I know that this Labor government is broke, I believe there are more important things to be concerned about regarding the prostitution industry in Queensland than the non-payment of fees to the government, fee payment plans and associated punitive measures for punishing those who are late in paying those fees. In regard to probity checking for Prostitution Licensing Authority appointments and employment, the bill’s explanatory notes states, ‘These amendments will support the safety and security of clients and sex workers...’. The bill acknowledges the need to ensure the safety and security of sex workers and their clients. With that in mind, recently I was advised by people within the Queensland prostitution industry of some disturbing information regarding potential health risks to sex workers and their clients.

Last year, the Department of Health and Ageing within the federal government undertook to provide the funding to reprint a guide, in the form of a handbook, as a reference for sex workers across Australia. The handbook discusses the spectre of and gives advice about the prevention of sexually transmitted diseases within the prostitution industry. The book has been printed in four different languages. It is the sort of thing that we, as a proactive government, should be promoting. I am advised that the handbook is available to sex workers right across Australia, but not in Queensland. My advice to the minister is to seriously take this on board, because it gives us an opportunity to do a bit of good. I ask that the state government, through the Prostitution Licensing Authority, conduct an urgent review of this situation with a view to ensuring that the handbook is made available to all sex workers within Queensland.

Again I refer to the assertion in the explanatory notes to the bill in relation to the safety and security of sex workers and their clients in Queensland. I have been advised that there is a degree of uncertainty within the industry as to where workers should report criminal activities and potential risks. They are apprehensive as to whether to contact police or the PLA on the basis that they may want to divulge confidential information to an appropriate officer. That information could involve criminal activity, illegal prostitution operations, organised crime, immigration, health matters and instances of potential corruption. In this regard, I ask for the establishment of a number of dedicated liaison officers who can work as a first point of contact for sex workers. Those officers could come from within the PLA or the intelligence area of the Queensland Police Service. Initially, the officers could liaise with the industry across the Gold Coast, the north and south metropolitan areas of Brisbane and also the Sunshine Coast as a trial. It is said that prostitution is the oldest profession and, like it or not, it is here to stay. Real people work in the industry and real people are industry clients. They need appropriate support from this government.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (3.24 pm): This afternoon I rise to contribute to the Police Legislation Amendment Bill currently before the House. The bill amends the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000, the Police Service Administration Act 1990 and the Prostitution Act 1999. I concur with the sentiments and statements expressed by the shadow minister, the member for Gregory, in his speech this afternoon.

One element of the legislative amendment before the House relates to the policy of dealing with nuisance offences. Under Labor--and everyone in the House would agree with me--Queensland police have become bogged down having to deal with public nuisance offences, which takes valuable time away from more prominent cases and, effectively, clogs up our court systems. Between 2005 and 2008, public nuisance offences increased by almost 40 per cent. As the former minister for police, in 2008 the member for Sunnybank stated that police data shows that alcohol is the single highest causal factor for public nuisance offences and is involved in three-quarters of all cases. As I have stated in this place on many occasions, clearly the state Labor government of the past 12 years has totally lost control of our streets, particularly at night when alcohol is reported as the main cause of public nuisance. The rapid increase in the rate of public nuisance offences since the offence was created in 2003 is an indictment on Labor’s softly-softly approach to the general justice system of Queensland.

For every crime there needs to be a penalty that is an adequate deterrent for one not to commit the crime in the first instance. I believe that an on-the-spot fine for someone who is causing a public nuisance sends a stronger message than simply issuing a ticket with a court date some weeks down the track. If someone is being a public nuisance, the police will have the discretion of issuing on-the-spot fines, which should put a dampener on a big night out on the town. Every resident in Queensland should able to go out in the evening, or at any time of the day, and enjoy our great lifestyle with moderation, respect for others and respect for property. The trial that the government initiated last year in South Brisbane and Townsville provided for on-the-spot fines between $100 and $150 to be allocated to those committing acts of public nuisance.

A Crime and Misconduct Commission report, released in May 2008, recommended a major overhaul of public nuisance policing. The CMC report noted that the average fine that was issued by a Magistrates Court for a public nuisance offence was $100. The issuing of on-the-spot tickets should significantly decrease the caseload in our court system. However, we are yet to see what the impact will be of this new system on the problem of nonpayers. The CMC report also indicated that 60 per cent of the summary offences dealt with by the Magistrates Court were public nuisance offenders and that 97 per cent of those defendants pleaded guilty or were found guilty after they had to appear in court. The Griffith University was commissioned to provide a report on the 12-month trial period for on-the-spot fines for public nuisances. The Griffith report indicated that such tickets were a cost-effective means of dealing with public nuisance offences and led to improved workload efficiencies for the current court system and the Police Service.

Interestingly, consultation for this amendment was limited only to government agencies and it appears that no consultation was undertaken with broader stakeholder organisations such as the Law Society. However, I note that this morning in parliament a letter from a barrister from the Queensland University of Technology was tabled with one of the reports. I have great respect for the work that is undertaken by the men and women who serve as Queensland police officers and I dispute the claims made by the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties President, Michael Cope, who said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This will become the thing police just slap on someone whenever they aren’t happy.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He further stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: No one will fight them and ultimately people who are homeless or young will bear the brunt of this.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: On many occasions in this place in relation to issues of justice in Queensland I have said that I am sick and tired of people, including the civil liberty champions, using youth and other factors as an excuse to get away with certain deplorable acts that, as a society, we should not accept. People do have rights and people do have choices, but with those rights and choices comes responsibility. I say to all these loopy, leftie civil libertarian campaigners--and generally they are mostly those opposite--that you cannot contract out of your responsibilities in society.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Law, Justice and Safety Committee toured the state during its alcohol related violence inquiry. We toured the nightclubs at three in the morning. We toured the streets, as those members of the committee have indicated in this place before, and what we saw was appalling.
Ms Grace: Was not.

Mr BLEIJIE: I take the interjection from the member for Brisbane Central and note that the member for Brisbane Central is not on the Law, Justice and Safety Committee. So for her to be commenting on what we saw is probably a little out of place.
Ms Grace: I live there; you don’t.

Mr BLEIJIE: I take that interjection. I point out to the member for Brisbane Central, as she crossfires walking across the chamber, that it was the Law, Justice and Safety Committee that was charged by this parliament with conducting the alcohol related violence inquiry and, as part of that inquiry, we did tour the state and we did go out at 2 am, 3 am, 4 am and 5 am in places such as Rockhampton, Townsville, Cairns, the Sunshine Coast, the Brisbane CBD and Surfers Paradise. What we saw on the streets, as I said before, was absolutely appalling. Who are the ones who have to put up with all of this? It is the Queensland Police Service predominantly and the volunteers that we have on our streets. As I said, the loopy lefty civil libertarians would not have a clue what happens on our streets at that time of the morning.
Mr Watt interjected.

Mr BLEIJIE: They can issue press releases. They can say all they want. They can say that these people have all of these rights. What I would point out is that it comes back to personal responsibility. I do not accept the view taken by many opposite in this House that, because people are young and because of other varying factors, that gives them some form of excuse for getting away with what they are doing at that time of the morning. Ultimately, the amount of alcohol or drugs that one consumes is a choice for that individual. If that individual then goes down a path of what we see as becoming a public nuisance, then they should bear the responsibility. Throughout the last five minutes there have been many interjections from those opposite, particularly the member for Everton. I take those interjections. I note he will probably jump to his feet in a minute. I take the interjections as a sign that he of course does agree that because they are drunk or on drugs they have an excuse to get away with what they are doing.
Mr Watt: Yes, that’s exactly what I believe, isn’t it?
Mr BLEIJIE: Yes. That is exactly what he believes, and I note he did not take a point of order, so I will take it that what I said was factual.
Mr Dick: You wouldn’t want to verbal anyone.

Mr BLEIJIE: Let me take the interjection of the Attorney-General. Let me remind the Attorney-General that, if anyone in this place should know what it is like to verbal someone, then I certainly would think it is the Attorney-General.

Mr DICK: Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. That is a very disgraceful reflection on me. There is no substance to the allegation. I take personal offence. I ask the honourable member in his state of agitation to withdraw.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order! I ask the member for Kawana to withdraw his comments.

Mr BLEIJIE: I withdraw. I say to all of those civil libertarians--and they have certainly come out of the closet in the last 10 minutes--that they should go out at that time of the morning and see what is really happening on the streets because, for once in their life, they might stand up and fight for the rights and liberties of our fine policemen and policewomen who have to put up with this garbage happening that as a society we should be standing against. They put up with it every single day and night. I give more credit to the Queensland Police Service, who will no doubt recognise the appropriate discretionary obligations that they will have under these new arrangements.

The bill before the House also amends the Police Service Administration Act 1999 to enable the electronic assessment of criminal history records for employment screening purposes. The use of the electronic records provided to CrimTrac under the National Police Reference System will create a more efficient system of employment screening when seeking information on criminal history. There are still appropriate mechanisms in place to protect the release of information to a third party which could only be undertaken with the written consent of the person.

The other objective of the bill before the House deals with the regulatory provisions with respect to brothel licence obligations. The amendment to the Prostitution Act 1999 allows for the automatic 28-day suspension of a licence or an approved manager’s certificate on the nonpayment of their annual fees. Relevant provisions are made with respect to fee payment plans and any outstanding fees between the party or individual involved and the Prostitution Licensing Authority. The bill also includes amendments which provide relevant disciplinary proceedings undertaken by the Prostitution Licensing Authority. These measures are draconian but necessary to maintain a properly regulated industry that is conducted in an appropriate manner.

I will conclude by thanking the fine officers of the Caloundra, Kawana Waters and Sippy Downs police stations and the Kawana Waters Police Beat at Kawana Shoppingworld which conduct the majority of police work that is undertaken in the Kawana electorate. The men and women of these stations are a testament to the Queensland Police Service. I wish to place on the public record the outstanding way in which they conduct themselves in the Kawana community. With that, I once again endorse the comments made by the shadow minister in his speech on the second reading.

Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (3.35 pm): Today I rise to speak to the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, which seeks to amend three bills--the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000, the Police Service Administration Act 1990, the Prostitution Act 1990 and Prostitution Regulation 2000. This regulation should provide police with yet another tool in their arsenal when it comes to preserving good order in our community. I think those comments have been echoed on both sides of the House.

On-the-spot fines for certain offences--public nuisance, public urination and associated offences--can only be seen as a positive thing. While no-one condones those offences, this new strategy has the ability to save time for our officers, and I think that is vital. That is certainly the overriding reason why I am standing here. The officers will no longer need to leave their active duty or their front-line activities to process relatively minor offences. I can see that there will be significant time savings certainly for two of my communities that have only one police officer--they are the communities of Macleay Island and Russell Island, both of which are due to receive an extra officer for each island. The community has been very vocal. They have raised safety concerns for a long time on those southern Moreton Bay islands. They are greatly relieved that two officers will be posted there--one to each of the islands.
The on-the-spot trial has had some very mixed results. I quote from an article in the Courier-Mail by Anna Caldwell dating back to 16 June 2010, where she said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Thousands of people could be slapped with fines for offences that would never have attracted police attention in the past under sweeping reforms to police powers.
XML.Hansard-Body: I am pleased to say that the public commentary seems to be coming down on the side that this is a good idea, that this is a positive initiative, not only because of time saving but because police realise that their time is valuable and they cannot be running off arresting people for these relatively minor offences, but they are still important issues to be addressed.

During the trial period, 1,800 people were fined for urinating and being drunk and disorderly in public places in the two trial areas of Townsville and South Brisbane, but 1,200 have ignored the tickets. No doubt they will be caught up in the fullness of time. My concern is with the SPER process. I am on the record many times saying that I have great concerns that people could lose their licences and things of that order and not actually be aware of it happening through the SPER process. I have never been a fan of that process.
The comments in the blogs are quite interesting. I will share with the House some of the blogs that were posted on the article, as recorded by Anna Caldwell. They state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Since swearing and verbal abuse are not part of free speech, these powers are appropriate. As long as our right to free speech and orderly dissent is not undermined, this is a good policy.
This is a great idea--so long as its enforced.
yay good on anna bligh! love it! finally doing something useful
fantastic! finally something that will clean up the scum off our streets, good on you.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is a common thread throughout. So I think it is obviously a step in the right direction.
XML.Hansard-Body: Then we get the flip side of the argument which is about the nanny state or the nanna state. The blogs include: ‘Why does everyone want to live in the nanna state? I’m leaving here.’ and ‘Every year it is another law against life.’ I am editing these because some of the comments are colourful, to say the least. There was an interesting comment that I read from one submitter. They stated, ‘I hope Kevin’--and by Kevin they are referring to the former Prime Minister--‘does not come home to visit.’ As we know, Kevin has something of a reputation for a colourful turn of phrase.

The community expectation is that we should not have to suffer this obscenity every time we venture out in public--whether we are walking down the street or are in a shop, at the beach, at a concert or at schools et cetera. It is unacceptable. It seems to me that over the last many years we have gradually allowed our standards to be watered down. This is definitely a step in the right direction.

Some of the language used every day by people in public places is offensive. I am thinking now of the obscenities that children hear when walking down the street or when they are at a cinema or in a shopping centre. This type of thing is a step in the right direction.

Family values and a more harmonious community can come out of this if that law is exercised. Some of the comments posted on the blog were along the lines: ‘It’s got to be a step in the right direction.’, ‘Bringing them into line.’, ‘It’s a great thing as long as it is enforced.’ Those kinds of comments are being echoed through the community.

It is time efficient and it appears to be a cost-effective use of resources. There are three groups of thinking on this. There is the nanny state group, the revenue raiser group--which was a predictable line of comment--and the ‘at last the government is doing something’ group.

I can only echo the sentiments made by the shadow minister, the member for Gregory, and other members of the House on both sides in commending the police for the great work they do in very difficult circumstances. Over this last weekend a number of officers were working down at the Armor All Gold Coast 600. It was a perfect venue where these strategies could have been utilised. There were a significant number of arrests. There were incidents around the track and around the precinct.
Mr Reeves: Most of them were the same as happens week in and week out.

Mr DOWLING: I take the interjection. They made up part of the press recording of the Armor All Gold Coast 600. What I was going to say was that the police who were on site were doing a fantastic job. That was the point I was making, Minister. The police were a strong presence and they were enjoying the atmosphere of the crowd. It was a well managed event and a well managed crowd. I certainly enjoyed it.

That is the sort of event where we need to be vigilant. We need to ensure that we do not allow society to degrade any further. I again echo the comments of those members of the House who support the fine work of our police officers.

Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (3.43 pm): It is my pleasure to say a few words with respect to the Police Legislation Amendment Bill. I will address my remarks to probity checking with respect to the prostitution section of the bill. The current situation with respect to permissible criminal history disclosures does not reflect the integrity benchmarks required for appointment as members of the PLA, the Prostitution Licensing Authority, or to undertake the duties of the executive director or staff members of the PLA.

The PLA employs seven full-time staff members. Because the office is so small each officer assists in all areas of the PLA’s work from time to time and, therefore, has access to sensitive information including policing information on licensees and approved managers, financial details of brothels and meets with sex workers and members of the licensed sex industry.

The bill amends the PA to allow the minister to obtain and take into consideration a person’s full criminal history in determining their suitability and integrity to be appointed as a member of the PLA or to be appointed to the role of executive director. The bill amends the PA to enable the executive director of the PLA to obtain a person’s full criminal history in determining their suitability for employment as a staff member of the PLA.

The full criminal history information includes spent convictions, juvenile criminal history, pending charges and non-conviction charges, including acquittals and withdrawn charges, and is despite any other act which may restrict the disclosure of the criminal history information. Honourable members would be aware that on a number of occasions I have expressed concerns about some types of criminal history information being disseminated, particularly as it relates to spent convictions and mere charges and where charges have been withdrawn.

However, in the field of prostitution and areas where we have seen, through the revelations in the Fitzgerald inquiry, that the old vice squads and licensing squads were full up with corruption, I think it is an area where it is very important that people working in a public office in this area are beyond all doubt in terms of their integrity and their backgrounds. I believe that in this area it provides an exception to the general principle that I have subscribed to in any usual event.

These amendments will support the safety and security of clients and sex workers, ensure confidentiality of sensitive information and maintain public and client confidence in the integrity of the PLA. Importantly, the bill will reflect the principles of natural justice in circumstances where there is an intention to make an adverse decision in relation to the appointment or employment of a person as a result of the consideration of the full criminal history information. In such circumstances, the criminal history information is to be disclosed to the person and the person is to be provided with a reasonable opportunity to be heard and their response to be considered before finalising the decision as to the person’s appointment or employment. Furthermore, the Public Service officer will be able to appeal an adverse decision under chapter 7, part 1, division 1 of the PSA.

Additionally, the amendments only permit the criminal history checking of a person seeking employment or appointment with the PLA with their written consent. Furthermore, the amendments provide for the destruction of their criminal history records when they are no longer required and ensure confidentiality of criminal history reports by creating offences for the unauthorised disclosure of the information. I believe these provisions protect the rights of people seeking employment in that area, bearing in mind my earlier comments. However, it is always important that we be vigilant against any insidious trend towards the erosion of basic civil rights.

I place on the record my views with respect to public nuisance ticketing. I support the measures contained in the bill. They are consequential upon the CMC investigation into this matter some time ago. They will lead to efficiency from the police point of view and less embarrassing situations for members of the public who are caught in the types of situations described by previous speakers.

In terms of the amendments with respect to CrimTrac and the National Police Checking Service Support System, again I say that I have historically had reservations about the conveyance of information concerning a person’s criminal history depending on what that information might be. However, I am reassured that the amendments do not expand the nature of criminal history information which is ultimately released to a third party for employment screening purposes.

Finally, I want to place on record my appreciation for the sterling services provided to the state of Queensland by recently retired Assistant Commissioner Col McCallum of Toowoomba. He has provided a lifetime of service to the public of Queensland and the Police Service. He has had an outstanding career and is a highly regarded person now living in retirement in Toowoomba. He and his family will continue to be assets for our city. I also want to mention another Toowoomba resident in Tony Wright, who has just been promoted to the position of assistant commissioner. He again is a most promising police officer and highly respected by those within the force and the community generally. I wish him well in the important duties that he is undertaking for the benefit of the people of Queensland into the future.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (3.50 pm:) I rise to make a short contribution to the Police Legislation Amendment Bill before the House today and in relation to the issue of public order notifications. In particular, I refer to chapter 3 of the CMC publication in 2008 that dealt with the issue of public order issues and why they are important, and I will quote from that document in some detail. I recommend the document and that chapter in particular to members of the House when considering public order issues.

It was in 1982 that James Q Wilson and George Kelling published an article titled ‘Broken windows: the police and neighbourhood safety’. The authors claimed that public disorder offences sent a signal that there was a lack of control in an area which then resulted in greater crime. Page 16 of the publication by the CMC then quotes in some detail an article by Katz, Webb and Schaefer in 2001. I will read that into Hansard because it highlights what Wilson and Kelling were trying to put across. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Visible disorder, if left uncontrolled, heightens citizens’ fear of crime and leads them to fear that a neighbourhood is unsafe. After citizens begin to feel unsafe, they withdraw from the community, both physically and psychologically, by reducing their public presence and severing social ties with other residents ... After residents withdraw ... informal social control mechanisms break down. Residents are no longer present to supervise youths or others in the community who are prone to mischief and misbehaviour, and no longer feel a mutual responsibility to react to such behaviour ... As a consequence, more serious forms of disorder begin to materialise; eventually these lead to an increase in serious crime ... Intervention, according to the hypothesis, must occur at the first sign of disorder to prevent the neighbourhood from spiralling deeper into decline.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is said that that particular theory is what pushed the then mayor of New York, Rudolph Giuliani, and his police chief to campaign on what was called ‘reclaiming the streets’ and it was that that they claimed led to such success. However, whether the success of this approach is real has also been the subject of much debate. Issues such as social, economic and demographic changes and changes in policing may also have an impact and make a contribution. In fact, the report of the CMC quotes a study by Sampson and Raudenbush which found--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The relationship between public disorder and crime is spurious except perhaps for robbery.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The jury is still out on who is right--the initial authors or the authors who contest to the contrary--but what cannot be denied, and again referring to the document, is this quote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... fear of crime is very much higher in those Australian neighbourhoods where it is common for unruly young people to congregate.
XML.Hansard-Body: I do not think anybody in this House disputes the correlation between fear of crime and the perception of crime. They go hand in hand. Whether one is right or one is wrong is not for this House to debate today. However, the proposal in the bill is aimed at a quick resolution of a problem that has either perceptively or in actual fact plagued our streets for some considerable period of time and also assists in the reduction of police time in dealing with matters that may be called at the much lower end of the criminal scale. It also would relate to a reduction in court time in that courts would not need to deal with these matters in the numbers they are at this point in time.

As we know, the jurisdiction of the Magistrates Court has been enlarging in the recent past. The fact that the court has to deal with these matters places a greater onus on magistrates to act efficiently and equitably, and the issue of notices in these circumstances would provide to the courts a greater capacity to deal with what may be considered much more serious criminal matters. The ultimate test on whether or not this particular bill with regard to notices is successful will be whether or not there is a downward spiral in this type of offence, and I would assume that the minister will also in due course be publishing data which establishes whether or not that success can be gauged upon the number of tickets or notices issued over a period of four to five years.

I also join with the member for Toowoomba North in giving accolades to police in general for the great work that they do and in particular the work they do in the area of Caloundra. The police in Caloundra do a wonderful service. I was in contact with the acting superintendent not long ago, when the local council determined to pool those who are employed by the council to assist on Friday and weekend nights in relation to law and order issues by council officers. The police have now put in train what they call a Caloundra Support Unit, and that support unit is a group of five police officers who will deal on the weekends with issues that have in fact arisen in the past. In fact, I have been told that this unit will deal with issues involving public order. That is a great initiative because, as we know, tourist destinations, particularly in the Christmas period, are prone to face a greater number of public order issues. If police are seen on the beat and are seen taking care of those matters in such numbers, it is a great deterrent. In that regard I certainly give accolades to the police, and I ask the minister to pass on my congratulations to them for the work they do in keeping Caloundra safe. This of course is one initiative--
Mr Reeves: We often see the police around at Christmas time in Caloundra.

Mr McARDLE: I take the interjection by the minister. He is quite correct: the police do a phenomenal job in Caloundra and indeed right across the state. It is hopeful that the initiative contained within the bill will also alleviate the need for police to undertake onerous tasks in relation to paperwork and also assist the court by giving it time to spend on much more serious matters.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (3.56 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate on the Police Legislation Amendment Bill. It appears that the government may be starting to get the picture. Under its watch, public disorder and public nuisance have increasingly consumed the time and efforts of not only our tireless police officers but also our court system. Therefore, a ticketing approach to public nuisance associated offences is a step in the right direction. The rationale underlying the provision of on-the-spot fines as an alternative method of dealing with relatively minor offences committed predominantly in the course of non-criminal behaviour is a sound one.

This bill will allow police to allocate their resources and, most importantly, their time to more pertinent and onerous matters. Exposing those who commit these offences to the criminal justice system is unnecessary and unjustified both on economic grounds and on the grounds that those who have early exposure to the criminal justice system have a greater propensity to engage in other criminal activity, especially if they are part of a vulnerable demographic. Here the bill seeks to initiate a more proportionate response to this degree of offending. In relation to the amendments to the Police Service Administration Act 1999, the new use of CrimTrac will undoubtedly make the screening process more efficient by doing away with physical handling. I note that the bill also amends the Prostitution Act particularly with respect to the disciplinary processes within the Prostitution Licensing Authority.

Before I conclude this short contribution I want to reiterate comments made by members on both sides of the House confirming the fantastic work that police officers do throughout our state and certainly echo that for the electorate of Glass House. However, I would like to take this opportunity to ask the Minister for Police to fast-track the upgrade of the Maleny Police Station. He would be well aware that I have asked a question on notice on this matter and eagerly await his reply to that. As he also would be aware after having recently visited Maleny, the residents of Maleny were very successful in their call to have the number of officers servicing that great community increased. Where once we had two, we now have four. I and the community are extremely grateful for that, but we are concerned about the substandard accommodation. At present it is a couple of modified Queenslanders that barely catered for the two officers that we had there in the past and which are far from suitable for the increased police presence that we now have. I would ask the minister for police to reconsider the priority rating for any upgrade to the Maleny Police Station on these grounds and to bring forward the construction of a new facility within the community as a matter of some urgency.

Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP) (3.59 pm): The hallmark of 12 years of this Labor government is a court system that is overburdened, police officers who are overworked and a justice system that is overly lenient on criminals who commit serious crime. I welcome any move to free up the courts by introducing ticketing for public nuisance offences.

A Griffith University trial of the ticketing system found that 46 per cent of public nuisance offenders were first-time offenders and that people who had no criminal history and who happened to have a bad night out were overloading our court system. This legislation will unburden our congested court system from having to process the almost 1,000 public nuisance offences a day that officers across this state have to deal with. However, this legislation does not address the greater need for legislation that will protect those officers who will be responsible for enforcing the ticket system from members of the public who show a complete disrespect for those who enforce the rule of law in this state.

Our police officers are already overworked and are now being investigated for minor infractions. Yet this government continues to reject the need for greater protection for our officers through mandatory minimum sentencing to deter serious assaults on our police. The introduction of the ticketing system for public nuisance offences will improve the workload efficiencies of the courts and the Police Service. The deficiency in this legislation is that police officers will now be required to issue on-the-spot fines without the protection of mandatory minimum sentencing, deterring those who may respond in a violent manner.

It is vital that this government starts to acknowledge that it is not only the paperwork and the court time that is putting pressure on police officers but also the unnecessarily high risk of violent assault that they face in the course of their work. These men and women do an incredible job in protecting the public. They work long hours and are often unable to take holidays because of the recruitment crisis that is faced by the profession. That recruitment crisis can be attributed to the witch-hunt that we see daily in our media and the excessive risk of violent assault that this government has decided should be all in a day’s work for our police officers.

The need for more police is vitally important in townships like Moranbah, which is experiencing a massive expansion owing to the growth of the mining industry in that area. I say to the minister for police that Moranbah needs more police and better accommodation to attract police to go there. A lot of crime is not reported in that area because people believe that it is a waste of time reporting it as there are not enough police on the job there. We need to do something about the police numbers in that mining town. I bring this matter to the attention of the minister right now and I will put it in writing as well. I wanted to bring those issues to the attention of the House.

Ms STONE (Springwood--ALP) (4.02 pm): It is very clear that there is growing frustration and concern in the community about nuisance behaviour in our public places. That nuisance behaviour can be anything from foul language to urinating in public, unruly and rowdy behaviour, or behaviour that can be perceived as aggressive or intimidating. It has been well documented in research from around the world that this type of behaviour in a public place leads to a fear and a belief that a place is not safe. While that perception may be exaggerated in the minds of people, it still sends people a message of fear and of not being safe in their community. In turn, that fear affects people’s lifestyle, their quality of life and, for some, their health. There is no doubt that there is a point at which people expect police officers to step in and control that behaviour in a non-confronting way and to have some form of penalty to use if necessary. There is also a point at which the community believes that the line has been overstepped and that an arrest is the appropriate response. I believe that this bill meets community expectations and will allow police resources to be used more effectively. It gives discretion to police to make sure that an arrest is made if necessary, or, in this case, a ticket can be issued if the police believe that this is also the appropriate response.

Before the trial in 2009, I was approached by a security provider with concerns about the growing trend of urinating in public. He was also concerned about the use of police resources to respond to this offence. He worked in the Valley and believed that this type of behaviour was becoming notably more prevalent, especially during the late evenings and early mornings in and around nightclubs. One of the most disturbing stories he told me was about the actions of some people who urinated from balconies on people passing by and on security officers standing below. This security provider informed me that many security officers, club managers, staff and other business owners in the area were not calling the police to assist because they realised that it would tie up two police officers, with all the work that was needed to do something about this. They knew the police would need to arrest the offender, take them to the watch-house and complete all the other work that was necessarily in relation to the offence. They were concerned that these officers would be tied up dealing with this type of behaviour when they could be attending to other matters of a more concerning nature. In other words, nothing was being done.

This security provider and his colleagues are certainly in favour of the issuing of infringement notices and believe that those infringement notices will send a clear message to people that no longer will this behaviour be tolerated and that there will be a consequence in the form of a response to their actions. I have to say that I agree with him. When I have been out and about in some of the state’s late-hour closing entertainment precincts, it was very noticeable that no longer were people trying to find the dark laneway or a large tree where they could relieve themselves; they had no shame in urinating in public and just wherever they were would do. To be fair, I would also like to point out that many of the late-night entertainment trading areas did not have public toilets available for people to use. That is certainly a problem and that is why the Law, Justice and Safety Committee recommended that in drawing up management plans for entertainment precincts councils look at providing appropriate public amenities for the area. That is why that discretion is needed when dealing with public nuisance behaviour. I am pleased that the police will have the discretion by which to work out the best form of policing needed in the circumstances.

I know that the trials were held in Townsville and South Brisbane. I have to say that the member for Chatsworth and I witnessed quite a number of public nuisance offences in Townsville and spoke to the police on duty that night about them. They were certainly able to tell us their views about public nuisance ticketing.

One of the issues that has been brought up time and time again by certain people is a concern about vulnerable social groups and the ticketing process. Whilst the Griffith University evaluation of public nuisance ticketing highlighted that Indigenous people were up to 14 times more likely to be dealt with for public nuisance offences, the overrepresentation of Indigenous people did not increase with the issuing of tickets. The Queensland Police Service is engaged in a number of programs that are aimed at addressing the underlying causes of offending behaviour. The potential impact on disadvantaged groups is recognised and significant effort is being undertaken to engage with support agencies. I have to say that that was very noticeable to us in Townsville.

In implementing the state-wide rollout of public nuisance ticketing, the Queensland Police Service will focus on the use of existing policies to mitigate any unintended negative impacts on vulnerable people, including the referral of people to available support agencies and the de-escalation of police action in appropriate circumstances. When issuing an infringement notice, police officers will be required to provide an information sheet that will include details of relevant support agencies and services. That will provide an opportunity for disadvantaged people to obtain support, including seeking legal advice. Furthermore, the state-wide rollout of public nuisance ticketing will be subject to ongoing evaluation through a themed operational performance review on public order offending. The review will seek involvement by relevant government and community agencies. Additionally, the State Penalties Enforcement Registry has existing policies to mitigate the unintended impacts on vulnerable persons.

This new system will free up the court system by removing thousands of public nuisance offences each year. It will also mean that police will spend less time on court work and will be able to devote more time to policing work in the community. Inappropriate behaviour in public places is simply not acceptable and the rollout of public nuisance ticketing state-wide will mean that no matter where you are in Queensland, if you are caught doing the wrong thing you can receive an on-the-spot fine.

I want to thank the officers of the Queensland Police Service for their hard work and commitment to keeping our streets safe. The police in Logan City work very hard, and I particularly thank the officers in Slacks Creek and the Loganholme divisions. Unlike the member for Mudgeeraba, who believes that the officers in her electorate pack up at 4.30 pm, I know that the officers of the Slacks Creek and Loganholme 24-hour police stations in my area do no such thing. In fact, they are out in their cars doing what we ask them to do. They are out patrolling our streets, keeping us safe and responding to call-outs. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (4.08 pm): I rise to speak to the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. The explanatory notes to this bill state that the bill has three main objectives: to amend the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act to support the state-wide rollout of ticketing for public nuisance, public urination and associated offences; to amend the Police Service Administration Act to enable the Queensland Police Service to use the full criminal information provided to CrimTrac under the National Police Reference System for the assessment of the suitability of records, including the revival of spent convictions for employment screening purposes; and to amend the Prostitution Act 1999 and the Prostitution Regulation 2000.

There is a strong belief in Queensland that the laws relating to public nuisance offences are weak. Offenders end up with being issued with on-the-spot fines that are being ignored. According to a Sunday Mail article titled ‘Just a nuisance’ by Daniel Knowles, on-the-spot fines are not worth the paper they are written on, with two-thirds of the people who have been slapped with tickets for public nuisance ignoring them. The article states that a ticketing trial in Townsville and South Brisbane resulted in police issuing fines to approximately 1,800 people for urinating in public or being drunk and disorderly in public, but around 1,200 people ignored the tickets. However, despite that seemingly ineffective trial, the article notes that an internal police report says that police officers are keen to see the rollout of those extra powers just in time for schoolies week next month.

I support the police officers in this regard and will be voting to pass this legislation. However, I do have a few reservations that I would like to speak about today. One of those reservations relates to the Queensland Council of Civil Liberties. The council is critical of the laws and was adamant that it gives police too much power. It fears that fines of between $100 to $300 for swearing in public will be a major money spinner for the state and could become the weapon of choice for frustrated officers on the beat. In light of recent events, any legislation that sees an increase in public service power makes me reflect and think deeply about giving too much power to public service officers.

Speaking to this legislation has given me the opportunity to reflect on a book written by Geoffrey Robertson, The Statute of Liberty, in which the author makes a case for establishing an Australia-wide charter of civil rights, which may be a way of ensuring that individuals can better protect their rights from bureaucrats, whether it be police officers or other government officers, who overstep their good bounds and abuse their powers. I am thinking about the statute of Queensland liberties. I think that is a debate that would be welcomed by many members of this chamber--those in government, on the crossbenches and in the opposition.

One of the groups of people that will be affected by this legislation is Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. Unfortunately, the Indigenous community is overrepresented in our prisons for many offences. Many Indigenous people have gone and will go to court because of offences under the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act related to public nuisance, public urination and associated offences. The Indigenous community in Bundaberg has raised concerns over their lack of support from local police in Bundaberg and the Burnett. Their principal concern is not so much police officers themselves but the matter of resourcing and the situation that the underresourcing of police officers has brought about in their community.

Currently there is only one police liaison officer in the Bundaberg district. There is one position vacant at the moment. Respected community elder Auntie Lester states that this police liaison officer has in the past committed herself to the Indigenous community and assisted numerous members with issues that require police intervention. She has established a very positive rapport within the community. However, the community is not being able to access her at the times when this is most necessary. The police liaison officer is now forced to work day shifts, between the hours of 8 am and 4 pm or 9 am and 5 pm and only on weekdays. As members can imagine, issues that involve our Indigenous youth in offences that are described in the Police Legislation Amendment Bill occur mostly in the evenings and mostly over the weekend period.

Auntie Lester makes the point that for the police liaison officer to work weekends she has to justify why she is required to work these weekend shifts. The police liaison officers were often seen walking the streets of an evening and in the past have assisted not only the Indigenous community but also the Police Service with investigations. Auntie Lester goes on to explain the importance of having police liaison officers working late and weekend shifts and notes that police liaison officers throughout the state work late shifts on regular occasions, particularly in volatile areas such as the Brisbane CBD and Fortitude Valley. She also commends the work by police liaison officers in Cairns, Rockhampton and Townsville. As we have heard, there have been a number of trials conducted in both Townsville and South Brisbane in relation to this legislation. She says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In order to resolve the many and varied issues currently present in the Bundaberg area, we suggest that an appropriate person be appointed to the Cross Cultural role, someone who is genuine in their endeavours to assist the community.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Auntie Lester further notes that Queensland police should undertake further cultural awareness training. She says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Currently in Bundaberg there is no interaction occurring between the PLO and the community. We are constantly informed at our community meetings from the Superintendent/Inspector that the lack of funding which is apparently associated with the reason why PLOs are unable to work during the evening/weekend periods, when most youth who do come to police attention regular, are out and about. If we have been wrongly informed and the funds have been given for PLOs then where has it been utilised?
XML.Hansard-Body: The community is beginning to contact the elders requesting them to attend to incidents involving our youth at various times of the evening. This places the elders in a position where they could be assaulted and one that they should not be forced into. This is a sign that the community’s needs are not being met by the police and they are not comfortable to seek police assistance. This is a very serious issue.

Auntie Lester and her fellow Indigenous community members are fed up with not receiving the proper support that they require to address youth issues. They make the impassioned plea for an allocation of more police liaison officers for the Bundaberg police district. I have spoken to Auntie Lester on many occasions. She says that they would prefer four police liaison officers because those officers have to deal with not only the Bundaberg CBD but also the Bundaberg police district that goes out to Eidsvold, Monto and the like. We especially need more police liaison officers around the western areas of the Bundaberg-Burnett region. If we had more police liaison officers then I believe there would be fewer offences and less need to implement the powers that the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 gives our officers.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind)
(4.17 pm): It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise to participate in the debate on the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I do not intend to repeat what other members have said to date, but I note that this bill is simply, in my view, about trying to improve the efficiency of police operations in Queensland. I certainly support that 120 per cent. I note in particular that in his second reading speech the minister referred to amendments to section 10.2A of the Police Service Administration Act 1999. He stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The bill enables the Queensland Police Service to use the full criminal history information of a person, which is currently electronically provided to CrimTrac under the National Police Reference System, to assess the suitability of records for release, including the revival of spent convictions for criminal history employment screening purposes under CrimTrac’s National Police Checking Service Support System.
XML.Hansard-Body: I support that 120 per cent. What that is simply saying is that we can work more efficiently in the provision of this information and, more importantly, that our police minister and the Queensland Police Service are working in partnership with other police services around our great nation.

That leads me to the next issue. I ask the minister when he next meets with his interstate colleagues to try to see how we can also extend this efficiency drive, this more economical method of policing in Queensland. It is my view that if other police services in Australia are able to deliver their service more economically and containing similar checks and balances to those that we require in Queensland, maybe we need to follow their lead. In particular, I draw the minister’s attention to his recent answer to question on notice No. 1888 in which I asked about the issuing of telecommunication interception warrants. Unfortunately, it seems to me that in Queensland a massive bureaucracy is built around our Police Service that has to be paid for by the taxpayer. I understand our interstate colleagues are able to provide the same service without this massive bureaucracy. I ask the minister and the government to perhaps raise this issue at the next ministerial forum. How can we improve the level of policing in Queensland and simplify the process by following the good lead of our interstate colleagues? I refer members to the minister’s detailed answer to my question No. 1888. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs SCOTT (Woodridge--ALP) (4.20 pm): This bill, the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, has what I believe is a very important change to the operation of police when dealing with low-level incidents such as public drunkenness, urination in public, failure to obey a police direction, swearing, offensive behaviour and such. At the moment these offences will sometimes result in offenders spending a night at the watch-house and, ultimately, a court appearance. While a night in the watch-house may be all that is required to ensure a young person makes a firm resolve never to end up there again, nonetheless for others it may initiate them into a level of defying the law and possibly slipping into a higher level of crime.

When we consider the large number of revellers out in our entertainment precincts on any given night, particularly Friday and Saturday nights, these low-level crimes can occupy so much police time and divert them from other more urgent and important issues. It also requires extra paperwork by police and time involved in court action. This legislation will enable our police to write an infringement notice with a fine attached, thus saving a vast amount of court time. Our courts are busy places and taking up valuable time for people to appear before a magistrate to hand down a fine simply is not best practice. With this new regime, the only time our courts will be used is if a person wishes to contest a ticket given for an offence. Police will use their discretion and may revert to existing measures such as move-on powers, diversion, cautions or, if deemed necessary and of sufficient seriousness, arrest and charges.

In bringing this bill before the House, we are acting on the recommendation of the CMC in its review of public nuisance and its report, Policing public order . Following this recommendation, a successful 12-month trial was conducted in Townsville and South Brisbane, which was subsequently reviewed by Griffith University and received a positive report. While there may be some misgivings amongst certain people about the ease at which police may be able to write a ticket, I recall similar concerns expressed prior to the introduction of move-on powers which we gave to police. To my knowledge there has not been abuse of those powers.

Police who are at the front line of public law and order in this state do a fantastic job, often in the face of abominable behaviour on the part of drunken and drug affected people. All of our emergency services personnel are at risk when they attend volatile situations and when there are large crowds of people who have been consuming large quantities of alcohol, often with drugs also involved. It can be a very dangerous situation. The initiatives in this bill will give police yet another option and one which will have, as a result, time saving measures, both in policing and court time.

Other measures contained within this bill enable a far greater electronic search of a person’s criminal history when being assessed for employment and also the threat of suspension of a licence under the Prostitution Act for non-payment of annual fees. This bill will result in far greater efficiencies within our police department and court system. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (4.24 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate on the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, which was introduced by the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services, the honourable member for Nudgee, just last sitting on 5 October. This bill will amend the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000, the Police Service Administration Act 1990 and the Prostitution Act 1999 to achieve three specific aims. These are to expand ticketing for public nuisance offences state-wide, to allow for Queensland Police to use CrimTrac for assessments of suitability records to be used for employment screening and to implement changes to disciplinary processes within the Prostitution Licensing Authority. I shall contain my comments to the first two points mentioned.

Amendments to this bill are the result of a report by the Crime and Misconduct Commission titled Policing public order: A review of the public nuisance offence , which prompted a 12-month trial of issuing infringement notices for public nuisance offences in 2009. Griffith University was engaged to evaluate the trial, which took place in Townsville and South Brisbane police districts. They found that the issuing of on-the-spot fines was a more cost effective means of dealing with public nuisance and also freed up courts and police. According to the minister’s second reading speech, the rollout of the ticketing system state-wide will reduce the need for offenders to be taken into police custody for minor offences and enable police to spend less time on paperwork for public nuisance offenders and more time performing operational duties. The minister has also indicated that ongoing evaluation will occur through an operational performance review on public offender reporting 12 months after the state-wide implementation.

Unlike many definitions relating to provisions ensconced in legislation, it is surprisingly difficult to find exactly what amounts to ‘public nuisance’ as the offence is deliberately broad in definition, decided by an objective test considering time, place and circumstance of the behaviour. The Queensland Police Service mentioned some actions as examples of possible public nuisance offences in its submission to the CMC review. These include insulting behaviour such as verbal taunts, disorderly behaviour, destruction of property such as smashing beer bottles and general harassment of the public. Further, the CMC’s own review highlighted the following four broad categories: offensive language, offensive/indecent behaviour including public urination, threatening or violent behaviour and disorderly behaviour. In addition, kicking over bins and acting in an obstructive or threatening manner can be interpreted by police as public nuisance activities.

The LNP will not be opposing this bill. However, we do have some reservations, which have been addressed by my colleagues and in particular the shadow minister and honourable member for Gregory. No electorates in Queensland are immune from public nuisance offences and suburbs in Currumbin suffer from time to time with unacceptable behaviours from a small minority. Unfortunately, this is more frequent in licensed areas in entertainment precincts. Operation Cleanout, conducted in Coolangatta over 24 and 25 September this year, saw 27 arrests for charges from urinating in public to possessing a dangerous weapon--none, I might say, for violent crime. Police from Coolangatta, Palm Beach, Robina and the State Crime Command in Brisbane were involved.

Our police generally seem to welcome this legislation as it will give them more time to spend on the beat. However, some concerns have been raised that, while the ticketing system will work towards freeing up our courts, an increase in non-payment of fines could result in an overload of cases being referred to the State Penalty Enforcement Registry--SPER. A history of unpaid liquor SETONS and driving SETONS are an example of fines that tend not to be paid, particularly if they are imposed on young offenders.

Announcing this legislation in June this year, the minister encouraged police to take a zero tolerance approach--and not before time from this government with a soft on crime attitude that has allowed public disorder to become a hallmark of society over the past decade.

Police resources are stretched thin on the ground, especially when officers from our local stations are taken away for major events such as schoolies in Surfers Paradise. Given those circumstances, police in the Currumbin electorate have learned to be resourceful by working closely with the community, ensuring a strong relationship of cooperation and collaboration. The unique cross-border situation in my electorate also creates a greater and more difficult workload for our police. Special constable status is required to make arrests across the border in New South Wales. Following my call for the fast-tracking of special constable status earlier this year, the situation was greatly improved and now virtually all officers at the Coolangatta station have the necessary training and qualifications to perform their duties unhindered.

The layers of bureaucratic inefficiency forced on to the Queensland Police Service by successive Labor governments have long frustrated serving officers in our great state. That is why our volunteers in policing, VIPs, play such an important role in assisting police in their duties. VIPs work with police to address customer service, community safety and crime prevention needs in the community. In the Gold Coast district we have 44 VIPs. I had the pleasure of talking to the VIPs manning the Crime Stoppers van in Coolangatta during crime prevention month in October. VIPs do a fantastic job offering important information on crime prevention tips to the community and making sure our kids are aware of the need to be sensible and safe. I would like to thank Senior Sergeant Holly James of the Gold Coast district crime prevention office for her efforts in coordinating the VIPs program.

Two years ago I conducted an electorate-wide survey asking residents to list their key issues and things they would like to see improved in our local area. Over 3,000 people responded and the issues that were of greatest concern, by far, were hooning and graffiti. This result prompted me to start the Hoon Watch initiative, which provided residents with a simple form to record details of villains who were disturbing their peace. To date the response has been strong, despite the former minister for police criticising this popular initiative when I launched it. Disturbances in our neighbourhoods should not be tolerated and, whilst there is already legislation to deal with many of the issues, the provision for police to issue tickets will hopefully act as a deterrent.

I could not speak to this bill without taking the opportunity to talk about the great work of individual police in the Currumbin electorate. I was really sorry to learn that Superintendent Jim Keogh and Inspector Des Lacy will be leaving us to take up positions further north. Superintendent Keogh is moving to Wynnum and Inspector Lacy has accepted a new job in Brisbane. Both gentlemen have many years of police experience on the southern Gold Coast and were instrumental in several projects that benefited our community, such as the Southern Alliance, the Palm Beach Community Consultative Committee and several truancy operations. On behalf of the people of Currumbin, I wish them well in their new endeavours.

I also mention the acting inspector for the southern Gold Coast, Chris Ahearn. It is hoped that Chris will be placed permanently in this position to carry on the solid groundwork that his predecessors, Des Lacy and Jim Keogh, put in place. I acknowledge Constable Emily Tragis who was the winner of the most outstanding female practitioner at the recent Australasian Council of Women and Policing awards. Emily was recognised for her work with our youth and drug, alcohol and other problems in our community. She has done an amazing job in a very short space of time, and it is really great to see someone so worthy acknowledged for that. I welcome to our electorate Katrina Casaclang, who commenced work in Currumbin as our youth engagement officer. I also acknowledge Tony Unicomb and Kurt Foessell from the Elanora police beat. It is the ongoing efforts of all officers that have such a positive influence in our community. I am pleased to see before us today legislation that is designed to improve the working conditions of our police.

Mr RICKUSS (Lockyer--LNP) (4.34 pm): I rise to make a brief contribution to the Police Legislation Amendment Bill. I congratulate the police minister for bringing forward this bill. Recently in the Lockyer, a liquor industry action group was set up because, unfortunately, as many other speakers have said, it is around hotels and in the entertainment districts where these issues arise. The hotels have banded together to form a LIAG to assist the police in managing some of those issues.

I congratulate Sergeant Tom Messingham, Sergeant Jim McDonald and the team from Gatton. I acknowledge Sergeant Bernie Wilce, a long-serving Gatton police officer, and retired Sergeant Mick Brennan. They have all done a wonderful job of managing some of the issues in a growing community such as Gatton.
Mr Horan interjected.

Mr RICKUSS: Yes, Mick Brennan is a good tent pegger. I take the interjection from the member for Toowoomba South. Those sergeants have been involved in the community and it is pleasing to be able to acknowledge the wonderful job that they do to try to improve the situation involving public nuisance offences.

This is commonsense legislation, particularly when we remember that some public toilets are locked at midnight to save them from vandalism. Unfortunately, some business doorways suffer the consequences and the police or the business owners have to clean up the mess. Addressing the issue has been a long and onerous task. I have heard of the frustration felt when a judge gives an offender only a $50 fine and a slap on the wrist, yet the shop owner has spent half the morning cleaning up his doorway. They really do find that very frustrating. I have also given a few letters of reference to young fellows who have found themselves in those unfortunate situations.

I believe CrimTrac will improve policing. This is all good common sense. The police need all the assistance they can get. Public nuisance offences can be solved a lot quicker and easier than they are currently. Unfortunately, some young people think of it as an initiation to see what mischief they can get into in those sorts of events.

Mr MALONE (Mirani--LNP) (4.36 pm): I rise to support the shadow minister in his enunciation of our support for the bill and to congratulate him. The debate gives me an opportunity to speak about the great work being done by police officers in my community, right throughout the seat of Mirani, and to talk about some of the frustrations that they experience from time to time. I particularly mention Superintendent Rowan Bond of the Mackay police district and Acting Superintendent Graham Coleman from the Rockhampton police district. I acknowledge officers from right across the electorate such as St Lawrence’s Senior Sergeant Mick Hill and Mirani’s Senior Constable Fred Bagley. Fred does a great job. He has been a resident in the Mirani township for 15 or 20 years now, which is as great an example of community policing as you will see anywhere. I am sure that Fred would be able to find the culprit of a crime before the criminal even thought about doing it. We need to advocate strongly for community policing as we move forward with policing throughout our rural communities.

At Eton Senior Constable Gary Knack is a great operator, particularly on the busy Peak Downs Highway. I acknowledge Mount Morgan’s Sergeant Darren McLean, who is the acting officer in charge. Darren has had a very difficult time over some years now. When I first started representing the area of Mount Morgan, he had only two police officers in the town. I believe there are now six officers at Mount Morgan and they have the town under a pretty tight rein. They are able to do street walks late at night, which helps with juvenile crime. The issue of juvenile crime is a fairly big issue. At one time a particular juvenile, who was not yet 16 years old, had been taken to court 30 times. They would take the lad into custody and take him to the courthouse in Rockhampton, but basically he would be released and would almost beat them home to Mount Morgan. That happened on a regular basis. I am not sure that the legislation before the House this afternoon will rectify that situation. Certainly, it was a cause of huge frustration for the police at Mount Morgan. They have that under a certain amount of control, but juvenile crime will always be a huge drain on police officer resources throughout the community.

At Finch Hatton we have Sergeant Dan Graham, who has come back into the police force after retiring. It is good to see Dan back. At Marian we have Bill Feldman, who is the officer in charge there. Many members would remember Bill as a former member of parliament who represented a seat just north of here for quite some time. In the area where my electorate office is at Sarina we have a long-serving officer in Dave Parnell, John Black and Brian Cumming from the traffic police. They are just a few of the police officers whom I deal with on a regular basis throughout the electorate. There are many others whom I meet from time to time.

I have great respect for the work that the police officers do throughout the community. It is a very important role and it is very important from the aspect of the youth in our towns so that they can look up to and respect police officers. The vast majority of police officers I meet and the work they do in the community are exemplary. It was very unfortunate that we had that situation in the Whitsundays as it was not representative of the police I meet throughout my community. With those few words, I congratulate the minister in bringing the legislation forward and I particularly support the police who work in my electorate.

Mr HORAN (Toowoomba South--LNP) (4.41 pm): In speaking to this legislation, I want to make some comments about, firstly, what is being proposed with regard to ticketing. I think it is something that the police have wanted for some time. If we look at police numbers, the first major increases in Police Service numbers were made by Russell Cooper under the Borbidge government, when the coalition at that time introduced the new police academy at Townsville and introduced the system of ‘retreads’. That is, people who had been in other police forces were able to join the Queensland Police Service. We saw a big increase in numbers then. Although numbers have increased from what they were decades or generations ago, the amount of paperwork and process that police have to undertake now has become very substantial.
