In dealing with criminals--people committing violence and all sorts of other crimes--the police have to go through an unbelievable amount of process. That is the way it is in modern policing. Also, the criminals are warned that they do not have to answer. They can get legal advice. They do not have to answer any questions if they do not want to. For the police--who are being paid by the Queensland taxpayers to provide them with protection and to do their best endeavours to charge people, arrest people and have them committed to trial--in some ways the task is very, very difficult. There are a number of advantages for those who are the miscreants, whereas the police have to make sure that everything is taped and videoed and that all the proper warnings are given to the people who have been arrested.

I think any system that can look at the lower level of crime or misdemeanours and remove that process so that our police officers who are out there on the street and who are needed on the street can continue to be there is a good thing. Their presence is as important as what they do. Their presence alone can make streets, suburbs and towns safer. It is important that they are visible or that they are in the car and able to respond to traffic accidents, domestic violence and the myriad other things they may have to respond to.

A ticketing system would provide great efficiencies. Not only that, it would take away some of the work that may be building up before the lower courts. Also, it can be--and I am sure it will be--a deterrent. I think something like 60 demerit points apply in most cases that we are debating here this afternoon. For many people, particularly young people, that would be a serious deterrent from doing it again--the fact that they have been issued a ticket on the spot. They have had the scare, if you like. They have been pulled up by the police for what they are doing. The matter has been dealt with, and very often swift justice is fair justice. It has been dealt with on the spot while the offence is occurring or has occurred and the lesson, with the issuing of the ticket and the fine, should be salutary. You would hope it would be salutary and the lesson learned. They would not have the amount of dollars that they would have to pay and they would not want to do that again in the future.

I think that is a good system. There is always a need for checks and balances. Ticketing is limited to public nuisance type offences. I think it would certainly add strength to the move-on powers that police have. I have spoken about this before in the parliament. Again, they were brought in by Russell Cooper in quite a pioneering move under the Borbidge government, and successive governments have increased the move-on powers of police. There have always been certain checks and balances available with those powers. But where those move-on powers were once very restricted to certain areas, such as around schools or a hole-in-the-wall ATM, they have now been expanded to other areas.

If, for example, a party is out of control or kids are roaming the streets after a party and there is a risk of violence or risk of them being a nuisance--bashing letterboxes or threatening people in the street--I think a ticketing system would add great strength to the move-on powers. I would be interested for the minister to explain in his summing-up whether that is how it could apply as well. If they are being a nuisance in the streets in the suburbs and are told to move on but they do not move on, can a ticket then be issued straightaway? That is the sort of thing that we need. We have heard plenty of people talk about urinating in the streets. I think there is a lot more to public nuisance than that. I certainly think that would be of great benefit to the police and would add a bit more strength to what they are able to do. The move-on powers can now apply in a very wide range of circumstances. If there is a problem in a suburban street with a party getting out of control, it is important that the police are able to say, ‘Move on. Get out of here. There are other people who live in this street who are entitled to live in peace and safety. We require you to move on,’ and if they do not move on then they can issue a ticket. That would add to the strength of what the police are able to do.

In talking about violence, I want to commend a movement in Toowoomba called Toowooomba Says No To Violence. A number of the leading police officers in town are involved in that movement, particularly in speaking to community groups. A number of people throughout Toowoomba--members of parliament, leaders of business, leaders of the community--have signed up to it. It is where people endeavour to act as role models and spread the message throughout our city that violence is not on, particularly violence against women. So we endeavour to make our city a safer place, particularly for women.

I would like to commend Peter Rookas of the Toowoomba Hospital Foundation, who plays a major role in this movement of Toowoomba Says No To Violence. It is, if you like, quite a manly thing where many of the men and leaders of the city stand up and say, ‘We totally disagree with violence, particularly violence against women, and we want to make our families and our streets in our city safer places.’ The police play a wonderful role in that. I certainly believe that it pays great dividends in making our city a safer place.

The police in Toowoomba have a very busy job. It is a major police district and a large city. We have a court system in the city. There is a major highway through the city. There is a lot of activity for the police in our city. With the Warrego Highway going through the city we have a large number of trucks going through the city--I have spoken about this before--and that is a massive issue. Probably no other city in Australia has to deal with the thousands and thousands of B-doubles that come up the range and through the city. Consequently, there are traffic problems that can occur throughout the city. They have to go through 16 sets of traffic lights from the east and west--that is, coming up the range or traversing the western fall going out on to the Downs. There are a lot of traffic issues. The traffic police are exceptionally busy with that as well as the normal traffic issues faced by a large and growing city.

With regard to violence in the city, our rate of reported violence is about 12 per cent below the state average. I think the police should be commended for this. They have undertaken particular strategies for key times like Friday and Saturday nights when young people want to be out and enjoying themselves. It is an attempt to make the city safe so that young people can enjoy themselves. They put on extra police and employ good strategies.

Violence does still occur. No-one wants to see it. Credit has to be given where credit is due. The police have been able to get the level of violence in our major city to 12 per cent below the state average. We would like to see it at zero, but, being realistic, if we can be well below the state average it speaks volumes for the actions of senior police officers in terms of the strategies and, in particular, the young police officers who go out on the street and undertake what is, at times, very difficult work.

It is important that our police are backed up in a number of ways. It is very important that our police prosecutors are given the training and support they need in prosecuting matters. The police officers should have police prosecutors who provide the very best of backup for the hard work they do. If they have been out on night duty and made difficult arrests and sometimes dangerous arrests, when they go through the court system they need representation by prosecutors who are highly professional and well trained. That would give them the idea that they are going out and doing this difficult and dangerous work but they are getting backup all the way. I believe it is an important aspect of policing that our police prosecution service has adequate numbers and the officers have adequate professional training so that they are at the highest level. They are very often up against quite skilled barristers.

It is important also that the judiciary recognise the work that the police do and recognise that the police are working on behalf of the public of Queensland. There has to be a recognition of the public expectation. The worst thing we can have is a turnstile system of justice--that is, where people get parole after parole. The frustration that results is that those within the ranks of the Police Service say, ‘What is the point?’ Senior officers have to say to them, ‘You have to keep going and keep doing what you doing and eventually justice will prevail.’ I think it is important to always look at that. In the other portfolios where the selection of the judiciary occurs that selection must be made with the highest regard for values, ability and the recognition of public expectations and the work that police officers put in to see that the public are protected.

One of the great tasks of police all over Queensland, but particularly in Toowoomba, is their involvement with the PCYC. They do a wonderful job. For many young families and children in particular they provide a safe place for recreation in the geographic heart of the city. Many thousands of young kids avail themselves of the services of the PCYC. Probably the best thing they do is through leadership training. The young leaders in their teens are taken away to camp and come back and become leaders in their own right in the PCYC. It is wonderful to see.

That is an important aspect of policing. It is a part of community policing. Young people learn to belong to an organisation and to respect their trainers and managers in whatever sport they are undertaking. They learn to build-up within their sport to higher levels. They learn to become coaches and trainers in their own right. They learn to cooperate and belong to a club and they can potentially undertake leadership courses and become leaders at the PCYC. There are a number of police officers who work on the PCYC committee in addition to the wonderful police officer who runs the PCYC, Cam.

A big police station like Toowoomba has many services such as forensic services, communication services and detective services. I would like to commend the police for what they do. I think the proof of the pudding is in the eating when we see the figure for violence which is 12 per cent below the state level. That speaks volumes. Being a major centre, many of the recruits come to Toowoomba once they graduate. They do their first year of training outside of the police academy there. There is a requirement on many of the police officers to not only be out on the beat or in a patrol car but also to take a young constable with them who has just come out of the academy. Part of their training is the six months to 12 months at a major station under supervision. That requires extra effort and training, particularly when they are out on the streets at night.

I am very hopeful that the part of this bill that relates to ticketing can bring about efficiency and a level of swift justice at that low level of misdemeanour known as public nuisance, which will allow police to get on with their job and have maximum time out in their patrol car answering the calls that they get or being visible on the streets or at the community activities that take place. Their valuable time needs to be far better spent on policing and not on process.

Mr PITT (Mulgrave--ALP)
(4.57 pm): I rise to make a very brief contribution and give my support to the Police Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 introduced by Minister Neil Roberts last sitting. Some of my colleagues have covered the various elements contained in the bill, such as the power to issue on-the-spot fines for public nuisance, public urination and associated offences, which is hard to argue with--however, some of those opposite have attempted to do so whilst maintaining they support the bill.

I want to focus my remarks today on those sections that deal with the assessment of criminal history records for employment screening purposes. Section 10.2A of the Police Service Administration Act 1990 authorises the commissioner to disclose criminal history records, with the consent of the relevant person, to third parties for employment screening purposes via CrimTrac or another police service. Disclosure of criminal history records under this provision is subject to non-disclosure provisions of other acts, including the Criminal Law (Rehabilitation of Offenders) Act 1986.

The National Police Checking Service Support System, NSS, implemented nationally in May 2010, now provides the opportunity for a more efficient means of transferring criminal history information between police services. The previous inefficient process characterised by manually vetting and transferring records in hard copy by fax and courier has been replaced by an online vetting and electronic records transfer solution.

The implementation of NSS is, however, reliant on the ability of jurisdictions to reuse the full criminal history information data set the Queensland Police Service and other jurisdictions currently make available to the National Police Reference System. This removes the need for jurisdictions, including the Queensland Police Service, to send to CrimTrac and use two separate sets of criminal history information.

During the recent implementation of NSS the QPS identified a deficiency in the legislation that prevents the QPS from re-using the criminal history data the QPS currently electronically provides to the National Police Reference System for employment screening purposes--that is, secondary use. The QPS also identified that due to the operation of section 10.2E of the PSAA the transfer of records containing spent convictions information to other police services via NSS results in an unauthorised technical disclosure of criminal history information to CrimTrac as the administrator and broker of information via NSS. To allow for the full implementation of NSS by the Queensland Police Service and to take full advantage of the efficiencies associated with the electronic vetting and transfer of records between jurisdictions, Queensland Police Service vetting officers need the ability to manage, review, vet and transfer criminal history records from one system.

As such, the bill will remove legislative impediments in the Police Service Administration Act to enable the use of full criminal history information already provided to CrimTrac through the National Police Reference System for use in assessing criminal history records. The amendments will also authorise the technical disclosure of full criminal history information to CrimTrac in facilitating the brokering of vetted records between police services. The amendments will not change the requirements that the final disclosure of a person’s criminal history to a third party can only be undertaken with the person’s written consent and limited to current adult convictions. The new process will also enhance accountability through a data trail auditing function. In short, this bill seeks to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of the Queensland Police Service and in my view gets the balance right in terms of community safety and the rights of the individual. I commend the bill to the House.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (5.00 pm), in reply: I first take the opportunity of thanking all members for their support. Universally across the chamber members supported this bill and indeed made very positive comments about, in particular, the way in which their local police address law and order issues in their various electorates. At the outset I also want to thank the Police Service for the work that it has done in preparing the material for this bill and indeed also the Prostitution Licensing Authority for the very professional service it provided as well. A number of members have spoken about the way in which the Police Service responds in their communities. However, we should also acknowledge the often unseen work of the Prostitution Licensing Authority. It is not the most visible work that is undertaken within the community, but it is a very professional group of people who take their role very seriously. I pass on my thanks to them for the great work that they do in keeping this industry as clean as is humanly possible.

As members have identified, this bill provides a much more effective and efficient way of dealing with public nuisance offences and flows on from a recommendation in a CMC report which suggested that ticketing was a viable option for dealing with offences which, in the main, most people either do not go to court for or when they do get to court plead guilty. So a considerable amount of police time is taken up in preparing briefs and a considerable amount of court time is taken up in dealing with matters which, in the end, people are not contesting. Of course the safeguard always remains that if people feel aggrieved by the issuing of a ticket by a police officer the option of contesting the matter in the court still remains, and that is an important provision.

The government authorised a trial in Townsville and South Brisbane and a Griffith University evaluation found that public nuisance ticketing was a cost-effective means of dealing with this issue, and consequent to that the government of course now through this legislation will be enabling the Police Service to roll it out across the state. There are a couple of important points out of both the trial and the evaluation that I want to mention. Around 46 per cent of people ticketed had no previous criminal history, and this is one of the significant advantages of this bill. There are a large number of people who for whatever reason--a bit of silliness on an evening out--end up having a criminal record. It impacts on their future employment. It impacts on their ability sometimes to travel overseas. The consequences of sometimes one mistake can have quite a serious and significant impact on a person’s life. One of the real advantages to me, to many people in the community and indeed to members of this parliament of this arrangement is that this will enable police in appropriate cases to issue a ticket which then means that an individual is not drawn through the court process and having that recorded against their name.

The important point to note here is that this is just an additional option for police. All of the existing arrangements where police can arrest, issue a notice to appear, simply caution or move the person on still remain. This is an additional option which obviously will be used quite frequently, as the trial suggested, but those other options do still remain. As a number of members have pointed out, in addition to freeing up court time, this will enable officers to spend more time on the beat dealing with problem people, particularly in some of the hot spots across the state.

A couple of members raised the issue of the impact on vulnerable people, whether they be Indigenous people or people with mental health issues or other disabilities. Police are very conscious of that and indeed are making significant efforts to engage with appropriate service providers to ensure that where diversionary arrangements can be put in place they are pursued. There is no doubt that it is a legitimate question or concern for people to raise this issue about the impact on vulnerable people. As I have indicated, police are aware of that. Additionally, police officers will be required to provide a fact sheet when they issue a ticket which outlines services that people can access if needed. Additionally, members would be aware that the Police Service conducts a very rigorous operational performance review process where local policing activities are scrutinised and local officers and indeed leaders are held to account for the performance in their regions. After 12 months there will be a themed operational performance review on public order offences, so therefore the Police Service itself will focus attention on how appropriately these laws are being used. I am confident that with the training that will be provided and the intent of the Police Service to use them appropriately that is going to occur.

I will address a few particular issues that members have raised but, just to move on to other aspects of the bill, amendments to the Prostitution Act are basically threefold. The bill streamlines or puts in place a more clear process for disciplinary hearings that the Prostitution Licensing Authority can use. The act does not really contain that much guidance as to how disciplinary proceedings will be conducted at the moment, so the bill really provides a comprehensive outline of how disciplinary proceedings will be conducted, how people will be treated, what rights they have et cetera. In addition to that, obviously in terms of probity--and a number of members mentioned this--there is now the ability for the full criminal history of an individual who might be applying for an executive position or indeed employment within the Prostitution Licensing Authority to have that full criminal history taken into account.

One issue that is of concern is that some people within the industry do not believe that they should be paying their fees, whether it be licence fees or management fees, on time. In order to address that issue, the bill contains some very sensible and significant provisions which provide for the automatic suspension of a licence or a certificate where the payment is not made but also provides an opportunity for those people who have genuine reasons for exceptional circumstances to enter into a payment plan.

Just to give the House an indication about the way in which a number of people have been behaving, since 2008 in terms of brothel licences, of 66 licences 42 annual return fees were paid late in that period, with average days overdue of 35 days. Some 17 disciplinary inquiries were commenced in relation to those overdue fees. With respect to managers, of 166 some 101 annual return fees were paid late--61 per cent--and the average days overdue was 23 days and 41 disciplinary inquires were commenced. That is really unacceptable. The Prostitution Licensing Authority relies upon that cash flow. Any business that had to rely upon payments of that nature would obviously be taking action against those creditors, so this is a sensible way to send a very clear message to those in the industry that they need to pay on time. The other provisions relate to CrimTrac amendments, and those amendments will obviously provide a much more efficient means of dealing with criminal history screening. Currently because of the nature of the restrictions under the act, a lot of that exchange of information needs to occur manually and now it can be done electronically.

I will now address a few of the issues that were raised by individual members. Firstly, I thank the member for Gregory for his support for the bill. He actually described it as good legislation. I thank him for that. I think it is recognised universally that this bill will provide the police with very effective and useful powers. But importantly, the member made the point that it is going to keep a lot of people out of court who do not need to be there. Of course, we have courts and we have jails for people who deserve to be there, but in many circumstances people are committing that one offence--and I go back to that point that in the trial 46 per cent had no previous criminal history--but that recording against their name obviously can have a significant impact. So they can still get the penalty and justice is served. That is a benefit to those people who might just make one mistake in their lives.

Moving on to the amendments to the Prostitution Act, the member asked how many people do not pay. I think I have answered that by giving those figures. I think that indicates that it is a significant issue. But also, as did a number of other members, the member acknowledged the good work of the Police Service. I join with him in recognising that our police work under exceptionally difficult circumstances at times. I think anyone who observed the siege that took place in Brisbane yesterday would recognise that at times they are faced with some significant and awful scenarios. But they deal with them very professionally. I know that members in this House give the police their full support.

The member for Gaven started by saying that this bill was a sensible attempt to reduce the paper chase. In a sense, he was acknowledging that this bill will streamline the way in which police are able to conduct their duties in what is an area of great concern in the community--that is, public nuisance offences. But then he went on--and in a sense I was trying to follow his argument--and seemed to argue that, in the enforcement of some public nuisance offences, we need to take account of the particular services that people find themselves in. He used the example of a bus driver who had to relieve themselves behind a shed somewhere and who ultimately received a ticket. I agree with him: I think police will use their discretion. However, I did make the point--and he did take the interjection--that his argument seemed to be in direct contradiction to his party’s stance on mandatory sentencing. Under the policy pursued by the Liberal National Party with a number of offences, if you commit the offence then, no matter what the circumstances, you go to jail. So I find it a little bit difficult to understand how the member is arguing that particular point, which I agree with, but then stands up in this place and is prepared to support mandatory sentencing, which is his party’s policy in a range of areas.

The member for Mudgeeraba criticised the resourcing of police. I think she is leading with her chin on that issue, as a number of the members of the opposition do. I make the point that under this government police resources have increased significantly. The member for Toowoomba South raised the issue of increased police numbers under a former minister. I make the point--and these are figures that members will hear me quote on numerous occasions--that when the National Party was last in government there was one police officer for every 507 people. That ratio is now down to one police officer for every 434 people or thereabouts. That is a significant increase in police numbers. Crime rates are down. The average crime rate for all offences is down by around 20 per cent. Property offences are down by 40 per cent. I think the issue of police resourcing is one upon which the Liberal National Party is quite vulnerable. The resourcing that the Labor government has provided has enhanced the ability of the Police Service to significantly reduce crime. Again, in that regard I give all credit to the police for the work that they are doing.

The member for Chatsworth, in following on from the point made by the member for Gaven, made the point that police are able to distinguish between a person who genuinely might have to relieve themselves in certain situations and those who are committing a public nuisance offence. Certainly, there will always be grey areas where people may be aggrieved about the way in which they have been treated but, as I have indicated, people are entitled to challenge these tickets in court if they so desire and that right will not be taken away from them.

The member for Buderim raised a couple of issues in relation to the distribution of health information to sex workers. I make the point that the onus--and it is contained within the conditions of the licence issued to licence holders--is on the licence holders to provide sexual health information at licensed brothels. Of course, Queensland Health also provides information. The member also mentioned a publication that the Commonwealth government produces. I understand that some brothels may have that information available. It is their right to do that. But also an individual licence holder may choose to use other publications of Queensland Health or, indeed, other publications that other agencies produce as well.

The member also said that he felt there needed to be some dedicated way in which people who feel uncomfortable in raising matters directly with police about illegal activity can do that. In fact, they can do that now through a range of processes. Obviously, one is Crime Stoppers. People can ring Crime Stoppers at any time if they have information about illegal activity, whether that be prostitution, drugs or any other criminal activity. So people in the industry who might feel uncomfortable about presenting to a police station can call Crime Stoppers. Additionally, they do now contact the Prostitution Licensing Authority about illegal prostitution activities. In fact, in last financial year, out of the 70 complaints that were made directly to the Prostitution Licensing Authority 40 were about illegal prostitution activity. I think the member asked a valid question, but there are those opportunities now. People can go to the police. They can also report anonymously through Crime Stoppers or they can deal directly with the Prostitution Licensing Authority, and that is what a number of people have been doing.

The member for Redlands supported the ticketing on the basis that it would enable officers to have more time on the beat. The member for Toowoomba North focused on the probity issues relating to the PLA and recognised the strengthening of the criminal history screening processes through appropriate use of spent convictions. He also supported the principles of natural justice that will be applied, which means that, where that criminal history checking is to be undertaken, firstly, it must be with the consent of the individual involved and, secondly, they must be given an opportunity to see or know the information that has been presented about them and be given a reasonable opportunity to respond, if appropriate.

The member also referred to the recent retirement of Assistant Commissioner Col McCallum. I join with him in putting on the public record here my respect and appreciation on behalf of all Queenslanders, not just in his local community, for the work of Col McCallum. As the member for Toowoomba South acknowledges as well, Col McCallum has a spectacular policing career. He is well respected right across Queensland, within and without the service, and we certainly wish Col and his family all the best in his retirement.
Mr Johnson: Hear, hear!

Mr ROBERTS: I thank the member for Gregory and I also thank the member for Toowoomba South. I also recognise Assistant Commissioner Tony Wright, who has recently been promoted. He is also an outstanding officer and has received a well-deserved promotion--along, of course, with all the others who recently received promotions to assistant commissioner and, indeed, the new deputy commissioners as well.

The member for Caloundra talked about disorder issues and the good work that police are doing in the Caloundra area. I acknowledge the support given to the bill by the member for Glass House. He made some comments about the police station in his area. I recognise that the station is an old Queenslander, but the Police Service advises me that it meets the current requirements of the service there. But I thank him for recognising and acknowledging the extra two officers who have been placed into the Maleny community.

The member for Springwood spoke about the negative impacts of public nuisance behaviour in many communities and also the positive benefits of this legislation in freeing up police time. I also acknowledge the work that the member has undertaken as chair of the Law, Justice and Safety Committee in its inquiry into alcohol fuelled violence. Obviously through that inquiry her understanding of this issue was enhanced. Therefore, she would well recognise the benefits that this legislation, and particularly public nuisance ticketing, can provide.

The member for Burnett talked about the impact of this legislation on Indigenous communities. I have already touched on that matter. Obviously, in terms of the implementation of this legislation we need to be sure that any vulnerable people are catered for. Indigenous members of the community are highly represented under existing public nuisance laws and, indeed, under public nuisance ticketing. So obviously these laws are being applied against a higher proportion of Indigenous people than non-Indigenous people. Of course, police have a responsibility to ensure that those laws are applied appropriately. I do know that in many of the communities I have visited police do, where it is appropriate, actively engage in diversionary measures to refer people, whether they be Indigenous people or other vulnerable people, to appropriate support agencies.

I thank the member for Nicklin, and the member for Woodridge who followed on from the member for Nicklin, for their positive comments in support of the bill and for their support of their local police. The member for Currumbin spoke about the work undertaken by her local volunteers in policing and also her local police, as did the members for Lockyer and Mirani. The member for Mirani also talked about some issues in the Mount Morgan area. The issue of police numbers was raised by the member for Toowoomba South. He spoke positively about the bill so I do not want to be too harsh on him. Police numbers have increased significantly under the Labor government from when he sat around the cabinet table. He did ask a question about both the move-on powers and the public nuisance ticketing and whether they could be used together. In a sense they are two separate issues. The move-on is obviously a power of direction that can be used appropriately whenever the law is triggered and public nuisance ticketing is an actual offence. Whereas they are different in that sense, they may well be used in the same set of circumstances depending on the situation at hand.
Mr Horan: If they refuse to obey the order to move on then they can be ticketed.

Mr ROBERTS: If they refuse to obey an order to move on they are committing an offence. The public nuisance would be a separate offence. So they can work hand in hand. Police obviously need to use their discretion and use the powers appropriately. There is nothing to stop both powers being used concurrently or separately depending on the nature of each issue.

Finally, the member for Mulgrave spoke specifically about the CrimTrac amendments. I thank him for that. It will provide a much more efficient way of dealing with this issue. As has been indicated by a number of members, currently police are having to fax material between agencies rather than simply accessing the material which has already been downloaded or uploaded onto the site.

With those few words I again take the opportunity to thank all members, particularly the member for Gregory as the opposition spokesperson, for their support of this bill. I do believe that this will be of great benefit to police. I know from speaking to a lot of police on the beat that they feel this will enhance their capability to deal with an issue which is of concern to a number of communities. I commend the bill to the House.
Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

Resumed from 8 June (see p. 1862), on motion of Mr Lawlor--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr STEVENS (Mermaid Beach--LNP)
(5.23 pm): I rise to speak on the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Amendment Bill 2010. I would like to state that the opposition agrees with the intent of the bill but we have some concerns, which I will outline in my speech and through the clauses, regarding specific aspects of the bill that have come to our attention through our consultation processes. With Australia having the least affordable housing in the world this has seen a rise in people seeking alternative affordable accommodation and housing. People are opting to live in a variety of forms of housing. This has seen a growth in the manufactured homes industry and the caravan industry. The current legislation, the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act 2003, is being amended due to the growth in the industry and the need for certain protection to be in place for residents and owners of manufactured homes and caravan parks.

These amendments have come out of a review of the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act 2003 which the government has conducted and which was tabled in the parliament on 15 May 2008. The Review of the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act 2003 Outcome Report I must say is long overdue as the industry is a very fluid one and keeps changing due to the economic needs of the community.

According to the explanatory notes the objectives of the bill are to protect homeowners from unfair business practices; to enable homeowners, and prospective homeowners, to make informed choices by being fully aware of their rights and responsibilities in their relationship with park owners; to encourage the continued growth and viability of the residential parks industry; and to provide a clear regulatory framework to ensure certainty for the residential park industry in planning for future expansion. I believe future expansion is an important part of this legislation in protecting these manufactured homes parks and is an integral part of the residential choices that are available out there in the community. The objectives are also to increase certainty for converted caravan owners dwelling in these manufactured homes parks and to improve the presentation of site agreements.

I will now look at some of the major amendments contained within this bill. The first one looks at the protection of manufactured home owners’ rights. The Liberal National Party is strongly supportive of any initiatives and policies that protect the rights of individuals. In saying that, we mean the rights of all individuals whether they be the park resident or the park owner. Clause 4 seeks to amend section 4 of the act to include protecting manufactured home owners from unfair business practices while still encouraging growth of this very important industry. We have seen in some circumstances, as in all industries, unscrupulous business owners taking advantage of people who are honest and unaware and believe others at their face value. Obviously Kevin Rudd believed what Julia Gillard was saying to his face but was unaware of what his deputy was saying behind his back. This can be the case in certain circumstances with manufactured home park owners and also, to some extent, the residents of these parks. However, no amount of legislation or education can completely eradicate unscrupulous operators so every opportunity should be taken to prosecute those leeches who take advantage of a section of society who in many cases are doing it tough.

The next significant amendment to the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act 2003 is to do with converted caravans. A converted caravan is a caravan that has had its original design changed and altered structurally with an addition or modification so that it is no longer classified as a standard caravan. As we are all aware, this manufactured homes act specifically does not apply to caravans. With the conversion from a caravan to a converted caravan--and it is very technical to understand completely the amount of work that goes into it going from a non-complying tenancy, if you like, to a complying tenancy under this act--it should be still classified as a caravan and not as a manufactured home. Under the legislation there are a whole different set of regulations needed for the construction of a manufactured home to qualify as a relocatable home under the manufactured homes act.

This type of housing has come about out of a need for affordable housing combined with the want of people to have the ability for mobile home and holiday alternatives. The development of caravans emerged from humble beginnings. As we all know, a travel trailer or caravan towed behind a vehicle provides a place to sleep that is more comfortable and protected than a tent. Of course, tent by definition is also excluded from the manufactured homes act. We all enjoy these sorts of holidays, especially in our beautiful state of Queensland where Australia shines and is famous for fun.

The caravans had its origins in Europe when travelling Romani gypsies moved from place to place to entertain town folk. This is where the phrase ‘no fixed address’ came from. The world’s first leisure trailer was built by the Bristol Carriage Company in 1880 and was an 18-foot design based upon Bible wagons of the time. The minister would be very familiar with those wagons. From those early days they developed into the variety of mobile accommodation we see today such as caravans, camper trailers, travel trailers, motor homes, pop-up trailers and fifth-wheel trailers. All are classified as either RVs--recreation vehicles--or mobile homes and some can be as well equipped as a standard house.

I remember well when the legislation for manufactured home parks came into being through a former member for Nerang. I had just joined council in 1988 and the then member for Nerang, Tom Hynd, had quite a few residents from Carrara in what has turned out in the 22 years that have passed to be the best real estate on the Gold Coast involved in the first sale of manufactured homes. There were many difficulties with the owners of those parks at that time and Tom Hynd took it upon himself to bring their plight into the parliament. First of all, he issued a green paper and then followed it up with the introduction of legislation into this House which saw those home dwellers afforded some protection in the vein of what was originally intended, which was a permanent dwelling place on a site that they rented from the park owners. As I recall, at that particular time the park owners had a different intention, which was to let that particular park sit there and have people pay them rent until the time came when they would undertake some lucrative redevelopment of the property in the form of a highrise or some other tourist development down on the Nerang River. They would then have been able to move the tenants out of that park. However, the legislation that came forward gave those people certainty in life. I knew quite a few of them; they were in the Nerang PCYC. Quite clearly, those people were sold a different story to what was intended. Through that original legislation--it has obviously been amended since--we have come to the amendments that we see today.

We are talking about quite a large sector of Queensland society. There are something like 15,000 unit owners around Queensland. It is very much an area for dispute. It is very much an area for further clarification. I have no doubt that we will see further amendments to this act coming through. I certainly congratulate the minister on moving forward, to borrow a good Labor Party term, in bringing these amendments into this House. We have had quite a few submissions from affected groups, both from the park residents and also from the owners of those parks, as to how the legislation before the House did not go far enough in many areas and expressing different views on which way it should have gone.

The two industries--the mobile homes industry and the recreational vehicle and caravanning industry--developed and the legislation today is focused on manufactured homes that are permanent structures that can be relocated if necessary. Manufactured home parks have become increasingly popular over the last 10 years and as times get tougher as we go forward in this century we may see more demand for this type of living. That is why it is increasingly important that we make these private parks workable in terms of the park owners whilst protecting the rights of the residents of those parks.

The virtues of manufactured home parks include their light infrastructure, low ecological footprint, minimal land disturbance, abundant permeable surfaces for stormwater drainage and ease of site restorations and, of course, their affordability. Living in a manufactured home park with provisions for community facilities is becoming popular with residents because they enjoy the extra benefits of this community living including recreational facilities such as pools, community halls and other shared facilities that all residents can utilise in a shared capacity but that on an individual basis would be far out of the reach of those individual park dwellers.

The definition of a manufactured home is one that is constructed almost entirely in a factory. The house is placed on a steel chassis and transported to the building site. The wheels can be removed but the chassis stays in place. A manufactured home can come in many different sizes and shapes. It may be a simple, one-storey mobile home or it could be so large and complex that you might not guess that it was constructed off site. In section 10 of the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act 2003 a manufactured home is defined as a structure other than a caravan or tent that has the character of a dwelling house, is designed to be able to be moved from one position to another and is not permanently attached to the land.

Clause 6 amends section 10 to say that a manufactured home does not include a converted caravan. However, if the owner and park owner agree then a converted caravan can be considered a manufactured home for the act’s purposes and they can enter into a site agreement governed by the act. This is a mutual benefit agreement that is covered in the amendments coming through to the 2003 act. Clause 7 inserts new section 10A, which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A converted caravan is a structure that--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) as originally designed, was a caravan; and
(b) is no longer a caravan because of a structural addition or structural alteration.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That alteration by structural addition obviously turns it into a manufactured home. One must mention here that ‘squareline’ caravans must come under this definition even though they are a different shape to a standard caravan.
XML.Hansard-Body: I now move to the issue of site agreements, which is the subject of much discontent and unease by the parties who enter into them. Hopefully, this legislation will go some way to easing the concerns. Site agreements are contractual arrangements between the owners of a park and the residents of a park. Site agreements are important for the smooth operation of the park business. Clause 8 inserts section 14A to define a site agreement, which is a dispute about whether a park owner or a person can enter into a site agreement under the act, except if the dispute is about a converted caravan site agreement or a dispute about the party’s rights and obligations under the agreement or this act. There needs to be contractual certainty for all parties involved, and I believe this bill moves towards improvements in this area.

Another amendment in the bill relates to the presentation of site agreements. Clause 9 amends section 25 to include new requirements to improve the presentation of site agreements. It states that they should--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) be easily legible; and
(b) if it is produced by any mechanical or electronic means, for example, by a typewriter or computer--be in at least 12 point font--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: which I will still need my glasses to read--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (c) be written in a precise way; and
(d) be clearly expressed in plain language--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The minister might be able to help me in his summing-up to identify what he means by ‘plain language’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Lawlor: Don’t you understand plain language?
Mr STEVENS: Not coming from the minister. I thank the minister for the interjection. It goes on--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (e) precisely identify the site; and
(f) state each party’s name and address; and
(g) state a phone number, if any, of the home owner--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: park manager or park owner. Clause 9 also states that the tribunal may make an order increasing or reducing the site rent on application of the homeowner or park owner.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 10 inserts section 25A, which states that a homeowner may apply to the tribunal to argue that a site agreement is not written in accordance with the requirements. It may have excessively long sentences, clauses or paragraphs; it may have unnecessary use of technical terms, jargon or language other than plain English, which the minister has committed to explaining to me; there may be extensive cross-referencing, failure to define key terms, excessive definition of terms, particularly in relation to commonly used words; important terms may be buried in fine print or schedules; or there may be terms that place the homeowner at an unfair disadvantage because he or she is not clear about their meaning even if their meaning could be determined by a legal practitioner. The LNP believes any disadvantage to the consumer should be remedied with these amendments, but the act could have gone further. I look forward to future amendments that do just that.

I now turn to the prohibited conditions on site agreements. Clause 10 inserts section 25B, which prohibits certain park rules or terms imposed on site agreements. The prohibited practices include that a regulation may prohibit a stated type of special term in a site agreement or a stated type of park rule; a park owner must not include a special term in a site agreement or park rule that is prohibited from being in a site agreement under the first prohibition above; a park owner must not attempt to enforce a special term in a site agreement or a park rule that is prohibited from being in a site agreement under the first prohibition in the aforementioned sentence.

But what is a special term? A prohibited term is void in a site agreement. A homeowner may apply to the tribunal to decide whether part or all of a stated term in the site agreement is void. On application, the tribunal may declare that a stated term in the site agreement is void or not void, declare that a stated term in the site agreement is void to a stated extent or make an order varying the stated term of the site agreement. I presume that the tribunal will consider the rights of the individual when deciding on the implementation of site agreements for residents.

Clause 11 amends section 36 to prevent fixed-term site agreements. Park owners must not enter into a fixed-term site agreement or vary a site agreement to include a term under which the parties to the site agreement agree to terminate the site agreement. If the park owner does this, then the term is void. Clause 12 amends section 38, ensuring a site agreement cannot be terminated on the basis that the homeowner is not using the home as their principle place of residence. This will allow for manufactured homes to be used as investment properties as long as they have a residential tenant in that property. I believe this is a very appropriate amendment.

Consultation has been a focus of the opposition’s analysis of the bill. We have found that manufactured home owners are concerned about their rights and whether the protection in this bill goes far enough. We have attended the government’s community consultation processes, which I must say has been undertaken far and wide over a reasonable period to give all participants the opportunity to have input. I attended the Runaway Bay consultation meeting that government officers conducted. At that meeting it was notable that consensus was completely absent. However, everybody had the opportunity to put forward their views on the matter. There would have been almost as many different views on what was a proper outcome for this legislation as there were people at the meeting. I was informed that the Beenleigh meeting was also very successful. Meetings were held as far north as Mackay. I am not too sure if they went to Townsville or Cairns in North Queensland.

In its examinations of the bill, the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee noted that considerable consultation was conducted by the government prior to introducing the bill, but that concerns were still evident within the community. The consultation process included a discussion paper and survey, a series of round table conferences, the release of a draft version of the bill in 2009 and the holding of a consultation forum. Residents and park owners, through their association, have raised with the opposition issues that we do not believe the legislation addresses. I will go through those as I discuss the amendments. In terms of industry and community stakeholders, the caravan park owners association has several concerns, including the three-year moratorium period before the converted caravan amendments commence.
Mr Ryan interjected.

Mr STEVENS: Certainly it is to them. I take the interjection of the member for Morayfield. It allows for the owner of a converted caravan the opportunity to apply to the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal, QCAT, to have the converted caravan reclassified as a manufactured home. This begs the question that if it is a converted caravan now, should it be precluded from protection under this particular legislation? Why have three years of litigation to say yes or no? In relation to the site agreements, and as I mentioned to the minister, stakeholders are concerned about the meaning of ‘plain language’. The act gives no guidance to explain it, which certainly creates uncertainty. High on the list of concerns about the legislation was the potential flood of applications to QCAT. Quite clearly, QCAT is already under severe pressure from other areas of legislation and they believe that this legislation will give rise to many more disputes for QCAT to settle. Therefore, they are concerned that QCAT be given enough resources and support from the government to deal with all those matters. They believe that that question will only be answered in time after the enactment of the legislation. A concern was raised that the prohibited special terms are retrospective, which will have major implications. Once they are retrospective, one would think many people will go to QCAT to satisfy disputes from times gone by. Prohibitive agreements will also be retrospective.

The site rent provisions impinge on the park owners’ rights to increase rent, which can only be done in line with increases in the CPI. Stakeholders argue that rent should be increased not only in relation to the consumer price index, because other specific costs that relate directly to the parks themselves may be much higher. For example, the recent massive rises in the price of electricity, water and fuel impact on operating parks and are well and truly above the CPI. If the operation of a park becomes unaffordable because the park owner is not able to get reasonable and fair recoupment of the costs, they will sell the park. The park could then change entirely in terms of operation. That would mean less of this type of residential property on the market for people to take advantage of.

QCAT can postpone the termination of a site agreement for up to one year, which causes uncertainty with any proposed development the park owner might be intending to do. In this day and age, contracts are particularly time important. Stakeholders felt it very unreasonable for QCAT to be able to delay a termination by that length of time.

Clause 24 inserts new section 74A, which prohibits park owners from threatening, intimidating or coercing park residents. The concern raised with this matter is that the penalty for the offence can be up to $20,000 and one person’s harsh words may be taken by another person as a heavy threat. They wonder what part of $20,000 will they be liable for in terms of the adjudication through QCAT.

Park residents are concerned that if they have to move to another site there may not be one available. That is particularly relevant for some isolated park areas. There is only limited compensation for relocation costs to a park within 300 kilometres, as I recall. That is okay if there is another park to relocate to within 300 kilometres, but in some areas there may not be a park available. Residents are worried that the bill does not address their issues in terms of relocation.

The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee analysis of the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Amendment Bill in its Legislation Alert No. 8 of 2010 explored concerns and issues regarding rights and liberties of individuals. The committee believes that in clauses 6 and 8, as I covered in my speech, it is to do with the definition of a manufactured home, and it is not a converted caravan. The committee went on to say that clause 20 may affect rights of park owners and that clauses 10-1, 17-8, 24-6, 29, 31 and 33 have the potential to affect rights and liberties of individuals in that they would create new penalties under the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act. I think that was clearly the intent when the legislation was designed.

In clause 10, if a park owner makes a park rule that is prohibited he is up for 100 penalty units, which is $10,000. In clause 11, if a park owner enters into a prohibited agreement he is up for a penalty of up to $20,000. These are very significant fines. In clause 17, if a park owner refuses to consent to assignment of a seller’s interest he is up for 20 penalty units, which is a $2,000 fine. Clause 18 provides for a $10,000 fine. Clause 24 provides for a $20,000 fine. The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee went on to say that clauses 10, 11 and 33 may adversely affect rights and liberties retrospectively. Clause 10 may also provide for inappropriate delegations of legislative power.

From a philosophical point of view, and as we speak to residents of the manufactured home parks, quite clearly they are a disjointed group. They have no lead agency, no one representative body. In fact, even the legislation clearly directs residents within manufactured home parks to have one voice to speak to the park owners in terms of disputes and in trying to regulate and keep down the number of different views, as I have said before, that the park residents have.

The parks are spread throughout Queensland. We have quite a few on the Gold Coast, the north coast and the central coast, particularly around Hervey Bay--those sorts of areas. They really need to combine to have a single voice to negotiate with governments on their behalf. Quite clearly, the residents whom we from the LNP spoke to felt disenfranchised. A lot of them are pensioners. A lot of them are doing it particularly tough. There were many comments in relation to the four per cent increase in pension payments not being enough to cover the increase in site rental agreements.
Mr Ryan: How much did they get under Howard?
Mrs Sullivan: They got nothing under Howard. They lived in tents under Howard.
Mr STEVENS: It was still not enough to cover the increase in their site rentals.
Mrs Sullivan: It is never enough.

Mr STEVENS: I understand how some members in the Labor Party do not understand the plight of pensioners and are ready to put them down. I heard the comment that it is never enough, that pensioners are always on about ‘never enough’. As a matter of fact, I inform members of the Labor Party on the government benches that I happen to have a brother who has joined the pensioner ranks. Quite clearly, he is not living like a king and able to afford high increases that the Labor government feels pensioners can cope with.

I would like to put on record in this House that quite clearly pensioners need to be looked after. The great majority of residential tenancies in manufactured home parks are pensioners and quite clearly they have to be looked after at every opportunity. There should be some direction given, because they are a fractured, individual group of tenants. Whilst we have other tenancy advocacy groups in terms of bodies corporate and other styles of residential living, this particular area of residential living is quite obvious for its lack of organisation and individual aspects which has seen their rights unfortunately eroded over a number of years. So I make that philosophical comment in terms of going back to this legislation. I am sure that in time to come we will see further amendments to this legislation to further protect the rights of individuals in residential parks as an increasing part of the society we have in Queensland.

The Liberal National Party is supportive of any legislative changes that protect consumers’ rights. As the shadow minister for fair trading I have spoken to Queenslanders who are concerned that their rights are protected in all areas, and I believe that this bill is a good start. The growing area of utilising manufactured homes as an alternative to standard housing is going to continue to expand, and the industry and consumers need appropriate laws to see the industry cope with that growth. It is a necessary and important part of our residential community options and must be protected by governments to the fullest extent. The opposition will be supporting the bill, but I still hold some of those reservations that I have highlighted in my speech.

Mr CRANDON (Coomera--LNP) (5.54 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate regarding the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Amendment Bill 2010. The main object of the act is to regulate and promote fair practices in the operation of residential parks to protect homeowners from unfair business practices and to enable homeowners and prospective homeowners to make informed choices by being fully aware of their rights and responsibilities in their relationship with park owners. According to the draft public benefit test review completed in January 2010, there are around 200 parks in Queensland accommodating 15,000 people. Most of those are in South-East Queensland. We can expect significant growth going forward.

Broadly, the legislation goes some way towards its goals. But, from feedback from homeowners living in manufactured home parks both on the Gold Coast and in Logan City, it does not appear to have gone far enough. Of further concern to me is the recent occurrence where receivers and managers have been appointed to the affairs of a trust that owns retirement villages. Taking these two things into consideration, there has to be a balance between viability of parks and affordability for homeowners. We are a voice in this place for our constituents, and it is necessary and important for us to put forward their concerns in this place.

People move to these facilities for a variety of reasons. Many people living in these facilities are pensioners. Pensioners are not a bottomless pit of money and they should not be responsible for a park owner’s mismanagement or poor management practices. From my background as a financial planner, I can confirm that many who move to manufactured home parks do so to help with their retirement income needs. Many have not had the opportunity to build a big enough nest egg to live a reasonable lifestyle whilst remaining in their residence. Many have sold their detached home and used the proceeds to buy into a less expensive home, using the money left over to top up their age pension and therefore provide for their retirement income at a level that is a little better than perhaps just receiving an age pension. With escalating costs of living--for example fuel costs, electricity costs and so forth--these savings are rapidly reducing. There are a few points that need to be made here, and I draw on material I have received from people who are living what is fast becoming a very expensive lifestyle through no fault of their own.

As I alluded to earlier, the rising cost of fuel and electricity is just the tip of the iceberg. When coupled with all of the other increases that all of us are experiencing, any increase to rent for those in a manufactured home park is becoming unbearable. While I am on the topic of rising costs, one cost that affects those who are pensioners in these parks is the rising cost of water. This government has written the legislation that provides relief for pensioners by way of a water rebate to ensure that these pensioners do not benefit. So here we have a situation where we recognise the need to give a rebate to pensioners for the cost of water as it increases. On the other side of the coin, we have many pensioners moving to these types of manufactured home sites who, because they move, do not qualify for that water rebate--same people, same water supply, same usage, no rebate.

Coming back to some figures provided to me by people on the ground, so to speak--park residents--they tell me that they quote the minister, who at various times has stated that ‘residential parks provide cheap and affordable housing to many thousands of Queenslanders’. They say that that may have been true in the past but not since the generous rent increases granted by the tribunal, especially those associated with the so-called market reviews.

The comparative cost of different housing options that have been outlined to me, using a six-month council rating period in 2009, are as follows. The example given was between a house in Arundel with the six-monthly cost of $1,267 versus a town house in Merrimac with a six-monthly cost of $2,105, which included body corporate fees, compared with rental payments of one site in their village of $3,079. I have not checked these figures. I have taken them on face value, but I have no reason to believe that they are inaccurate. Yes, we can consider the outlay for residents versus the outlay for the town house versus the outlay for the manufactured home site. I alluded to that earlier. We have a situation where people are selling a more expensive home to use the proceeds to move to a manufactured home site. Of course, there is a capital cost to take into consideration in that regard.

The point these people are making is that their available capital, this additional capital, was intended to provide them with a better lifestyle, not to pay the ever-increasing cost of site fees that are well above inflation. One further point that was made was that the tribunal approved a rent increase of seven per cent in April this year and a further five to six per cent in June due to the tribunal ruling forcing them to commence paying for the water usage that I referred to a short while ago.

These increases put the site costs up $3,448 for a six-month period. So it is $1,267 for a house, $2,105 for a town house and $3,448 for a manufactured home site. The annualised difference from top to bottom--that is, from the house through to the manufactured home site--is $4,362. That equates to a capital investment required of around $110,000. So $110,000 of the proceeds from the sale of the home that they sold so that they would have more money for their retirement years--and in many circumstances that is probably all they ended up with in extra funds--goes into the bank and that $110,000 pays the $4,362 increase in costs associated with them living in that manufactured home site as opposed to living in their own home. So they have gone no way towards improving their lifestyle in their retirement years which, I would argue, was their original intention in many cases. Not one dollar of it goes towards improving their lifestyle.

Earlier I stated that homeowners should not be responsible for park owners’ mismanagement or poor management practices. Constituents talk to me about the introduction in the legislation of, what they refer to as, vague principles such as ‘viability’, ‘significant’ and ‘unforeseen’. I understand what they are worried about. Of course we all know the meaning of the words, but it is the concept that the park owners have not thought ahead sufficiently to have these matters covered in their business plans that disturbs the homeowners.

They talk about potential site fee increases and other costs being imposed upon homeowners for these and other reasons. They ask: at what level of profitability does a park become viable? Is it viable if it breaks even--that is, after paying all of the salaries of the people who are involved in running the park and breaking even beyond that and perhaps for the park owner a capital return if they at some time decide to move on and no longer manage the park--or is a five per cent profit or perhaps a much higher profit of 10, 15, 20, 25 or 30 per cent required? No-one really knows what is regarded as a reasonable rate of return for these park owners.

How and who will establish and monitor these issues, they ask. I repeat that the homeowners are on fixed incomes for the most part and there is a limit to how far they can stretch to bail out park owners. Another point that has been made abundantly clear is that the individual homeowners are in a weaker negotiating position than park owners. QCAT aside, at the end of the day it is what they bring to QCAT that it is going to make its decision on.

The park owners are typically company structures with astute businesspeople at their helm. They also have an association that can act on their behalf as a group. The member for Mermaid Beach referred to a failing at the moment where individual homeowners in parks do not have an association and therefore are in a weaker position.

As I said, the park owners also have an association that can act on their behalf as a group, the point being that they are able to more easily bring resources to bear to support their argument. We have a situation where park owners are collecting rent from homeowners and using those proceeds to bring to bear the resources to fight the individual homeowners. So the homeowners are funding the fight against themselves in relation to any argument that they might have that they might want to put through the tribunal. An extension of this is the concept that a company could use proceeds collected from homeowners in one park--that is, a viable park--to fund another park that they own that is ailing or indeed another business that is ailing that has nothing to do with parks of any description but is simply another business.

A further point--and I referred to the percentage increase earlier--is that recent increases are significantly higher than pension increases. This cannot be sustained by people on fixed incomes. It was a 13 per cent increase in their cost over a period of just a few months. We are talking about an inflation rate of something in the order of three per cent. We may very well find that some have to sell out and fall back to rental accommodation during their twilight years if the trend continues.

In closing, I make the point that I made at the beginning of my contribution. The bill goes some way to providing further certainty for homeowners but I urge the minister to make this a work in progress and continue to work on improving the act to more properly address the concerns of an ever-increasing number of retired and near retired residents of manufactured home parks.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (6.06 pm): There is not always a long journey between choice in housing and getting any shelter that one can. Having a home or being homeless after good or bad health is probably the most powerful of all human needs. This bill has a basic aim of delivering some certainty to a critical group of Queenslanders--those defined as living in manufactured homes. A manufactured home is defined as the end result option, that being where the owner rents the site of a manufactured home, owned not by the residential park owner, and owns the home, according to the minister in his second reading speech.

But what if the owner rents the site from a residential park owner and the residential park owner owns the manufactured home too, as is often the case on the Gold Coast, and critically where the previous owners of that manufactured home did not live in that structure for the three years immediately prior to the commencement of these amendments? All these points are critical not because the bill and the minister’s department have not tried to address the complete issue of definitions but because the bill may not resolve many of the problems facing the homeowners of certain manufactured homes.

For the majority, some of their issues are addressed, but they as a group remain an unhappy lot. After defining manufactured homes, the minister has also taken a big focus on the clarification of what a caravan is when a caravan is not a caravan and when it either becomes a manufactured home or close enough to becoming a manufactured home and when a caravan becomes an entity covered under the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act 2010 and also when it remains under the RTRA, the Residential Tenancies and Rooming Accommodation Act. It is all pretty confusing.

There is an attempt within the bill to clarify this. I actually think the minister has attempted to work his way through this, as the shadow minister said. There is really some quite interesting detail here that has reached a crescendo in the case of Tamahori v Roofley Pty Ltd 2009. It followed on the review of the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act 2003 outcome report.

It must be said that the current undecided court cases will be heard as though the amendments had not been made, but converted caravans would not be covered under this act. A site agreement can be made between the park owner and the caravan owner under the provisions of the act. Respectfully it might be said that we have at best a two-stream system of judicial fairness and at worst a contradiction of the facts that may lead to a severe judicial and legislated unfairness. This occurs because there are very tight definitions regarding the quantum of modifications to a caravan that define it as a manufactured home but it is loose with the definition about what is and what is not transportable. Realistically in a modern world, nearly anything is transportable. What generally limits that transportability is cost. Everything else is essentially flexible, but if the budget will not allow it and nor is it economically practicable then that alone would seem to be the key ingredient to determine whether a home is transportable or not.

I suspect transportability will be tested in courts. The most likely determining factor will be those seeking access to Commonwealth benefits in planning terms to both rental allowances on their homes and whether they have been accepted for those benefits. This benefit may be making a lot of these types of housing developments popular, especially for retiring or the retired population. What some members may not be aware of is that the benefits flow after the property meets the test of the non-freehold or rented land, and that includes nonleased and the dwelling on it theoretically being transportable. In reality, these homes are not really very transportable at all. In a modern world they have less in common with the old Logan unit or kit home and more in common with modern non-brick veneer on concrete floor base-to-ground structures. The closest parallel is the donga--the detachable on-site general purpose annexe. This is either that loved or loathed dwelling now ensconced in Australian folklore.

Is this relevant? It certainly is, for this is where the bill will certainly lead many of the existing residents of residential parks or enclaves which are essentially the same. In an era where there is a rapidly ageing population who are seeking less complication in their lives, downsizing of their homes and financial obligations, these manufactured homes will be a very sizeable part of the housing equation in absolute terms as a proportion of these dwellings. It may be that all of the changes are coming too late for many and will not be all embracing enough for the great numbers who in the next 10 years will find themselves either in a residential park or considering buying or renting a manufactured home in a park or an equivalent of it.

Australia has a housing shortage of 300,000 homes or $100 billion worth of homes. This shortage of 300,000 homes in Australia has an enormous immediate knock-on effect in our community. It is particularly compounded in the growing communities in South-East Queensland. The shortage is not generalised. It is very lopsided and is amplified by economic, social and physical demands. In an economy where mining is booming, we are being pulled between housing shortages in mining or near-mining towns where there is fly-in and fly-out staff and there is a disconnect between demand and supply. Older Australians are also reticent to move because of divorce in their children and themselves, children staying at home longer, loss of social supports because of moving and an equity problem in their savings. Australians, whilst enjoying a high percentage of home ownership, which is still at the 70 per cent mark, have declining home equity and rising mortgages, with an average home mortgage on the Gold Coast of $400,000. This is driving homeowners to look at manufactured homes as a serious option because of the attractive Commonwealth effective subsidies and a liberation of locked up equity found in their retirement options.

For those nonowners it gives an affordable option that ensures for many the security of a home free from everything from rates to under 50-year rental families whose lives may not necessarily be acceptable to an older group. This pursuit of a later life of security, not wishing to live near rental properties, being close to those with similar aspirational goals and a flexibility of selling options is very common to many of these. In my electorate of Gaven there are three very large such premises that address the three major market sectors. The public likes it and it wants more of it. The tragedy of this bill is that by limiting incentives to park owners we may see little future investment in these areas. The minister has correctly stated that the bill--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... proposes important amendments to strengthen provisions of the act that protect the interests of manufactured homeowners.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: After having moved into a park, the opportunity for a homeowner to change providers and get a better deal for themselves is very limited.
XML.Hansard-Body: For most a home is a personal choice subject to many conflicts, much happiness and sanctuary. It follows that when a resident either feels powerless or is threatened by loss of control over their own home they might choose security over both convenience and cost savings. The minister is reassuring owners that the bill--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... strengthens provisions of the act ... from engaging in threatening, intimidating or coercive conduct regarding site rent issues.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He adds--
