Essentially a site agreement under the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act is an agreement between a park owner and a homeowner that provides for the rental of land on which the manufactured home is positioned. It also provides for the homeowner’s non-exclusive use of common areas and communal facilities within the park. Written site agreements are important because they help homeowners and park owners have a common understanding of their rights and responsibilities. Written site agreements also assist the parties in avoiding and resolving disputes.

The act currently includes a range of important requirements regarding the presentation and content of these site agreements. In my electorate of Broadwater there are quite a number of manufactured home villages and parks and a number of caravan parks that provide sites for manufactured home residents. These include Paradise Lakes Resort, Emerald Gardens, Hammond Village, Harbourside Gardens, Settlers Village and Pine Ridge Caravan Park. In the lead up to this bill being drafted I arranged for the department to hold a consultation workshop at the Runaway Bay Community Hall. I know that many residents took the opportunity to attend. Whilst the issues discussed were often very complicated, I commend the residents for taking an interest and participating in the consultation.

From meetings with resident group representatives and manufactured home owners on a number of occasions during the review of the act and since the introduction of the bill I know that the security of their investment and the ability to live in their home without fear of their agreements or circumstances changing is particularly important for owners. Since the introduction of the bill and during the review, along with my colleagues the member for Murrumba, the member for Burleigh, the member for Waterford and the member for Morayfield, I have taken the opportunity to talk with the minister about the concerns that residents have raised with us and we have had some opportunities to talk to the department and senior policy advisers. I would like to thank the minister for those opportunities to talk with him directly.

One of the fundamental policies underpinning the act is to provide a high degree of security and certainty in a homeowner’s right to reside in a residential park. I understand that unlike many types of leases, site agreements under the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act are not intended to be for a fixed term. They are essentially perpetual in nature. A homeowner’s interest under the site agreement can be assigned by the current owner to another person who has agreed to purchase the manufactured home. The act provides homeowners with a specific right to sell their home on-site and it also prohibits park owners from interfering with the sale of a home and from unreasonably refusing to consent to a proposed assignment of a site agreement.

Under the act, a site agreement between a park owner and a manufactured home owner can only be terminated in one of three ways: by notice of the homeowner; by mutual agreement of the homeowner and the park owner; or by order of the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal upon application by a park owner.

This third option has been raised with me by my residents as of particular concern. They are concerned about how long manufactured park owners will actually have the use of that land for the purposes of residential manufactured homes. I have talked to the minister about my concern that, whilst the tribunal must order the park owner to pay compensation to the homeowner, if the park owner puts in an application to use the land for another lawful purpose, what impact would this have on residents? I am concerned about them finding a comparable location to the park that they are currently living in and them having to move and find a location. I have also raised with the minister my concern about the impact that this would have on affordable housing for Queenslanders and particularly senior residents. I ask that the minister in his summary provide to the House what the government is doing to address this particular issue. As we have heard tonight, many members have acknowledged that a lot of the people living in these manufactured home parks are senior residents who invest quite a lot of money in the purchase of their manufactured home and then they are paying rent on top of that. We acknowledge that they are vulnerable members of the community. Whilst they may have downsized from a previous home, many of them are using manufactured home parks as affordable alternative accommodation.

I understand that a review of the act identified that some park owners are attempting to establish fixed-term agreements which is contrary to the policy intention of this act. These park owners attempt to establish fixed-term agreements by including an end date in the special terms of the site agreement or by convincing prospective homeowners to enter into mutual termination agreements with the park owner before or at the time the actual site agreement is entered into. In addition to being contrary to the intended operation of the act, this practice also places homeowners at significant risk of not being eligible for compensation under the act if the park owner decides not to renew the homeowner’s site agreement. I believe that this is a serious risk for homeowners given that the cost of moving a manufactured home can be in the vicinity of $20,000, depending on the characteristics of the manufactured home.

We have had many people comment tonight on the definition of a manufactured home. Under the act, where there is provision that the manufactured home owner move their home, it can cost up to $20,000. Under a fixed-term arrangement many residents would be forfeiting this right. Unfortunately, there can be an imbalance in the bargaining positions of park owners and homeowners, because prospective homeowners are unlikely to be as aware of the operation of this legislation as park owners. I understand that some homeowners who have entered into this type of arrangement report that they felt that they had no choice about the termination agreement and if they did not sign it then they would not be offered a site in the park at all. Other homeowners report that the relevant park owner verbally assured them that they would be offered a new site agreement at the end of their existing site agreement.

The bill will address this issue by specifically prohibiting termination clauses and agreements that are entered into before or on the same day as the site agreement. The bill operates retrospectively by making these types of clauses and termination agreements void even if they were entered into prior to the commencement of the amendments. The bill will not stop park owners and homeowners from freely entering into genuine mutual termination agreements during the life of the site agreement. However, it will prevent the unintended use of mutual termination agreements and special terms by some park owners who seek to establish fixed-term agreements, thereby avoiding that compensation for homeowners.

I believe these amendments are consistent with the original intention of the act and will make sure that some manufactured home owners are not disadvantaged compared to others when it comes to their rights about termination of their site agreements and potential compensation payments. The review also highlighted opportunities to improve the rules regarding site agreements. Whilst the act currently requires site agreements to be written in a clear and precise way, the review of the act also highlighted that some site agreements are particularly excessively complex and legalistic in language and this makes it very difficult for manufactured home owners to fully understand the meaning of various terms of their site agreement and can result in disputes about the interpretation of that agreement.

This bill proposes an amendment to require site agreements to be clearly expressed in plain language. This will give manufactured home owners a better chance of properly understanding their site agreement and making informed choices. The Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal will have jurisdiction to consider applications from homeowners who consider that a term of their agreement is not in plain language. If the tribunal finds that a term of agreement is not clearly expressed in plain language, the tribunal will have power to make orders varying the term and prohibiting the park owner from using the same term in another site agreement.

The explanatory notes to this bill obviously contain guidance on the types of factors that can be considered in assessing whether or not the terms of a site agreement are clearly expressed in plain language. Some of the examples given are that the site agreements could have used excessively long sentences, clauses or paragraphs; extensive cross-referencing; failure to define key terms; important terms being buried in fine print or schedules; and terms that place a homeowner at a particularly unfair disadvantage because he or she is not clear about the meaning even if the meaning could be determined by a professional legal practitioner. I think this is a very good inclusion in the bill.

This amendment is intended to empower homeowners by giving them the best possible chance to understand their site agreement, both before entering into the agreement and during the life of the agreement. The amendment is also complementary with the change to the objectives of the act which highlight the need to enable homeowners and prospective homeowners to make informed choices by being fully aware of their rights and responsibilities in their relationship with park owners.

In addition to improving the presentation of site agreements, this bill also aims to address particular issues that have arisen concerning the content of site agreements and in particular the inclusion of some special terms in site agreements. While the act requires site agreements to contain particular information, it also gives park owners and homeowners flexibility to agree to special terms in their site agreements. This is intended to enable park owners and homeowners to tailor their site agreement by including particular terms that suit the individual circumstances of both parties and the park. However, the review also highlighted that in some cases special terms are being included in site agreements that unfairly disadvantage the homeowner and which are not reasonably necessary for the protection of the park owner’s legitimate commercial interests.

This bill addresses this issue by providing the power for specified special terms or park rules to be prohibited by regulation. Park owners and homeowners will continue to have the flexibility to agree on special terms in site agreements--and these could include a resident wanting to keep a pet or to do some gardening and how that would be done--and to adopt park rules that suit both the parties’ and the park’s individual circumstances except where the special terms or park rule have been prohibited. I understand that these will be considered in regulation. They may include some examples from New South Wales legislation such as issues relating to the use of tradespeople in manufactured homes. A lot of manufactured home residents have raised with me their concern that they wanted to use a particular tradesperson but their manufactured park owner insisted on a particular tradesperson. Many residents feel that that is a little unfair; they would like to engage their own tradespeople to address issues around their own home. Enabling unfair special terms and park rules to be prohibited by regulation will provide significant protection to park owners including those homeowners who already have site agreements as the bill will retrospectively void prohibited special terms and park rules.

The bill proposes new offences for park owners who include a special term in a site agreement or make a park rule that has been prohibited by the regulation. The bill also provides homeowners with the right to apply to the tribunal to decide whether all or part of a special term in their site agreement constitutes a prohibited special term. I understand that the proposed regulation will be developed in consultation with manufactured home owners and park owners.

I would also like to make some observations regarding the provisions of the bill that deal with utility charges being passed on from park owners to homeowners. The Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act includes rules about charges of utility services such as electricity, water, gas and sewerage. The application of these rules depends on whether the homeowner’s use of the utility service is separately measured and billed. I know that the way in which the manufactured homes in my electorate are set up is very different. This particularly addresses many of those concerns in my electorate. I understand that in some cases park owners are charging homeowners more for utilities than the amount the park owner is being charged by the supply authority. The amendments contained in the bill will stop these park owners from profiting from utility bills by making it clear that park owners must not charge homeowners more than the actual costs of providing the quantity of the utility supplied to the homeowner where the homeowner’s use of the utility service is separately measured and charged to the homeowner. This amendment means that all residents in the park who receive separate utility bills, including those in caravans, will be treated equally with regard to the payment of utilities used as the amendments are consistent with the requirements under the Residential Tenancies and Rooming Accommodation Act 2008.

Many residents have raised with me that they think their rent can only increase by CPI and that in recent years park owners have sought to increase rent based on market review. Residents have told me that they think this is unfair, particularly when market review is not included in the terms of their site agreement. I ask the minister to address these concerns in his summary and clarify how the bill will address the residents’ concerns particularly when, as I have mentioned, the majority of manufactured home owners are on fixed incomes and have invested significantly in the purchase of their manufactured home.

In closing, I say that I appreciate very much the efforts undertaken to improve consumer protection for manufactured home owners through the changes proposed in the bill. However, I still have ongoing concerns in relation to the relocation compensation of manufactured home owners and, in particular, the market review. I trust that the department will continue to monitor the effects of these issues on residents as a priority moving forward. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms DARLING (Sandgate--ALP) (8.57 pm): I rise to make a brief contribution to this debate mainly because my government colleagues have already covered all of the main reasons that we need these important reforms.

There are three parks in the electorate of Sandgate that have manufactured homes on-site. One at Brighton has only a handful of homeowners as most of the people there are renting homes or are in caravans, another in Fitzgibbon has all manufactured home owners and the third in Taigum has a combination of homeowners and renters, with plans for further development.

I welcome the improved protection measures in this bill, but I also call on park owners to do the right thing by their homeowners and respect their rights, including the right to live a life full of family and friendship without constant pressures to comply with unreasonable park edicts. These parks are homes to many people on low incomes. Although they do not own the land on which their homes sit, they do own their homes and they deserve to be treated just as honestly and respectfully as any homeowner.

The problem in some parks around the state is that park managers can too easily bully homeowners because of their ability to set park rules. These are home parks, not detention centres. I have seen in my own area how well a park can function when the lines of communication are open. So my message to park owners is this: people do not want to lodge complaints, they do not want to call in the Office of Fair Trading and they do not want to pursue redress in the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal; they just want to live a happy life in the home they have purchased. So please treat them with the respect they deserve.

I commend the strengthened consumer provisions, especially the amendments that provide further protection for homeowners where a park owner wishes to use their land for another purpose. There are limited options but enormous costs for homeowners who need to relocate their homes when a park owner seeks to terminate a site agreement. It is important that the tribunal can consider the social and economic impacts of a termination. I thank the department, the minister and his trusty advisers for the extensive consultation on these reforms. I thank many of my constituents for their very detailed and frank feedback. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr McLINDON (Beaudesert--TQP) (8.59 pm): I rise to contribute to the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Amendment Bill 2010 and to support the introduction of this legislation. Given the significant and increasing pressures in housing affordability, it is timely that the manufactured homes act be reviewed and amended accordingly to make it applicable in just terms and conditions to all parties involved. The main objective of the bill is to promote fair trading practices in the day-to-day operations of the residential parks.

Whilst there is a belief that there will be an increase in residential parks living due to the unprecedented cost of living and housing affordability, we must also be aware that the location and relocation of future parks will most likely occur in areas with less infrastructure due to land valuation and accessibility. I must say at the outset that for legislative purposes we refer to these homes as manufactured homes, which can be quite offensive to some people. I discovered this at a community forum a few years ago, when I was told that it was considered disrespectful to refer to somebody’s home in that manner. Whilst it has quite an impersonal reference, we must put the terminology used within this bill into that perspective.

I recall from my tenure on the Logan City Council, working in conjunction with the member for Springwood, the impending relocation of Springtime Gardens, which was located in an ideal position in Springwood. Currently, Springwood faces the realities of growth in the area, which puts added pressure on the tenants in terms of where they could relocate to and, in some cases, how they would move as for some the cost of relocating a manufactured home was financially impossible. One single mother was distraught because she was still paying off her home and could not afford to relocate it. In addition, a relocation would create further financial hardship due to the lack of accessibility to essential services.

Having doorknocked throughout many residential parks over the years, I am sure many Queenslanders will be appreciative of this legislation, which will give them necessary protections. I note there has been confusion as to the status of what is deemed a manufactured home due to the many and varied alterations which, over time, can be made to caravans. The amendments contained in this bill will give a specific regulatory framework that will give greater certainty to the definition.

The fixed term site agreements will give far greater peace of mind to those who, in many cases, may not fully understand the legalities of any supposed length of stay agreed upon by the park owner and the homeowner. Of course, the flexibility remains in those agreements, which are disregarded mutually. I note also that retrospective operation of the amendments is necessary. However, I hope that will not ignite any disfavour between parties with standing agreements. Those who may intend to use this to exploit another party would be duly dealt with. It is a good proposition to allow for the establishment of homeowners committees that park owners will be obliged to be responsive to. The committees will resolve any matters arising. The bill confirms that only one committee at each park will exist to prevent the possibility of factional warfare that would see homeowners turn against homeowners and one stressed park owner left to deal with the unworkable.

The list of new penalties outlined in the bill provides adequate protection to the homeowners and discourages the park owners from attempting to misuse or contract out of the policy principles underpinning the act. I look forward to the implementation of this legislation and will be sure to pass the information on to the various residential parks within the Beaudesert electorate.

Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP) (9.02 pm): Affordable housing means having housing options. Manufactured home parks used to provide one alternative for people seeking a less expensive option than freehold property. They loved their manufactured homes, whether flash or humble, which were located upon a leased block of land. They had neighbours nearby and they understood community. I am talking in the past tense because this is becoming a past life for many people who love their homes but who are being forced out. Unfortunately, this legislation will not stop that problem. With the SEQ regional plan there are winners and there are victims. I advise the parliament that people living in manufactured home parks are victims, as the value of land within the urban footprint has made many of those parks even more valuable for redevelopment, although not as manufactured home parks. They are fast being lost, along with other caravan parks, from within the SEQ regional footprint. They are being squeezed out as properties within the urban perimeter become unaffordable.

I fear that this legislation fails to provide the protection that the owners of manufactured homes are seeking, because at the end of the day if the park owner decides to close down and redevelop and the homeowner has to relocate, there may not be anywhere to go within 100 kilometres. Certainly I face that situation in my electorate. I have constituents whose parks are being closed or progressively closed but they have nowhere to go. There are no alternatives within 100 kilometres. I have raised this issue with the minister and I hear other members of the parliament raising the issue. While I appreciate the attempt to put protections into the act, unless that power balance is addressed by providing alternative sites that people can move their homes to, they will still be left up the creek without the proverbial paddle.

I suggest that, in addition to this legislation, we need provisions within the SEQ plan and planning procedures that provide incentives for the maintenance of caravan parks and manufactured home parks, because currently they are being priced out of the market, they are being upscaled and redeveloped, and people are losing their opportunities. One hundred kilometres is a long way for someone to move a manufactured home. I know that there is talk of compensation for people who move within 300 kilometres, but the reality is that most people who want to stay within the community where their friends and family live will not want to move more than 20 or 30 kilometres away, and certainly will not want to move 100 kilometres away. One hundred kilometres is a long way away from friends and family.

In Queensland, as you go further north building regulations change, as properties have to be cyclone proof. There is an historic issue that it may be harder to bring older relocatable homes up to current building standards. Whatever way we look at it, there are a lot of problems associated with relocating what were completely relocatable homes when first established, but today’s higher standards mean that options are a lot more limited. I fear that the very specific issue of land supply will mean that in South-East Queensland manufactured home parks will close down because of the pressures of growth. However, we will also see caravan parks that provide tourism opportunities becoming a thing of the past. I think that is a great shame in the state of Queensland.

When we talk about people being squeezed out, we must remember that we are talking about real lives. We are talking about real people who are affected. I have raised some cases with the minister previously and I will mention one here in the parliament. Some of the cases that individual park homeowners have faced have been most unreasonable. A constituent of mine was ordered by the tribunal to be gone by a certain date with no accompanying order for relocation costs. The order to determine the relocation costs was made only three days before they were supposed to have picked up their whole home and relocated to who knows where. That was a completely unreasonable situation caused by the tribunal’s processes.

I have drawn that case to the minister’s attention, but I will outline it for the benefit of the parliament. Initially, on 6 May 2010 my constituent was ordered by the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal to be gone from their site by 18 June 2010. They attended another hearing three days before they were due to be gone, which gave them a bit of a stay of execution. In summary, they were ordered to be gone by a certain date, with no order given at that time as to their relocation costs. The tribunal made the compensation order only three days before they were supposed to have packed up and moved out. There are examples where not only can the practice of some park owners be unacceptable but, as in this case, the tribunal can also fail in its consideration of the impact upon people. My constituents were very distressed because they did not even know what they were entitled to with the relocation and even if they received a compensation package they had nowhere to go to. They were left in a very vulnerable situation.

There are some people who choose this way of life. It does provide an affordable housing option, or it has in the past, but we are finding that they are increasingly vulnerable. I will continue to raise the issue that more needs to be done within the planning laws of this state, the South East Queensland Regional Plan, to truly encourage a range of housing options, not just those that are going to be so up-market that people who had previously chosen these options will have no option. They will not be able to afford to live in South-East Queensland. In fact, they will not be able to relocate their home outside of South-East Queensland either, because they simply will not be able to afford to. This issue is not going to go away. We believe that it needs to be firmly addressed. I note that the minister has advised in correspondence to me that the government is considering this matter. I add my voice to those who have spoken about the vulnerability of this group of constituents because they still have nowhere to go. Unfortunately the legislation before us still does not address the issue that they are facing.

Mrs SULLIVAN (Pumicestone--ALP) (9.09 pm): I, too, rise to support the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Amendment Bill 2010, which proposes to amend the Manufactured Homes Act 2003. From the outset, I would like to take the opportunity to thank those involved in the consultation process, particularly those officers from the Office of Fair Trading and those residents who attended public consultation forums across Queensland. One was held in Caboolture and it was certainly well attended.

Discussions have been long, and some have expressed to me that it has taken far too long for the bill to come before the House. Public consultation began over three years ago and has attracted considerable attention. In fact, around 670 written responses were received, and because of the feedback during the process some changes were made to the draft bill. This government is dedicated to providing all Queenslanders with a fair go. While we can cannot provide everyone with everything they want, in this bill we did aim to regulate and promote better fair trading practices in the operation of residential parks.

In the electorate of Pumicestone, which I represent, there are a number of residential parks, and their occupants form a very valued part of our community. Those living in residential home parks have chosen this lifestyle for many different reasons. Parks are an essential provider of alternative affordable housing to about 15,000 Queenslanders. Therefore, the fact that this bill progresses consumer protection initiatives while also allowing for the continued growth of the residential parks industry is very important.

Some would argue that the bill does not go far enough. Some will be unhappy that it does not cover every individual circumstance, which is obviously impossible. While I acknowledge that there is always more that we can do as far as legislation is concerned, I am pleased that this bill, when passed this evening, will clarify and further strengthen several aspects of the current law for the benefit of occupants. There is no reason that once the bill is implemented people cannot seek further reform to continue to modernise the bill to suit the times and the changing attitudes in the community.

I would like to include in my speech a comment from a letter dated 2 October 2010. While others were not entirely satisfied with the draft bill, as I have stated--and I am going to get to their concerns shortly--others, like the chairperson of the Island Breeze Resort homeowners committee, Mr Alan Nichols, were keen to see the bill put before the House with no more changes. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I am writing to seek your support in having the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Amendment Bill 2010 presented as a whole in its current form.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The letter went on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Concerns have been expressed that some Manufactured Home Park owners have attempted to have amendments made prior to the Bill being passed through Parliament. These concerns have been supported by the Caravan and Manufactured Home Residents Association of Queensland Inc. or C.A.M.R.A. Your support to the Minister for Fair Trading would be very much appreciated.
XML.Hansard-Body: I have had numerous pieces of correspondence from residents who wanted more changes. One gentleman was deeply concerned that there was still an imbalance between the homeowners and the park owners due mostly to the different attitudes expressed from an economic and social perspective. Residents want security of tenure. They want to pay what they consider to be a reasonable rent for that security. They want to see their rent money being used to further improve their quality of life. Everyone would agree that these are all reasonable requests.

The park owners--I know many of them, and I have visited many of their residential parks--on the whole have invested considerable funds to develop, make viable and profit from their business ventures. The bill takes note of these competing concerns between park owners and the occupants and tries to provide certainty for both parties. This is why change should be gradual, so that each party is able to adjust to those changes.

Amendments in this bill will also make things clearer for occupants contemplating entering a residential park. For example, the bill includes amendments to improve the presentation and content of site agreements. Many of these have been contentious in the past. They will need to be clearly written in plain English and therefore easily understood. As well, the bill proposes a power for particular special terms in site agreements to be banned by regulation. These have been a problem in the past where agreements or contracts did have clauses that differed and this caused angst among many of the occupants. Amendments will also provide occupants with more confidence and certainty regarding site rent increases by considerably limiting the grounds on which a park owner may seek an increase in rent outside the terms of the site agreement.

There are many other strengths to this bill but, due to the time, I finish by saying that I commend the bill to the House. I believe that this bill goes a long way to protecting homeowners in residential parks from what I would consider to be unfair practices of the past.

Hon. KL STRUTHERS (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (9.15 pm): I support this bill. It is just one more way that the state government is building a fairer Queensland, through ensuring that Queenslanders can be secure in their tenancy in a lifestyle that they choose--in this case, in manufactured homes in parks. I thank the minister for his support of this legislation. We are trying to get the balance right here between the rights of the owners of the parks and making sure that tenants in manufactured homes in these parks have security of tenure and things like compensation if they are unfairly moved on at short notice.

The bill gives residents in manufactured homes in caravan parks greater certainty about their rights. Manufactured homes are affordable housing that suit some people’s circumstances. As Minister for Housing, I am very aware that many people call these places home and they have very comfortable and secure homes. In fact, my mother lives in a manufactured home in a park on the Gold Coast. She has said to me on a number of occasions that she has never felt more secure. She has a great group of people in that park and she feels very comfortable there. The only insecurity that is hanging over her head is that at any time she could be moved on. There is encroaching development around her park at Runaway Bay and she knows that at any time she may be required to move on.
Ms Croft: I’ll look after her.
Ms STRUTHERS: But she certainly feels very secure where she is at the moment. She knows that she has a great state member in PK Croft, looking after the residents in that park.

The bill certainly tries to rectify the uncertainty that had come to exist in the law over the rights of owners of manufactured parks. I particularly welcome the changes in this bill that will make the termination of site agreements much clearer. Residents of manufactured homes deserve the certainty and security that this act gives them, and they certainly deserve the opportunity to object to the termination of their site agreements. Residents will also have the right to receive compensation where these terminations are due to a park owner wanting to develop or change the use of the land. The bill also provides certainty, which park owners and operators have told me they want, to invest in a park. The government is keen to provide the business security for park managers to ensure caravan parks and mobile home parks are a viable enterprise for them--an enterprise that they can invest in, upgrade and maintain.

As minister, I am certainly very keen to make sure that there is a range of affordable housing options for people. It was with great pleasure that I went to the Sunshine Coast last week to officially open the upgraded Woombye Gardens Caravan Park. It is not the usual business of government to buy caravan parks but, being the good Labor government that we are, looking after the interests of low-income people, we have actually bought three of them--at Hervey Bay, Monte Carlo in Brisbane and Woombye on the Sunshine Coast. Those opposite do not support public housing. Those opposite do not support low-income battlers who are looking for security in housing. We have taken the unprecedented step of buying caravan parks.

The purchase of the Woombye caravan park is a great story. We have invested $2.3 million in that caravan park. The 67 residents who are in those new cabins--manufactured, factory-built cabins--in that park, as I went around and went into their homes, told me how good they felt and how secure they felt. It was great to meet people like Noel. Noel was in the Navy. He was a Navy diver. He then did diving privately with mining companies and others out in the Strait. I asked him what had happened for him to get that scar on his head. He told me the story that he had started to cut the jaws out of a shark, thinking it was dead on the bottom of the ocean, but it in fact bit him. Noel, in his 70s, has had a pretty formidable life and is now settling into the Woombye caravan park in his new cabin and feeling very secure and very happy. That is the sort of story we want to hear--stories of people who are doing it pretty tough and on a low income but getting the security of that sort of tenure.

The other area that we have been involved in--and it is quite unusual for governments--to find options for affordable housing is buying up motels and doing motel makeovers. We have done about 20 of those around the state. If members have stayed at the Rum City Motel in Bundaberg they will find that that is now public housing. The old Surf City Motel--or something like that--on Kawana Way is now public housing. These are great motels. We are doing motel makeovers that are providing affordable housing for people.

We have to be creative in how we respond to the needs for affordable housing for people on low incomes. This government is in the business of looking at a range of options including supporting the tenure and security of people in manufactured homes, in doing things like buying caravan parks and in doing motel makeovers. How many new social housing dwellings have we got on line? Four thousand.

Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (9.21 pm), in reply: I thank all members who have contributed to this debate on the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Amendment Bill 2010. I also take this opportunity to acknowledge the many members who have made individual representations to me on behalf of manufactured home owners living within their electorates. It is encouraging that members clearly understand the importance of this legislation and share the Bligh government’s commitment to protecting Queenslanders who live in manufactured homes.

From what members have said we can see how difficult it is to draw the line in the appropriate place. Most members supported issues associated with homeowners but also most supported the ability of people to invest in manufactured home parks. It is a matter of getting the balance right. That is not the easiest thing to do. As a couple of members mentioned, there might be other amendments. All legislation is under constant review. Basically, most legislation is a work in progress. As circumstances change so too must legislation be changed.

The great challenge in regulating residential parks is establishing and maintaining strong, effective consumer protection for manufactured home owners while avoiding regulatory burdens that discourage and stifle the viability and growth of the residential parks industry. This challenge has been well articulated by members in their contributions to this debate. Neither park owners nor homeowners are winners if the regulatory framework discourages the private housing sector from offering sites for long-term occupation by people living in manufactured homes. This bill has benefited from a comprehensive legislative review and extensive consultation processes.

I will now turn to some of the matters raised by members in their contributions to this debate. I thank the member for Mermaid Beach for his general support for the bill, his comments on particular provisions and I note his acknowledgement of the extensive consultation process. The member also noted that the bill contains amendments to require site agreements to be clearly presented in plain language. These amendments aim to help prospective homeowners better understand their rights and obligations under their site agreement.

Whilst it will depend on the circumstances of the case, the explanatory notes provide guidance on characteristics of plain language. Site agreements should not contain excessively long sentences, clauses or paragraphs and unnecessary use of technical terms, jargon and so on.

In response to the member’s comments about the potential increase in the number of applications made to QCAT, the amendments provide homeowners with important means to resolve disputes if they genuinely believe a term of their site agreement is not clearly expressed in plain language. The situation will of course be monitored.

I would also like to respond to the member for Mermaid Beach’s comments about the changes in relation to converted caravans and thank the member for Morayfield for his acknowledgement of the benefit the three-year transitional arrangement provides for existing converted caravan owners. The amendments provide existing converted caravan owners with a three-year period to apply to QCAT to seek an order for a site agreement if they believe their home meets the definition of a manufactured home under the pre-amended act. They will not be unfairly disadvantaged by the changes. It is a sunset clause, effectively.

Comments about the retrospective nature of the amendments that relate to the prohibition of special terms were also made by the member for Mermaid Beach. While the member contends that these amendments impact on the existing rights of park owners, it is important to note that homeowners are often in a weaker bargaining position when entering into site agreements. The capacity for an existing special term of a site agreement to become void in existing agreements following the making of a regulation is considered justified due to the long-term potentially intergenerational nature of site agreements and the fact that site agreements can be assigned to new homeowners.

If the amendments do not operate retrospectively, homeowners may be bound by unreasonable special terms in their site agreement for many years, notwithstanding that the terms have been prohibited. As such, it is appropriate that special terms that have been identified as being unfair and exploitative should not be permitted to continue in any site agreements. These important amendments will protect the interests of homeowners and substantially improve the level of consumer protection.

During consultation the question of coercive conduct that was raised by the member for Mermaid Beach was also raised by stakeholders. In general, a park owner engaging in reasonable communication and negotiations with a homeowner regarding rent issues does not constitute threatening, intimidating or coercive conduct unless their behaviour would make a reasonable person feel unwillingly compelled to comply with the request. The explanatory notes also provide some guidance about these provisions.

I also acknowledge the member for Mermaid Beach’s comments about the potential impact for park owners if QCAT postpones a termination order for up to one year. These amendments ensure that QCAT may consider both the needs and welfare of homeowners as well as the potential impact, including financial, on park owners.

I thank the member for Coomera for his comments about site rent increases in relation to consideration of the viability and profitability of parks. We have quite validly defended the rights of park owners here. The majority of residential parks are part of the private housing sector and are operated by private individuals and businesses.

He raised a few issues about the cost of running a townhouse in Maryborough, a house at Arundel and a townhouse somewhere else. One cost $1,267, one cost $2,105 and the other cost $3,448 per annum. He says he is a financial planner. I am glad he is not doing my finances.
Mr Stevens interjected.

Mr LAWLOR: That is good for you. Under the amendments, park owners seeking an increase in rent outside the terms of a site agreement will need to demonstrate and prove to the tribunal that their business is experiencing significant increases in operational costs, unforeseen and significant repair costs or significant facility upgrades in order to be granted an increase in site rent outside the terms of a site agreement. These types of expenses can be objectively identified and assessed by QCAT when resolving disputes about site rent.

Members, including the member for Gaven, commented on the adequacy of the compensation provisions in the bill. Currently, if a park owner obtains an order from QCAT allowing termination of a site agreement because the park owner wishes to use their land for another purpose, QCAT must also order the park owner to pay the homeowner compensation based on the costs of moving the home and the homeowner’s personal effects to another location.

In addition, the bill allows QCAT to make additional orders to assist homeowners faced with the termination of their site agreement, including orders postponing the termination date for up to one year and orders requiring the park owner to make another site in the park available to the homeowner, if that is available, of course. Increasing the compensation payable by park owners could conceivably discourage new entrants to the industry, resulting in increased pressure on the availability of sites.

Given that site agreements are perpetual and assignable and may only be terminated in certain circumstances, park owners have limited opportunities to ensure rent provisions of a site agreement continue to be appropriate given changes in operating costs over time. Therefore, it is considered fair and necessary for the act to allow park owners to seek increases in rent in particular circumstances. Importantly, park owners will no longer be able to seek market review based increases unless this method for increasing site rent has been specifically agreed to and included in an individual site agreement. Importantly, QCAT will continue to have jurisdiction to resolve disputes regarding proposed rent variations. If homeowners do not agree to the proposed increase outside the terms of their site agreements, the park owner will only be permitted to impose the increase if authorised by QCAT. The type of information required may be documents or any other evidence to substantiate and prove that the park owner is facing actual and significant increases in operating costs, unforeseen repair costs or significant facility upgrades.

Many members, including the members for Nicklin and Glass House, noted that some manufactured homes can resemble more traditional homes and questioned how this may impact on homeowners. The definition of a manufactured home provided in the act is broad enough to encapsulate a variety of different types of homes, from the more traditional mobile homes to larger and more substantial structures. While some modern manufactured homes appear to be permanently attached to the land, many of these homes are designed to be moved and meet the definition of a manufactured home. Homes must also meet local government requirements for construction approvals. In addition, if a park owner wishes to terminate a site agreement to use their land for another purpose, the park owner will be required to pay the homeowner compensation for the move, including where the costs may be substantial. It is important that each person seeks independent legal advice and makes informed decisions about the structure they are purchasing before entering into a site agreement with a residential park owner.

I note that the member for Glass House proposed that park owners be subject to a licensing regime. The key issue for this type of scheme is that residential park owners own the land the manufactured homes are positioned on. Therefore, revoking or placing restrictions on a residential park owner who is not meeting licensing requirements could result in a park owner being prevented from offering sites for manufactured homes. Manufactured home owners would not be in a better position if the park owner ceased offering sites because moving and relocating a manufactured home can be costly and vacant sites are difficult to find. The act currently contains clear prohibitions in relation to fraudulent, misleading, harassing or unconscionable conduct. These types of behaviours can be investigated by the Office of Fair Trading.

The bill also contains amendments which further strengthen the act by ensuring these prohibitions apply when a park owner is acting as a selling agent for a manufactured home. The member for Nicklin spoke about an exemption from requiring park owners to obtain a licence so they may benefit from a happy hour. The key difference between retirement villages and residential parks where manufactured homes may be positioned is that there is no age restriction for residential parks and therefore individuals of all ages may reside in a residential park. In fact, I have been to several of these parks, including one at Arundel and one at Hope Island, where quite young people reside.

Various people have mentioned issues about affordable housing. With regard to the park that I visited at Hope Island, the manufactured homes there are selling for around $500,000. There are not only elderly people there, so it is an issue concerned not only with the fact that nursing homes have the right to have happy hour. There are also issues associated with the age of the people living in the manufactured home parks. However, it is a valid issue and I am still prepared to have a look at it.
Mr Wellington: Will we have an amendment, Minister?
Mr LAWLOR: No, we will not be doing that. There are risks associated with providing this type of exemption given the diversity of occupants in manufactured homes.

Many members spoke about the need for continued consideration of the issues impacting on manufactured home owners. During the review manufactured home owners reported increasing pressure on the availability of home sites, and this is particularly an issue that was mentioned by the member for Broadwater, who has six manufactured home parks in her electorate and therefore is probably more impacted by this legislation and by the issue of manufactured home parks than any other member here. This issue has been raised by many members, including the member for Maroochydore.

Whilst the Bligh government is focused on achieving high standards of consumer protection, it is also mindful of the risk that increasing the regulatory burden may discourage existing residential park owners from offering sites for long-term occupation by manufactured homes. It is also important that potential new entrants to the industry have confidence that offering sites for manufactured homes is an attractive commercial proposition. The government will be undertaking further work to identify practical strategies to address the concerns expressed by some manufactured home owners that the number of residential parks offering sites for traditional manufactured homes is not meeting demand for those types of sites within the sector.

A whole-of-government approach is being taken to identify the barriers and disincentives facing the residential parks industry. Most importantly, this strategy aims to develop options to facilitate the growth and viability of a sector as an important provider of affordable housing options for Queenslanders without lessening the protection for homeowners, and there was reference by the Minister for Housing to steps that she has taken to acquire sites in Hervey Bay.

The Office of Fair Trading is currently working with the Department of Communities, the Department of Infrastructure and Planning and other Queensland government agencies to identify options for promoting growth in the industry. Encouraging an increase in the stock of sites for manufactured homes will relieve some of the pressure and risks facing homeowners whose right to reside in a particular park comes to an end. The government also recognises that this is an issue that the government cannot resolve on its own. To that end, a public discussion paper is being developed to enable park owners, homeowners and other interested parties to share their experience and expertise with the government in developing effective and innovative strategies to deliver more manufactured home sites. The government is undertaking a public consultation process regarding this particular issue in the future.

The member for Bundamba commented on park maintenance. Under the act the park owner has the responsibility to maintain the common areas and communal facilities in a reasonable state of cleanliness and repair and fit for use by the homeowner. As she mentioned, I have been to that particular park and I would agree with her that the people at Brisbane River Terraces certainly deserve a better performance from the managers than they are getting. I certainly witnessed that myself. If homeowners are not satisfied with the standard of the park, as a first step homeowners can consider seeking assistance from the homeowners committee. Under the act, homeowners committees are entitled to present park owners with proposals and complaints. Park owners are obliged to respond to the committee about proposals and complaints. The act also allows a homeowner to apply to the tribunal for an order reducing the site rent if the homeowner believes the amenity or standard of the residential park’s common areas and communal facilities has decreased substantially since the site agreement was entered into.

There were a couple of other issues raised by members. The member for Nicklin mentioned that manufactured homes are constructed on land which makes it very difficult for them to subsequently remove. As I mentioned, these days you can spend $400,000 or $500,000 on a manufactured home. Of course, firstly you have to reach agreement with the owner and have a site agreement, but the difficulty and cost that it might take to remove the home should always be considered when you are constructing what is effectively a home on someone else’s land. When talking about investments like that, they should be taking legal advice and considering very carefully the difficulties which the member for Nicklin has pointed out in the event that they want to relocate the home.

The member for Maroochydore mentioned concerns about QCAT. It is not appropriate to comment on the merits of the decision; however, I note the member’s concerns about short time frames for termination orders to take effect and point out that the bill allows the tribunal to postpone a termination order for 12 months.

In closing, I would like to thank the honourable members who contributed to this debate and also those who took the time, as I mentioned, to make personal representations. I would also like to thank former ministers for their work on this legislation, including the member for Albert, Margaret Keech, who commenced the review of the act in 2007 and who accompanied me on a very informative and enjoyable visit to a purpose-built manufactured home park, Halcyon Waters, at Hope Island. Further, I would like to thank the member for Bundamba for the very informative visit, as I mentioned, to Brisbane River Terraces in her electorate.

I would like to thank the literally hundreds of manufactured home owners, homeowners’ committees, residential park owners, and consumer and industry representatives who have shared their experiences, expertise and suggestions during the consultation processes conducted during the review and in the development of this important bill. I also thank the departmental staff, including Damian Sammon, David Reardon, Stuart Busby, Anita Eenink and Tafline Gibson for their continued efforts, hard work, assistance, and also my staff, in progressing these significant amendments. I commend the bill to the House.

Motion agreed to.
