XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: BHP Billiton Mitsubishi Alliance, Caval Ridge Mine
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP) (9.41 pm): I bring to the attention of the House the move by the BHP Billiton Mitsubishi Alliance to increase its fly in, fly out workforce at the Caval Ridge Mine site near Moranbah from 70 per cent to 100 per cent. This application has generated great emotion in Moranbah and mining communities. The residents have every right to be angry because a 100 per cent fly in, fly out workforce would spell social and economic disaster for the Bowen Basin region.

Mining communities in rural Queensland are already suffering from the strain that a high percentage fly in, fly out workforce presents. In his evaluation report the Coordinator-General states that there has been a noticeable decline in the viability of businesses and community organisations as the proportion of the non-resident population in and around these towns has increased. Also a 100 per cent fly in, fly out workforce is in direct contradiction to the government’s growth management strategy to, ‘Ensure economic developments promote growth in rural Queensland.’

I say to the government that approval of this application will not only be not prudent; it will set a dangerous precedent that will commit the long-term sustainability of rural mining communities in Queensland to years of disadvantage and the ruination of lifestyles. The growth of rural Queensland is dependent on families being given the opportunity to remain together, which will encourage social interaction and community participation and ensure the health, growth and sustainability of towns like Moranbah into the future. A non-resident workforce whose families live in urban centres will not have the opportunity to contribute to communities that are already heavily burdened with the negative impact of a high percentage non-resident workforce.

This is an opportunity for the government to demonstrate a commitment to sustainable rural communities by rejecting any application of a 100 per cent fly in, fly out workforce. The sustainability and future growth of Moranbah, the Bowen Basin region and all mining communities in Queensland is threatened by this application. The government must act decisively to ensure that permanent infrastructure and housing are mandatory to future mining development in this state.

I call on the members of this government, as they wait for BMA application, to spend a week in Moranbah’s shoes and they will find that it is more than just a mining town that rakes in revenue for the Treasury coffers. It is a community where parents are raising their children, grandparents are retiring and families are participating to ensure they can enjoy the quality of life that this community has to offer. In reality, Moranbah is a place they call home.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP) (9.44 pm): I wish to bring to the attention of the House an initiative that has ignited the industrious sounds of grinders, hammers and saws; sparked the development of great comradeship; and, in such a short time, has made a significant contribution to the Labrador community spirit by enhancing the lives of many. The Labrador Men’s Shed officially opened its doors on 12 August this year. It was a celebration of the volunteer efforts of a number of local men who had the goal of establishing a men’s shed on the northern Gold Coast. John and Graeme Muller and Warren Fowler were instrumental in establishing the Labrador Men’s Shed. Their drive and enthusiasm captured the attention of many as they pushed for a space, donations for timber and money to get their men’s shed up and running.

The Labrador Men’s Shed, which is located in a complex known as the Hub, on the corner of Brisbane Road and Turpin Road, Labrador, is the place for any man over the age of 18 to work on their own projects or help out with some of the great community projects that the men’s shed is involved in. To date, over 80 men have joined the men’s shed. Some of them live in units or in gated communities where a man’s shed does not exist. Some men live locally in houses but just want to be part of a group of men who love to work with tools, have a coffee and a chat and be part of the community.

It could be said that what happens at the shed, stays at the shed. However, this army of merry and busy men are working on lots of projects that they are very proud to tell people about and have other men participate in. One community project that has great support, and which is a well-established one, is local Peter Fernside’s project of converting gas bottles into cooking barbecues for Pacific Islander communities. Other projects include the construction of possum boxes and children’s toys, led by Tony Harris offering ‘shedders’ loads of opportunity to work with wood and to help out some local charities.

The men’s shed has already provided the nearby Child and Family Centre with a sandpit box for the kids and has established strong partnerships with the local primary school, police and other government and non-government organisations. The state government’s Positively Ageless--Queensland Seniors Strategy 2010 to 2020 recognises that encouraging active ageing and supporting participation in the community are crucial to enhancing seniors’ quality of life. The government has set a goal to reduce social isolation for seniors through increased community participation in an inclusive and age-friendly community. Whilst the government will investigate and undertake a variety of initiatives, it cannot do it alone. The role of men’s sheds like this one in Labrador will contribute significantly to achieving this goal of reducing social isolation.

At the open day for the men’s shed many wives and family members commented to me about how happy their men were now that they had somewhere to go and to make noise, tinker and be productive. I am pleased to be able to support this wonderful community group and I look forward to hearing more about its success and the ‘shedders’ projects.

Mr STEVENS (Mermaid Beach--LNP) (9.37 pm): I rise to bring to the attention of this House the deception and blatant trickery by the Bligh Labor government of the students, staff, families and surrounding residents of the Broadbeach State School in my electorate of Mermaid Beach.

When I asked the question of the education minister, Mr Wilson, in November 2009, ‘Are there any plans to sell the Broadbeach State School?’ his written was response, ‘There are no plans to sell the Broadbeach State School.’ Yet the officers of Education Queensland have come clean on their plans to flog off most of the school site land and put 600 kids in a high-rise for their education. Either the minister for education was deliberately misleading with his answer in November 2009 or he does not have a clue about what his own department is getting up to. Considering the desperate financial mess that this Labor government has got the state of Queensland into, I think the former is most likely the case. If the government is desperate enough to sell Parklands showgrounds for private high-density housing, then it is desperate enough to sell the Broadbeach State School for high-rise development.

The minister’s latest reply to my question on notice on 16 September this year about the sale of the school was to use sneaky polliespeak and say that there are no current--and I emphasise the word ‘current’, translating into meaning before the next election--plans to sell the Broadbeach State School. If the minister were genuine in his defence of retaining this valuable community asset, he would have ruled out the sale completely. Instead he used weasel words such as, ‘The department would need to undertake further detailed analysis,’ which is similar wording that the Labor Party used before the last election about the sale of Queensland Rail.

The students, staff, families and surrounding residents can be assured that the LNP will not be sacrificing this wonderful school and its associated land to pay for the horrendous financial black hole that this Labor government has dug itself into. The Broadbeach State School community has a clear choice at the next election between the Labor Party, which is exploring sneaky and underhanded ways by which to sell off their valuable public asset without consulting them, or the LNP, which is committed to retaining the current site and enhancing its value as an education facility.

The school has almost doubled its numbers since I became the representative in 2006 and there will only be increasing demand for the school in the years ahead, particularly if the light rail option stopping in Broadbeach in stage 1 ever comes to fruition. Premier Bligh needs to put her unqualified vow to the students, families and residents surrounding Broadbeach State School that she will not sell any of this magnificent public asset under any circumstances. If she refuses to make that commitment, the public can expect another dodgy public asset sale after the next election if Labor wins. This property is at the centre of many highrises that have many people living in them who need that open space and need that school for their families for the future of a wonderful Gold Coast and a great Mermaid Beach electorate.

Mrs SMITH (Burleigh--ALP)
(9.50 pm): Almost half of the Australian adult population will experience a form of mental illness at some stage during their life, yet two-thirds of those experiencing a mental illness do not seek treatment, largely due to the stigma attached to it. Mental illness does not attract the same empathy as other conditions. I find it hard to believe that in 2010 there are many people who still do not see mental illness as a medical condition. I am proud to be part of a government that is taking steps to reduce the stigma attached to mental health. We are leading the nation with an $8.5 million campaign to reduce the stigma and discrimination associated with mental illness.

Mental Health Week provides an excellent opportunity to raise awareness of the importance of looking after our mental health and reducing the stigma attached to mental illness. Mental health is a state of wellbeing. It is not just the absence of illness but also the ability to maintain relationships, cope with stress, contribute to the community and enjoy life. Good mental health helps us to more fully enjoy life and the world around us. We respond better to the stresses and challenges of daily life when our mental health is good. The reality is that the vast majority of people who suffer from mental illness do not need to be admitted to acute hospital beds; what they need is treatment and support. Mental Health Week is celebrated in October each year. While it is an opportunity to highlight the positive steps we are taking, we need to commit every day of the year to ongoing recognition of mental health issues and how we might address them.

During Mental Health Week I attended an art exhibition staged by clients of the Gold Coast Mental Health Rehabilitation Service and supported by Gold Coast Hospital clinicians and staff, many of whom were present on opening night. Although I am not artistic, I understand that creating artwork is very therapeutic. It can convey emotions that we may be reluctant to show and speak to us about things we do not want to say. This exhibition was on display at the Southport Public Library and allowed the wider community to see and touch the works and to marvel at the talent displayed. It also helped to promote better understanding of mental illness within the community. I thank those clients who shared with us on the night not only their artwork but also their stories of loss of good mental health and the journey to recovery.

It is not good enough to just wear a ribbon, attend an event and pat ourselves on the back for acknowledging the issue of mental illness. We need to increase awareness and develop research aimed at reducing the incidence of mental illness. Statistics show that one in four of us will be affected by mental illness, either directly or indirectly. It could be our partners, our children or even ourselves. We cannot afford to ignore this issue.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Glass House Electorate, Health Services; Caloundra South Development
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP)
(9.53 pm): Before I speak on a significant electoral matter, I would like to pause and personally thank some very important people. Last Thursday my wife, Taryn, was taken via ambulance to the emergency department of the Nambour General Hospital. I would like to start by thanking Matt and Martin from the Queensland Ambulance Service at the Nambour station for their professionalism and comic relief in what was a stressful situation for Taryn, me and our five kids. I know that Taryn had to ask them to stop the wisecracks because it was hurting too much, but their levity certainly helped us all.

To the staff at the emergency department, particularly doctors Andrew and Lisa and wardsman Gary, thank you. Your quick and skilful intervention means Taryn is well and truly on the mend and, Gary, thanks for helping me corral the kids at various times throughout the day. Quite simply, we do not praise the work of our front-line health professionals near enough, so let me take this opportunity to personally say a heartfelt thankyou.

On a less pleasant note, since the Bligh Labor government announced that the Caloundra South development would be taken away from the Sunshine Coast Regional Council and handed to the ULDA my office has been inundated by community concern and outrage. Whilst I appreciate there is a need to identify and progress suitable sites for development, I share many of the concerns raised by my constituents.

Firstly, the project was removed from the oversight of the relevant local government. Throughout Queensland it is local government that plans and approves developments such as this. They, better than any other tier of government, are in touch with the sentiments of our constituents in these matters and aim to reflect this in their decisions. By removing this project from local government oversight the Bligh Labor government could be accused of removing a local voice in the progress of the Caloundra South development.

The transfer of the project to the ULDA also removes a number of checks and balances that would normally exist around such developments--another cause for alarm with Glass House locals. Then there are the environmental implications. The council has spent considerable time and money on investigating the environmental challenges posed by this particular development, not least of which is the ongoing status of the Pumicestone Passage and its catchments. Just last week the Ecosystem Health Report Card showed that the passage itself had fallen from a C plus to a D plus rating and the catchments from a B to a C minus. The council will be making its studies available to the ULDA but I would encourage the authority to go further and ensure that there is a full environmental assessment of the development site and its environs. If the outcomes do not add up, do not force the issue.

Finally, if this development is to be fast-tracked, we on the Sunshine Coast need vital infrastructure now. We need the CAMCOS now--not a fast bus system from Landsborough to Caloundra, but a rail solution from Beerwah to Maroochydore. If not, all the newcomers to the coast will become car dependent and our roads excessively congested. We need the Sunshine Coast University Hospital now. This is yet another example of the Bligh Labor government foisting its demands upon the people of the Sunshine Coast while it continues to ignore the desires and reasonable requests of the same people.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP)
(9.56 pm): On 9 September, the Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport, the Hon. Phil Reeves, and I officially opened stage 1 and the ground floor of a planned three-storey complex for rowing, canoeing and community use at the Centenary Rowing Club facilities at Riverhills. The state government has provided grants totalling $585,000 to help build the first public rowing club for youth on the Brisbane River in nearly a century.

The ground floor area is dominated by boat storage and washdown areas, and also has a coach’s room and wheelchair accessible areas. Once it is complete, the club’s new facility will provide a wonderful home base for Queensland rowers ensuring they will have the necessary facilities to become champions.

With 180 junior members, the club is already a first-class community asset. Centenary can take great pride in its youth rowing program, which club executives believe is unique in Australia. As the Parliamentary Secretary for Disability Services, I am pleased to say that the club is strongly committed to including people with a disability in their activities. The club reaches out to schools and the community to offer young people not only coaching and exercise but also social and personal development.

The idea of a state-of-the-art clubhouse along the Brisbane River in Centenary started over 14 years ago with approaches to local authorities made by Peter Cooke on behalf of the Centenary Canoe Club, as it was then called. Peter Cooke joined forces with Russell Poole from the rowing club to take their cause forward as the Centenary Canoe and Rowing Club. Since then, water sports have continued to thrive at what locals call the Mudhole, situated behind the Jindalee Scout Hut along Mount Ommaney Drive. I would hope that their work will continue to be acknowledged in the future and that the new facility and pontoon at the end of Sumners Road becomes home to both canoeing and rowing enthusiasts and is shared by a number of local community organisations looking for a place to meet.

I am also very proud of the fact that the state government has recently contributed to many worthwhile sporting organisations in the area through the Gambling Community Benefit Fund and sport and recreation grants. Some of the clubs with recent funding include the Centenary Archers Club, Jindalee Districts Australian Football Club, the YMCA, the Centenary Canoeing and Kayaking Club and the Corinda Bowls Club. I often attend trophy presentations or awards days for the Centenary Stormers Soccer Club, the Centenary Junior Rugby League Club, Little Athletics, the Jamboree Heights Swimming Club, the Oxley Swimming Club, St Catherine’s Soccer Club and the Oxley United Football Club. It is great to see so many volunteers and young players making an extraordinary effort in their chosen sport. All of my local sporting clubs do a fantastic job keeping the enthusiasm going for participation in healthy physical activities. They continue to expand their memberships and endeavour to undertake improvements to their facilities for the benefit of young people in the area.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (9.59 pm): Last Friday the Bligh Labor government yet again succumbed to people power in the electorate of Mudgeeraba with another backflip on road issues. In the lead-up to the 2009 election it was fairly obvious to local residents that they had been severely neglected by the Labor government and by their Labor state member, who for eight long years had failed to listen to residents’ concerns about the increasing traffic gridlock which has now become commonly known as the ‘Mudgeeraba car park’.

Residents will well remember the postcard campaign on local roads that I waged during the election, and the removal of the north-bound on-ramp at Robina Parkway at exit 82 was just one of many spot fires lit under the former member. The Bligh Labor government ignored local residents and planned to remove the on-ramp and replace it with a service road running parallel with the M1 in the flood plain with little consultation with the locals. Local residents were already up in arms with 1,500 cars a day using their local streets to avoid congestion on the overpass.

In response to our protest card campaign, over 75 per cent of local residents signed a protest card and posted it to the Premier, demanding that the on-ramp stay open in order to avoid clogging the overpass, prevent rat-running through local streets and ensure that their homes were not further devalued due to traffic congestion and noise concerns. Just last week I received a response from the Premier whereby both she and the Minister for Main Roads had performed a monumental backflip. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The department advises that during the early planning for this project the possibility of removing the on-ramp to the M1 at Robina Interchange (Exit 82) was investigated. However, it was discounted some time ago. Please reassure your constituents that the department does not intend to close the ramp.
XML.Hansard-Body: Of interest, following discussions with Main Roads only a few days later, they had no knowledge of the on-ramp change. On Friday local residents and I met with Channel 9 Gold Coast News to make sure that neither the Premier nor the Minister for Main Roads performed a backflip on their own backflip.

When questioned by the media on the Gold Coast, the Premier appeared to have no knowledge of the issue even though the letter was personalised to me by the Premier with a specific request that I reassure my constituents that they had finally won their battle. This is one of a number of hard-fought battles that residents and I have waged in the Mudgeeraba electorate. I have been dubbed by our local media as the ‘member for the M1’. I think that this arrogant Labor government is finally learning what people power is in Mudgeeraba as locals are sick and tired of this arrogant, out-of-touch, on-the-nose Labor government.

Ms FARMER (Bulimba--ALP) (10.01 pm): I use this opportunity to praise a wonderful group of young people who operate out of the Bulimba electorate and the equally wonderful couple who coordinate the group. I am referring to TS Gayundah, the naval cadets unit which runs from the historic Bulimba Barracks.

TS Gayundah is the oldest cadet unit in Queensland, having been first established in 1954. I had the very good fortune to be introduced to its members not long after I was elected when their new commanding officers, Phil and Wendy Broxham, invited me to one of their parades. I did not really know at that point what a treat was in store for me. However, having now become a regular visitor at their special events since this first parade, having worked closely with Phil and Wendy as they have strived to develop the unit and having seen these young people grow in stature and confidence, I can say that I am now a very enthusiastic member of the TS Gayundah fan club. The discipline that the cadet unit offers to young people, the skills, the respect for authority, the understanding of what it is to work as a team, the encouragement to take pride in oneself and one’s work--these are just some of the many things these young men and women have learnt.

When I first met TS Gayundah, the unit had around 18 members. Eighteen months later, they have almost 40 members. This is due in no small part to Phil and Wendy Broxham. I understand that it is often difficult to recruit members in metropolitan units as there are so many other options competing for the attention of people of this age. However, Phil and Wendy, by being the positive, determined people that they are, have forged a unit which is cohesive and purposeful and which responds in spades to the high expectations and also to the genuine love and caring that Phil and Wendy have for them.

The achievements of the unit are also acknowledged elsewhere. The unit itself was recently named the best unit in the Brisbane flotilla and came eighth overall in Australia. The community also recognises them. I know they were in great demand on the last Anzac Day, making no less than seven appearances at both the local RSL service and at various nursing homes around the area on behalf of the RSL.

One of the greatest aspirations of the group over the last 18 months has been to attend some of the significant battle sites in Europe, culminating in a dawn service at Villers Bretonneux. This has required some significant fundraising, which I know has presented its challenges and which has been a goal that has sometimes seemed unattainable. However, with their usual determination and inability to ever give up, the group is now well on its way towards its fundraising goal. Again, Phil and Wendy Broxham have been the linchpins and have done remarkable work.

I want to congratulate this outstanding group of young people on the way they have developed as people and on their commitment to their community. As we think about Remembrance Day in just two weeks time, it is particularly wonderful to see the respect and admiration of the unit for our armed services personnel, both past and present, and for what they have done for our country. I look forward to working with TS Gayundah in the future and watching them grow even further.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.04 pm): I rise and table a report given to me by Townsville mother Ann Maitland. This is the second report regarding the tragic death of her daughter Michelle Maitland in June 2009 at Gymnastics Townsville. Since the first report was tabled on 6 October this year, several concerned gym professionals have approached Ann and me with important technical information and observations. It is vital for this House to consider the facts and informed expert opinions found in this report. Workplace Health and Safety Queensland is out of its depth in addressing these matters. On behalf of Ann, I would like to thank the Attorney-General, Cameron Dick, and Premier Anna Bligh for their genuine interest and concern in this serious and tragic matter. I know the Premier took the time to personally meet with Ann. That was very much appreciated, as well as the Premier organising a meeting with the Attorney-General.

Bundaberg nurse whistleblower Christine Cameron has been waiting for 18 months for an official response from Queensland Health to her very serious allegations of patient harm as a result of possible misconduct by employees of Queensland Health. I have spoken often in this place about her concerns and the extraordinary delay that the ESU has been responsible for. Tonight I want to express my disgust at the public comments made by the manager of the Bundaberg Base Hospital, Beth Norton, in response to recent media stories about nurse whistleblower Christine Cameron. Ms Norton’s recent comments are nothing more than an attempt to minimise the seriousness of Ms Cameron’s allegations and to limit political damage. There are unexplained deaths. An elderly woman was tied to a chair. A child was assaulted. Patients’ lives and their wellbeing were placed at risk. Peter Leck and Darren Keating, Patel’s bosses, would be proud of Norton’s devotion to a political party’s misinformation.

I would like to thank Bargara dentist Lincoln Harris of Harris Dental, who donated $50,000 worth of free dental to Gin Gin resident Caroline Michell. Dr Harris profoundly changed Caroline’s life and made sure that Caroline and Adam, her husband, were able to have a beautiful wedding with lots of smiles last weekend. Caroline is a victim of this government’s failed dental health system. Because of a medical condition, she suffered from severe dental decay. Despite being on a public waiting list for years, she was not there long enough to overcome the eight-year waiting list at the Bundaberg Base Hospital. I want to congratulate the Burnett community and the media, who all rallied to help Caroline, her husband, Adam, and her disabled son, Patrick. The Burnett community rallied after the media exposed Caroline’s plight and donated generously. Caroline and Adam are battlers who have had more than their fair share of bad luck. Hopefully, their wedding signifies a new beginning.

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr PITT (Mulgrave--ALP) (10.07 pm): I was thrilled to join Deputy Premier and Minister for Health, Paul Lucas, and emergency services minister, Neil Roberts, to open the new $16.3 million Gurriny Yealamucka Primary Health Care facility at Yarrabah last week, delivering on a long-held commitment that was started through the hard work of the former member. Queensland Health, the Queensland Ambulance Service and Gurriny Yealamucka Health Service Aboriginal Corporation are all co-located at the centre in a unique partnership that will become the model for future projects. The primary healthcare centre brings together a wide range of medical, community and other health services and their existing staff under one roof. The brand new building includes a multi-purpose meeting room and boardroom for the community and services that aim to improve service delivery and encourage a holistic approach to health.

Yarrabah’s two paramedics attended more than 650 jobs last financial year, 170 of which were life-threatening emergencies. This investment recognises the commitment our paramedics make to the Yarrabah community and the value we place on providing the community with health services of the highest standard.

The importance of providing a one-stop shop for health services cannot be underestimated. One of the fantastic features of this joint facility is that paramedics can drive their patient into the station and deliver them directly into the centre’s emergency facility through an adjoining purpose-built door. This saves valuable time and ensures paramedics and health centre staff can continue to work together to achieve the best possible outcome for the patient.

Queensland Health already provides a range of services in Yarrabah, including emergency triage, outpatient palliative care, primary clinical care, immunisation, child health, renal, health promotion and education, support for victims of sexual and domestic violence and transport services to larger centres for urgent and elective medical needs. The centre will also provide facilities for visiting health specialists such as mental health, alcohol and drug services, the child development unit, diabetes services, the eye health team, social workers, GPs, TB screening and more.

The new service at Yarrabah, along with Mapoon and Kowanyama on Cape York, is one of the three pilot sites chosen to transition Queensland Health’s primary health services in discrete Indigenous communities towards greater community control. The opening of this facility and co-location sets the stage for more detailed discussions about how we can work with Gurriny health to increase the community’s involvement in the planning, allocation of resources and delivery of health services in Yarrabah. This includes increasing the number of Aboriginal people delivering those services. On that point, it is fitting that the new building will be named after Sister Muriel Stanley, and will be a worthy memorial to her and her dedication to improving Indigenous health and supporting Indigenous people. My hope is that young people in the community will all know Sister Muriel’s story. I have no doubt that many will seek to emulate her contribution and become health workers and leaders in the community themselves.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 10.09 pm.
